Quiz Results

Part 76 of 85 (Quiz Attempts 751-760)

Quiz Attempt #119706

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in five different cities A-E along with the ratio of the number of people in three different age groups I, II, and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:What is the ratio of the number of people of age group-I of city A and D together to the number of people of age group-I of city C and E together?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.1:2
  • B.1:1
  • C.2:1
  • D.3:2
Correct Answer: 1:1

Required ratio = 16×14.4+38×12.814×19.2+15×12 = 7.27.2 = 1:1

Question 2
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in five different cities A-E along with the ratio of the number of people in three different age groups I, II, and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Number of people in age group III of city D is ______% more than that of age group II of city B.(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.7%
  • B.614%
  • C.623%
  • D.6%
Correct Answer: 623%

Required Percentage = 48×12.8-38×1638×16 × 100 = 6 23 %

Question 3
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in five different cities A-E along with the ratio of the number of people in three different age groups I, II, and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:The difference between the total number of people in age group II of city A and B together and age group III of city C and E together is:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.2 lakhs
  • B.1.2 lakhs
  • C.2.4 lakhs
  • D.0.8 lakhs
Correct Answer: 1.2 lakhs

Required Difference = 36×14.4+38×16 - 24×19.2+15×12

= 13.2 – 12

= 1.2

Question 4
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in five different cities A-E along with the ratio of the number of people in three different age groups I, II, and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Number of people of age group I is more than 4 lakhs in exactly ______ city/cities.(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.one
  • B.two
  • C.three
  • D.four
Correct Answer: two

Number of people of age group I is more than 4 lakhs in exactly 2 city/cities

Question 5
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in five different cities A-E along with the ratio of the number of people in three different age groups I, II, and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:For city C, if the number of people who will turn 21 years of age next year is 16000; the number of new born will be 32000, and the number of people in age group III will remain the same, then what will be the new ratio of people in different age groups?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.31:31:60
  • B.31:32:60
  • C.31:32:56
  • D.21:23:35
Correct Answer: 31:31:60

Current people are 480000, 480000 and 960000

New ratio will be 496000 : 496000 : 960000

= 31 : 31 : 60

Question 6
Which of the following tool is used to create pre and post-session polls to gauge students learning from each session?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Mentimeter
  • B.Github
  • C.Plotagon
  • D.Labster
Correct Answer: Mentimeter

Mentimeter is an interactive presentation tool that allows educators to create live polls, quizzes, word clouds, and especially pre- and post-session polls to gauge student learning and engagement during or after a session.

 

Other options:

 

(B) GitHub – A platform for version control and code collaboration, not for polling or educational assessment.

 

(C) Plotagon – A tool for creating animated videos, not for polls or quizzes.

 

(D) Labster – A virtual lab simulation tool used for teaching science subjects, but not designed for creating polls.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 7
The style that involves a student's tendency to take more time to respond on the accuracy of answers is known as:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Impulsive style
  • B.Surface style
  • C.Reflective style
  • D.Manipulative style
Correct Answer: Reflective style

A Reflective style refers to a student’s tendency to:

 

  • Take more time before responding,

 

  • Carefully analyze options, and

 

  • Prioritize accuracy over speed.

 

This is the opposite of impulsive style, where students respond quickly but often less accurately.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 8
“If a student gets a part time job in an architect's office and applies what was learnt in geometry class to help the architect analyze a spatial problem that is quite different from any problem the student encountered in geometry class” is an example of _______ learning?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Near transfer
  • B.Forward-reaching transfer
  • C.Low-road transfer
  • D.Far transfer
Correct Answer: Far transfer

Far transfer occurs when knowledge or skills learned in one context are applied to a very different or unfamiliar situation.

 

In this case, the student uses geometry knowledge in a real-world architectural setting, solving a problem that is quite different from classroom examples.

 

Thus, option (D) is correct.

Question 9
Match the List-I with List-IIList I (ICT Tools)A. Learning Management System (LMS)B. Virtual RealityC. Video ConferencingD. PodcastList II (Example)I. ZoomII. CanvasIII. AudacityIV. VirbelaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
  • B.A-I, B-III, C-IV, D-II
  • C.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • D.A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III

Let’s match each ICT Tool with its correct example:

 

A. Learning Management System (LMS) → II. Canvas

Canvas is a well-known LMS used for managing courses, assignments, and student interactions.

 

B. Virtual Reality → IV. Virbela

Virbela is a platform that uses virtual reality to create immersive environments for education and collaboration.

 

C. Video Conferencing → I. Zoom

Zoom is a widely used video conferencing tool for live classes, meetings, and webinars.

 

D. Podcast → III. Audacity

Audacity is an audio editing tool often used to record and produce podcasts.

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Question 10
Which of the following is an example of positive-transfer of learning?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Mastering algebra helps in understanding calculus.
  • B.Learning to play piano makes it more difficult to learn the violin.
  • C.Knowing how to drive a car makes it harder to learn how to ride a bicycle.
  • D.Learning to speak French hinders learning Spanish.
Correct Answer: Mastering algebra helps in understanding calculus.

Positive transfer of learning occurs when previous learning helps or facilitates the learning of a new skill or concept.

 

In this case:

 

Algebra provides foundational skills such as manipulating equations, understanding variables, and logical reasoning.

 

These skills directly support and ease the learning of calculus, which builds on them.

 

Other Options (they are examples of negative transfer):

(B) Piano and violin involve different hand techniques and postures – may interfere with learning.

 

(C) Driving a car and riding a bicycle involve different motor skills – could cause confusion.

 

(D) French and Spanish, though similar, may cause interference due to overlapping vocabulary and grammar.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 11
A quantitative research would be mainly concerned withA. measurementB. causalityC. contextD. replicationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.A, B and D Only
  • C.B, C and D Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: A, B and D Only

Quantitative research focuses on measurement (A), causality (B), and replication (D). It involves collecting numerical data and analyzing it statistically to determine relationships between variables and ensure the results can be reproduced. Context (C) is more of a concern in qualitative research rather than quantitative research.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) A, B and D Only.

Question 12
The criterion of ‘credibility’ in qualitative research is equivalent to which of the following criteria in quantitative research?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.external validity
  • B.internal validity
  • C.objectivity
  • D.reliability
Correct Answer: internal validity

In qualitative research, credibility refers to the confidence that can be placed in the truth of the research findings. It is similar to internal validity in quantitative research, which refers to how well the study measures what it intends to measure and whether the results truly reflect the phenomena being studied.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) internal validity.

Question 13
Identify correct statements about content analysis.A. The main use of content analysis has been in the examination of printed texts and documents.B. Content analysis lacks transparency.C. Coding is crucial in content analysis.D. It is almost impossible to devise coding manuals that do not entail some interpretation on the part of coders.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.A, C and D Only
  • D.A, B and D Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

The correct statements about content analysis are:

A: The main use of content analysis has indeed been in examining printed texts and documents, where researchers analyze the frequency of words, themes, or patterns in the text.

C: Coding is crucial in content analysis, as it helps to categorize and quantify data systematically.

D: It is almost impossible to devise coding manuals that do not require some level of interpretation by the coders, as different coders may interpret some aspects of the content differently.

B is incorrect because content analysis is a systematic and transparent method for analyzing qualitative data.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) A, C and D Only.

Question 14
The numerator and denominator degrees of freedom are used in which of the following test-statistic in hypothesis testing?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.t
  • B.F
  • C.Z
  • D.χ² (chi square)
Correct Answer: F

In hypothesis testing, the F-test involves both numerator and denominator degrees of freedom. The numerator degrees of freedom typically come from the variance between groups, and the denominator degrees of freedom come from the variance within groups.

Question 15
Sharpness of the peak of a statistical distribution is represented by(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Kurtosis
  • B.Skewness
  • C.Mean
  • D.Median
Correct Answer: Kurtosis

The sharpness of the peak of a statistical distribution is represented by kurtosis. Kurtosis measures the "tailedness" or sharpness of the peak of the distribution, indicating whether the data have heavy or light tails compared to a normal distribution.

Skewness (B) measures the asymmetry of the distribution, not the peak.

Mean (C) and Median (D) are measures of central tendency and do not describe the shape of the peak.

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Kurtosis.

Question 16
A symbol that represents an idea or thought in non-verbal communication is referred to as(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Hidden symbol
  • B.Effective symbol
  • C.Abstract symbol
  • D.Ideational symbol
Correct Answer: Abstract symbol

In non-verbal communication, a symbol that represents an idea or thought is most accurately described as an abstract symbol. It does not depict a physical object directly. It stands for ideas, emotions, or intangible concepts.

 

For example:

  • A heart symbol ❤️ for love,

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 17
In any conventional media, the point of content production and the point of consumption involve(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Temporal separation
  • B.Imaginary hurdles
  • C.Free marketing
  • D.Technological over-dependence
Correct Answer: Temporal separation

conventional (traditional) media like newspapers, television, or radio:

 

The content is produced at one point in time (e.g., a news bulletin prepared in the morning),

 

And it is consumed by the audience at a later time (e.g., evening news watched at 9 PM).

 

This delay between production and consumption is called temporal separation.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 18
What do people basically want to extract from the communicated message?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Compulsions
  • B.Meaning
  • C.Synergy
  • D.Behavioural pattern
Correct Answer: Meaning

At its core, communication is about conveying and understanding meaning.

 

Whether verbal, written, or non-verbal, people interpret messages to extract meaning — to understand the intent, emotion, or information behind the message.

 

This helps them respond appropriately, make decisions, or form opinions.

 

Thus, option (B) is correct.

Question 19
Making way for technologies of automation is ________ transformation of modern society(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Cyber-nation
  • B.Mechanical
  • C.Political
  • D.Artificial
Correct Answer: Cyber-nation

Cyber-nation refers to the transformation of society through automation and computer-based technologies. It involves integrating cybernetic systems (like computers, robotics, and AI) into various sectors such as industry, governance, and services.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 20
In the early stages of development, broadcast media were marked by:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Positive communication
  • B.Negative communication
  • C.One-way communication
  • D.Two-way communication
Correct Answer: One-way communication

In the early stages of broadcast media (such as radio and television):

 

The flow of information was unidirectional — from the sender (broadcaster) to the receiver (audience).

 

There was no immediate feedback or interaction from the audience.

 

This is called one-way communication, where the audience plays a passive role.

Question 21
If a person travels in a car at a speed of 36 km/hour, then he will reach his destination on time. He covers half the journey in (4/5)ᵗʰ time. What should be his speed for the remaining part of the journey so that he reaches his destination on time?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.80 km/hour
  • B.75 km/hour
  • C.90 km/hour
  • D.85 km/hour
Correct Answer: 90 km/hour

Let D be the distance.

Time for whole journey = D36

Let S should be speed for second half distance

Then, D2S = D36 - 45 × D36

or D2S = 15 × D36

or s = 90

Question 22
Let L and M be the sum and average of four consecutive odd numbers (a, b, c and d) respectively, and, P and Q be the sum and average of three consecutive even numbers (x, y and z) respectively. If M = Q – 6 and P = L – 16, then M =(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.32
  • B.34
  • C.36
  • D.30
Correct Answer: 34

L = a + b + c + d

M = a + b + c + d4 = L4

P = x + y + z

Q = P3

M = Q – 6 = P3 – 6

or L4 = P3 – 6

or 4P = 3L + 72 -------(i)

Also, P = L – 16 --------------(ii)

Solving (i) and (ii), we get

L = 136

M = L4 = 34

Question 23
Three positive numbers are in the ratio 2 : 3 : 4. If the sum of their squares is 2349, then the numbers respectively are(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.14, 21 and 28
  • B.18, 27 and 36
  • C.16, 24 and 32
  • D.12, 18 and 24
Correct Answer: 18, 27 and 36

Let numbers are 2x, 3x and 4x

Then, (2x)2+(3x)2+(4x)2 = 2349

or 29x2 = 2349

or x2 = 81

or x = 9

Numbers are 18, 27 and 36

Question 24
In a certain coding scheme the word ‘SCHOLAR’ is coded as ‘TEKSQGY’. In the same coding scheme, the word ‘GREEN’ will be coded as(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.ITGGP
  • B.HTHIS
  • C.EPCGP
  • D.JUHHQ
Correct Answer: HTHIS

The difference between letters is increasing by 1.

Thus, correct code will be HTHIS

Question 25
In what time will a sum of money double itself at the rate of 12.5% per annum simple interest?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.10 years
  • B.8 years
  • C.6 years
  • D.12 years
Correct Answer: 8 years

Let P be the principal and t be the time.

Then, P = P×12.5×T100

or T = 10012.5 = 8 years

Question 26
‘Abhay’s mind is a cave, deep, dark and full of bats.’ Which of the following is correct about the above statement?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.It contains analogical argument.
  • B.It is a valid and sound argument.
  • C.It contains analogy.
  • D.It is a valid but not a sound argument.
Correct Answer: It contains analogy.

The statement ‘Abhay’s mind is a cave, deep, dark and full of bats.’ is an example of a metaphor, rather than an analogy. A metaphor directly compares two unrelated things to highlight their similarities, whereas an analogy would explain the comparison in a more detailed manner, usually showing how two things are alike in several respects.

Question 27
Arrange the following terms in order of decreasing in intension:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)A. Baseball playerB. AthleteC. FielderD. Ball player
  • A.C, D, A, B
  • B.B, A, D, C
  • C.C, A, D, B
  • D.B, D, A, C
Correct Answer: C, A, D, B

The term intension refers to the degree of specificity or the number of attributes included in the concept. In decreasing order of intension, we go from the most specific term to the most general term:

C. Fielder is the most specific, as it refers to a specific position in baseball.

A. Baseball player is more general than "fielder," but still specific to the context of baseball.

D. Ball player is less specific than "baseball player" as it can apply to any sport involving a ball.

B. Athlete is the broadest term, as it encompasses all individuals who engage in any kind of sport or physical activity, not limited to ball games.

 

So, the correct order of decreasing intension is: C, D, A, B.

Thus, the correct answer is (A) C, D, A, B.

Question 28
I have read that one aspirin taken every day reduces the risk of heart attack. Why not take two a day and double the protection? Which informal fallacy is committed in the above statement?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Fallacy of composition
  • B.Begging the question
  • C.Hasty generalisation
  • D.Slippery slope
Correct Answer: Fallacy of composition

The fallacy committed in the statement "I have read that one aspirin taken every day reduces the risk of heart attack. Why not take two a day and double the protection?" is actually the fallacy of composition (A).

 

The fallacy of composition occurs when one assumes that what is true for a part is also true for the whole. In this case, the statement assumes that because one aspirin reduces the risk of heart attack, taking two aspirins will double the protection, which is not necessarily true. The relationship between aspirin dosage and heart attack risk is more complex and may not be linearly proportional.

Question 29
Which of the following statements are logically equivalent?A. Some beverages are not liquids.B. Some beverages are liquids.C. Some non-liquids are not non-beverages.D. Some beverages are non-liquids.(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.B and C Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

Some non-liquids are not non-beverage is CONTRAPOSITION of Some beverages are not liquids.

 

Some beverages are non-liquids is OBVERSION of Some beverages are not liquids.

Question 30
According to classical Indian School of Logic (Nyāya) the statement “fire is cold because it is a substance” is fallacious because:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.It has a non-inferentially contradicted middle term.
  • B.The middle term has an impossible locus.
  • C.The middle term instead of proving its presence in major term proves its absence.
  • D.The major term proves its presence.
Correct Answer: It has a non-inferentially contradicted middle term.

The given is the kind of Badhita Fallacy.

 

Badhita is the non-inferentially contradicted middle. Here the middle term is contradicted by some other Pramana and not by inference. It cannot prove the major term which is disproved by another stronger source of valid knowledge; e.g., ‘fire is cold, because it is a substance'. Here the middle term ‘substance' becomes contradicted because its major term ‘coldness' is directly contradicted by perception.

Question 31
In computer Networking, MAC addresses are unique to each device. Which of the following is the meaning of the term MAC?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Medium Access Card
  • B.Media Address Command
  • C.Modem Addressing Card
  • D.Media Access Control
Correct Answer: Media Access Control

The correct answer is: (D) Media Access Control.

 

In computer networking, MAC stands for Media Access Control. It refers to the unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communications on the physical network segment. This address is used to uniquely identify devices on a local network.

Question 32
Which of the following “Digital India” themes is incorrectly matched with its purpose?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Spoken Tutorial – Learn various free and open-source software all by oneself
  • B.FOSSEE – Reduce dependency on proprietary software in Educational Institutions
  • C.e-Kalpa – Create Digital-learning environment for design
  • D.e-ShodhSindhi – Spread education in Embedded systems and Robotics
Correct Answer: e-ShodhSindhi – Spread education in Embedded systems and Robotics

The correct answer is: (D) e-ShodhSindhi – Spread education in Embedded systems and Robotics

 

The e-ShodhSindhi initiative aims to provide access to digital resources and scholarly content to researchers and students, especially for Indian language content, not specifically for embedded systems and robotics.

 

Spoken Tutorial: A platform for learning various free and open-source software independently.

 

FOSSEE: Promotes the use of free and open-source software in educational institutions, reducing dependence on proprietary software.

 

e-Kalpa: Aims to create a digital learning environment for design, including software tools for design and graphics.

Question 33
With reference to ICT, which of the following statements is true?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Global Positioning Systems (GPSs) in cars send signals to satellite which then work out where they are and send this data back to the car.
  • B.HTTP stands for HyperText Transfer policy.
  • C.RAM stands for Rapid Access Memory.
  • D.Geographic Information System (GIS) is a computer-based tool for mapping and analysing things that exist and events that happen on earth.
Correct Answer: Geographic Information System (GIS) is a computer-based tool for mapping and analysing things that exist and events that happen on earth.

The correct answer is: (D) Geographic Information System (GIS) is a computer-based tool for mapping and analysing things that exist and events that happen on earth.

 

Geographic Information System (GIS) is a computer-based tool that allows users to capture, store, manipulate, analyze, manage, and present spatial or geographic data. It is used to map, model, and analyze real-world phenomena that exist on the Earth's surface or events that happen over time.

Question 34
Based on the following, which of the following statements is true.A CD contains 12 music tracks which are of lengths (in minutes): 3, 7, 4, 3, 5, 6, 4, 5, 4, 7, 8, 8 and each minute of music requires 12 MB of storage.(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.512 MB of memory is used for the 12 music tracks.
  • B.1 GB of memory is used for the 12 music tracks.
  • C.768 MB of memory is used for the 12 music tracks.
  • D.If the tracks are to be stored in MP3 format, then each music track will be reduced in size by 90%. The storage that the 12 tracks would require is 69.12 MB.
Correct Answer: 768 MB of memory is used for the 12 music tracks.

Original storage requirement: The total storage required for the 12 music tracks in the original format is 768 MB.

 

MP3 format storage: If the tracks are stored in MP3 format, the storage is reduced by 90%. Therefore, the storage required for the 12 tracks in MP3 format is approximately 76.8 MB.

 

Correct Answer is option (C) - 768 MB of memory is used for the 12 music tracks.

Question 35
Match the List-I with List-II:List-I (Computer Components)A. ALUB. Control UnitC. Pen DriveD. Main MemoryList-II (Description)I. Immediate access storageII. Carries out arithmetical and logical calculationsIII. Directs the input and output flow in the CPUIV. Secondary/ offline storageChoose the options:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • C.A–I, B–III, C–IV, D–II
  • D.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
Correct Answer: A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I

The correct answer is option (A) - A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I.

 

Here’s the correct matching of computer components with their descriptions:

 

A. ALU (Arithmetic and Logic Unit) → II. Carries out arithmetical and logical calculations: The ALU is responsible for performing arithmetic and logical operations in the CPU.

 

B. Control Unit → III. Directs the input and output flow in the CPU: The Control Unit manages and coordinates all the operations in the computer, including directing the flow of data.

 

C. Pen Drive → IV. Secondary/ offline storage: A Pen Drive is a form of secondary storage used for storing data offline or for portability.

 

D. Main Memory → I. Immediate access storage: Main memory (RAM) is used for immediate access storage, holding data and instructions that are currently in use by the CPU.

Question 36
International Solar Alliance (ISA) is the alliance of countries, most of which lie:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Between North Pole and Tropic of Cancer
  • B.Between Tropic of Capricorn and South Pole
  • C.At equator
  • D.Between Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn
Correct Answer: Between Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn

The correct answer is: (D) Between Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn

 

The International Solar Alliance (ISA) is an alliance of countries that are mostly located between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn. This region, known as the tropics, receives abundant sunlight throughout the year, making it ideal for harnessing solar energy. The ISA aims to promote solar energy use and strengthen cooperation among solar-rich countries to combat climate change.

Question 37
Biomass:A. is a carbon cycle neutral fuelB. has significantly higher calorific value than coalC. can be converted into solid, liquid and gaseous fuelsD. can be converted into Producer GasE. cannot be obtained from energy cropsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.A, C and D Only
  • C.B, D and E Only
  • D.A, B and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

The correct answer is option (B) - A, C and D Only.

 

A. Biomass is a carbon cycle neutral fuel: True. Biomass is considered carbon neutral because the carbon dioxide released during its combustion is balanced by the carbon dioxide absorbed during the growth of the plants from which it is derived.

 

B. Biomass has significantly higher calorific value than coal: False. Biomass generally has a lower calorific value compared to coal.

 

C. Biomass can be converted into solid, liquid, and gaseous fuels: True. Biomass can be processed into different forms of energy, such as solid fuels (wood pellets), liquid fuels (biofuels like ethanol), and gaseous fuels (biogas).

 

D. Biomass can be converted into Producer Gas: True. Biomass can be converted into producer gas (a mixture of gases like carbon monoxide, hydrogen, and methane) through a process called gasification.

 

E. Biomass cannot be obtained from energy crops: False. Biomass can be obtained from energy crops such as switchgrass, miscanthus, and others specifically cultivated for energy production.

Question 38
Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs), replacement for chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), have to be phased out completely by the year:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.2025
  • B.2030
  • C.2035
  • D.2040
Correct Answer: 2030

The correct answer is: (B) 2030

 

Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) are ozone-depleting substances that were introduced as temporary replacements for chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). Under the Montreal Protocol, developed countries committed to phasing out HCFCs by 2020, while developing countries were given a timeline extending to 2030.

Question 39
Softening of hard water is done by:A. AerationB. BoilingC. Lime sodaD. OzonationE. Ion exchangeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and E Only
  • C.B, C and D Only
  • D.C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: B, C and E Only

The correct answer is: (B) B, C and E Only

 

A. Aeration: Not typically used for softening hard water. Aeration is a process used to remove dissolved gases or volatile substances, not to soften water.

 

B. Boiling: True. Boiling hard water can precipitate some of the calcium and magnesium salts, temporarily softening it.

 

C. Lime Soda: True. Lime soda process involves adding lime (calcium hydroxide) and soda (sodium carbonate) to remove hardness-causing ions (calcium and magnesium).

 

D. Ozonation: Not used for softening hard water. Ozonation is used primarily for disinfecting water and breaking down organic contaminants.

 

E. Ion exchange: True. Ion exchange is a common method for softening water, where calcium and magnesium ions are exchanged with sodium or potassium ions.

Question 40
Due to over fertilization of lakes, quality of fish produced:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.does not change
  • B.impairs
  • C.improves
  • D.first improves then impairs
Correct Answer: impairs

The correct answer is: (B) impairs

 

Over-fertilization of lakes, often caused by excess nutrients like nitrogen and phosphorus from agricultural runoff, leads to eutrophication. This process results in the excessive growth of algae, which depletes oxygen in the water, harming aquatic life, including fish. As a result, the quality of fish produced impairs, as fish populations decrease due to oxygen depletion, and toxic algal blooms may also harm fish health.

Question 41
The National Knowledge Commission suggested that the proposed national universities should not have:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Affiliated colleges
  • B.Public funding
  • C.Linkage with industries
  • D.Teaching departments
Correct Answer: Affiliated colleges

The correct answer is: (A) Affiliated colleges

 

The National Knowledge Commission (NKC), which was established in India in 2005, recommended reforms in the higher education sector. One of its key suggestions was that the proposed national universities should not have affiliated colleges. This is because affiliated colleges often have limited autonomy and flexibility, which could hinder the ability of national universities to provide high-quality education and research. The idea was to create more autonomous institutions with a strong focus on quality and innovation.

Question 42
Who among the following was the principal of Bengal National College, established in 1906?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Motilal Ghosh
  • B.Aurobindo Ghosh
  • C.Satish Chandra Mukharjee
  • D.Bipin Chandra Paul
Correct Answer: Aurobindo Ghosh

The correct answer is option (B) Aurobindo Ghosh.

 

Bengal National College was established in 1906 in Calcutta (now Kolkata), with the aim of promoting nationalist education. The principal of the college at that time was Aurobindo Ghosh, a prominent freedom fighter and intellectual.

Question 43
Most recommendations of the Calcutta University Commission were influenced by(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.The Hunter Commission
  • B.Wood’s Dispatch
  • C.The Haldane Commission
  • D.The Indian Universities Commission
Correct Answer: The Haldane Commission

The Calcutta University Commission (1917–1919), also known as the Sadler Commission, was influenced significantly by the Haldane Commission.

Question 44
Which of the following institutions were to play a role in shaping the National System of Education at higher level under the National Education Policy (1986)?A. UNESCOB. UNDPC. UGCD. AICTEE. ICARChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.A, C and D Only
  • D.C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: C, D and E Only

The correct answer is: (D) C, D and E Only

 

Under the National Education Policy (NEP) 1986, the focus was on developing a National System of Education with coordinated efforts by key Indian regulatory and academic bodies. The institutions playing a crucial role at the higher education level included:

 

UGC (University Grants Commission) – responsible for coordinating and maintaining standards of university education.

 

AICTE (All India Council for Technical Education) – responsible for technical and management education.

 

ICAR (Indian Council of Agricultural Research) – for education in agricultural sciences.

 

UNESCO and UNDP are international bodies and were not directly involved in implementing the national system of education at the institutional level in India.

Question 45
The education imparted at Nalanda University was both religious and(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Irreligious
  • B.Entertaining
  • C.Secular
  • D.Business-oriented
Correct Answer: Secular

The correct answer is: (C) Secular.

 

Nalanda University, one of the most renowned ancient centers of learning in India, offered education that was both religious and secular. While it was initially established as a Buddhist monastic university, it also taught a wide range of secular subjects such as logic, grammar, medicine, mathematics, astronomy, and philosophy. This broad curriculum attracted students from across Asia, reflecting its status as a premier educational institution.

Question 46
Read the passage and answer the following.Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups---and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘Is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in addition to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationships and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self—inside his or her own consciousness—lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.Ethical living is based onA. our own virtuous attributesB. our behaviour towards other speciesC. our behaviour towards environmentD. material satisfactionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.B and C Only
  • B.A and B Only
  • C.A, B and C Only
  • D.A, B, C and D
Correct Answer: A, B and C Only

The passage emphasizes that ethical living is concerned with:

 

A. Our own virtuous attributes – Yes. It explicitly mentions “virtuous character traits such as integrity, honesty, faithfulness, and compassion” as central to ethical living.

 

B. Our behaviour towards other species – Yes. The passage states that ethical living considers “how we treat other species”.

 

C. Our behaviour towards the environment – Yes. The environment is specifically mentioned as part of the ethical concern: “increasingly, other species and the environment.”

 

D. Material satisfaction – No. The passage does not mention material satisfaction as a component of ethical living.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 47
Read the passage and answer the following.Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups---and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘Is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in addition to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationships and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self—inside his or her own consciousness—lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.Identify the virtuous character traits which help an individual to flourish in life.A. IntegrityB. PsychophancyC. HonestyD. CompassionE. FaithfulnessChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B, C and D Only
  • B.A, C and D Only
  • C.A, B, C, D and E
  • D.A, C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C, D and E Only

. The passage clearly lists the virtuous character traits that help individuals flourish:

 

“…such as integrity, honesty, faithfulness and compassion…”

 

Thus, option (D) is correct.

Question 48
Read the passage and answer the following.Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups---and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘Is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in addition to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationships and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self—inside his or her own consciousness—lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.Which of the following statement is incorrect?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Culture is static
  • B.All cultures have developed their ethical norms and principles over time
  • C.Rational people of goodwill exist in all cultures
  • D.Culture is dynamic
Correct Answer: Culture is static

The passage implies that ethical norms and principles evolve:

 

"Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures..."

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 49
Read the passage and answer the following.Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups---and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘Is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in addition to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationships and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self—inside his or her own consciousness—lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.For a good leader it is imperative to have(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.resources
  • B.daily reflections on his conduct
  • C.higher educational background
  • D.belief in spirituality
Correct Answer: daily reflections on his conduct

The passage emphasizes the importance of self-awareness and ethical reflection for anyone who wants to take moral leadership:

 

“A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self—inside his or her own consciousness...”

 

Thus, option (B) is correct.

Question 50
Read the passage and answer the following.Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups---and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘Is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in addition to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationships and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self—inside his or her own consciousness—lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.Quality of our interactions in human relationships is gauged by(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.economic status
  • B.social status
  • C.interpersonal behaviour
  • D.educational background
Correct Answer: interpersonal behaviour

The passage clearly emphasizes that ethical living is about:

 

"...the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour..."

"...morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact."

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Quiz Attempt #119707

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the percentage (%) increase in income and expenditure of various types of Banks, namely PSU Banks, Old Private Banks, New Private Banks and Foreign Banks over the previous year during the year 2021-2022 and 2022-2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:(Note: In the above table, the meaning of any figure x% is as follows:(I) x% in 2021-2022 means income or expenditure in 2021-2022 is x% more than that in 2020-2021.(II) x% in 2022-2023 means income as expenditure in 2022-2023 is x% more than that is 2021-2022.Consider the income of PSU Banks in 2020-2021 as ₹ 10,00,000 crore. If the expenditure of PSU Banks in 2022-2023 is equal to the income of PSU Banks in 2020-2021, then the income of PSU Banks in 2022-23 will be approximately __________ % more than the expenditure of PSU Banks in 2021-2022.(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.62
  • B.44
  • C.56
  • D.64
Correct Answer: 64

Income in 2021–22 = ₹10,00,000 (1.15) = ₹ 11,50,000 crore

Income in 2022–23 = ₹11,50,000 (1.17) = ₹ 13,45,500 crore

 

Since 2022–23 expenditure is 22% more than 2021–22, Expenditure in 2021-22 = 1000001.22 = ₹ 8,19,672.13 crore

 

Required percentage = 1345500-819672.13819672.13 × 100 ≈ 64%

Question 2
The following table shows the percentage (%) increase in income and expenditure of various types of Banks, namely PSU Banks, Old Private Banks, New Private Banks and Foreign Banks over the previous year during the year 2021-2022 and 2022-2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:(Note: In the above table, the meaning of any figure x% is as follows:(I) x% in 2021-2022 means income or expenditure in 2021-2022 is x% more than that in 2020-2021.(II) x% in 2022-2023 means income as expenditure in 2022-2023 is x% more than that is 2021-2022.If the expenditure of foreign Banks in 2020-2021 is equal to their income in that year and is equal to ₹ 60,000 crore, then in 2022-2023, what is the difference in income and expenditure of Foreign Banks?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.₹ 3984 crore
  • B.₹ 4000 crore
  • C.₹ 5462 crore
  • D.₹ 3460 crore
Correct Answer: ₹ 3984 crore

Income in 2021–22 = ₹60,000 × 1.09 = ₹65,400 crore

Income in 2022–23 = ₹65,400 × 1.12 = ₹73,248 crore

 

Expenditure in 2021–22 = ₹60,000 × 1.04 = ₹62,400 crore

Expenditure in 2022–23 = ₹62,400 × 1.11 = ₹69,264 crore

 

Required difference (Income − Expenditure) = ₹73,248− ₹69,264 = ₹3,984 crore

Question 3
The following table shows the percentage (%) increase in income and expenditure of various types of Banks, namely PSU Banks, Old Private Banks, New Private Banks and Foreign Banks over the previous year during the year 2021-2022 and 2022-2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:(Note: In the above table, the meaning of any figure x% is as follows:(I) x% in 2021-2022 means income or expenditure in 2021-2022 is x% more than that in 2020-2021.(II) x% in 2022-2023 means income as expenditure in 2022-2023 is x% more than that is 2021-2022.Consider the income of new Private Banks in 2021-2022 as ₹ 8000 Crore. If the expenditure of new Private Banks in 2021-2022 is same as their income, then the difference in income of new Private Banks in 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 will be approximately __________ % of the difference in expenditure of new private banks in 2021-2022 and 2022-2023.(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.52
  • B.76
  • C.84
  • D.118
Correct Answer: 84

Income in 2022–23 = ₹8000 × 1.37 = ₹10,960 crore

Difference in income = 10960 - 8000 = ₹2,960 crore

 

Expenditure in 2022–23= ₹ 8000 × 1.44= ₹11,520 crore

Difference in expenditure = ₹11,520−₹8000 = ₹3520 crore

 

Required percentage = 29603520 × 100 ≈ 84%

Question 4
The following table shows the percentage (%) increase in income and expenditure of various types of Banks, namely PSU Banks, Old Private Banks, New Private Banks and Foreign Banks over the previous year during the year 2021-2022 and 2022-2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:(Note: In the above table, the meaning of any figure x% is as follows:(I) x% in 2021-2022 means income or expenditure in 2021-2022 is x% more than that in 2020-2021.(II) x% in 2022-2023 means income as expenditure in 2022-2023 is x% more than that is 2021-2022.In 2021-2022, if the income of PSU Banks is twice the expenditure of Foreign Banks, then in 2022-2023, what will be the ratio of income of PSU Banks to the expenditure of Foreign Banks?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.1 : 2
  • B.78 : 37
  • C.75 : 29
  • D.2 : 1
Correct Answer: 78 : 37

PSU Income in 2022–23 = 2x × 1.17 = 2.34x

Foreign Expenditure in 2022–23 = x × 1.11 = 1.11x

Required ratio = 2.34x1.11x = 78 : 37

Question 5
The following table shows the percentage (%) increase in income and expenditure of various types of Banks, namely PSU Banks, Old Private Banks, New Private Banks and Foreign Banks over the previous year during the year 2021-2022 and 2022-2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:(Note: In the above table, the meaning of any figure x% is as follows:(I) x% in 2021-2022 means income or expenditure in 2021-2022 is x% more than that in 2020-2021.(II) x% in 2022-2023 means income as expenditure in 2022-2023 is x% more than that is 2021-2022.In 2021-2022, if the income of Foreign Banks is four times its expenditure, then what will be the approximate ratio of income to the expenditure of foreign Banks in 2022-2023?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.1 : 4
  • B.4 : 1
  • C.5 : 1
  • D.1 : 5
Correct Answer: 4 : 1

Let expenditure in 2021–22 = ₹x

Then income in 2021–22 = ₹4x

Income in 2022-23 = 4x × 1.12 = 4.48x

Expenditure in 2022-23 = x × 1.11 = 1.11x

Required ratio = 4.48x1.11x ≈ 4 : 1

Question 6
Which of the following are the characteristics of mental development of Adolescents?(A) Increased ability to deal with abstraction(B) Reviewing of hopes and aspirations(C) Increased ability to understand(D) Increased ability to generalize the facts(E) Ability of problem solvingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.B, D and E only
  • B.A, B and D only
  • C.A, C, D and E only
  • D.C and E only
Correct Answer: A, C, D and E only

Adolescence is marked by significant cognitive and mental development, influenced by brain maturation and educational experiences. Let’s examine each statement:

 

A. Increased ability to deal with abstraction – Correct. Adolescents develop abstract thinking, allowing them to handle concepts like justice, freedom, or algebra.

 

B. Reviewing of hopes and aspirations – Not purely cognitive/mental. This relates more to emotional and social development rather than mental/cognitive development.

 

C. Increased ability to understand – Correct. Cognitive growth leads to better comprehension of complex ideas and multiple perspectives.

 

D. Increased ability to generalize the facts – Correct. Adolescents can draw broader conclusions from specific information, showing higher-order thinking.

 

E. Ability of problem solving – Correct. Enhanced logic and reasoning improve problem-solving skills significantly during adolescence.

 

Thus, option (C) is the correct answer.

Question 7
Knowing the importance of metacognition, Richa decided she would try to focus her young students' attention on their own thinking skills. Richa knew by having her students "think" about their thinking they would eventually increase their metacognitive skills. Which one of the strategy should Richa employ?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Overlearning
  • B.A KWL Chart
  • C.Rote learning
  • D.An algorithm
Correct Answer: A KWL Chart

K-W-L chart is a three-column graphic organizer that provides space for participants to record what they Know (K), what they Want to know (W), and what they have Learned (L). K-W-L charts are an easy way to activate participants' prior knowledge and get them to set an intention for their learning.

 

This process helps develop metacognition, i.e., awareness and control over one’s own learning and thinking process.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 8
A sociology professor wants to gather student's opinions on controversial social issue discussed in class which tools allow the professor to create polls and analyze responses in real-time?(A) Poll everywhere(B) Camtasia(C) Strawpoll(D) Survey Monkey(E) MentimeterChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and D only
  • B.A, C, D and E only
  • C.B and E only
  • D.B, C and D only
Correct Answer: A, C, D and E only

To gather student opinions in real-time, the professor needs tools that allow live polling, data collection, and quick analysis. Let’s evaluate each:

 

A. Poll Everywhere – Yes, it allows live polls during presentations, perfect for classrooms.

 

B. Camtasia – No, this is a screen recording and video editing software, not a polling tool.

 

C. Strawpoll – Yes, a simple online poll creator for quick opinion gathering.

 

D. SurveyMonkey – Yes, allows creating detailed surveys and analyzing responses, though not always real-time like others.

 

E. Mentimeter – Yes, a popular interactive tool for real-time polls, quizzes, and Q&A sessions.

 

Therefore, option (B) is correct.

Question 9
Priya knows she did something embarrassing at her best friend's birthday party many years ago, but she cannot remember what it was. This is an example of:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Repression
  • B.Amnesia
  • C.Implicit memory
  • D.Interferences
Correct Answer: Repression

Repression is a defense mechanism where the mind unconsciously blocks distressing or embarrassing memories from conscious awareness.

 

In Priya’s case, she knows something happened but cannot recall the memory — a classic sign of repression.

 

Other options:

 

(B) Amnesia – refers to a general loss of memory, often due to brain injury or trauma, not typically specific to an embarrassing event.

 

(C) Implicit memory – involves unconscious memory, like skills or routines, not forgotten events.

 

(D) Interference – happens when new or old memories block access to others, not due to emotional suppression.

Question 10
A science teacher assigns students a project where they design and conduct an experiment to investigate the effects of environmental factors on plant growth in real time. This assessment is an example of?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Summative Assessment
  • B.Authentic Assessment
  • C.Ipsative Assessment
  • D.Peer Assessment
Correct Answer: Authentic Assessment

Authentic Assessment involves tasks that reflect real-world challenges and require students to apply their knowledge and skills in a practical context.

 

In this case, designing and conducting a real experiment to study environmental effects on plant growth is a hands-on, real-life application of scientific learning — a hallmark of authentic assessment.

 

Other options:

(A) Summative Assessment – typically evaluates learning after instruction (e.g., final exam), not ongoing, hands-on projects.

 

(C) Ipsative Assessment – compares a student's current performance with their past performance, not relevant here.

 

(D) Peer Assessment – involves students assessing each other’s work, which is not the focus of this question.

 

Thus, option (B) is correct.

Question 11
Identify the main preoccupations of quantitative researchers:(A) Measurement(B) Causality(C) Emphasis on context(D) GeneralizationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A and B only
  • B.A, B and C only
  • C.A, B and D only
  • D.B. C and D only
Correct Answer: A, B and D only

Quantitative researchers are primarily concerned with measurement (A), causality (B), and generalization (D). They focus on obtaining precise, numerical data that can be analyzed statistically to draw conclusions that can be generalized to larger populations. While they may consider context, it is not as central to their research as it is in qualitative research. Therefore, the correct answer is C (A, B, and D only).

Question 12
Your measurements should show which of the following validities if you want to generalize the results of your research to a different population?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Construct validity
  • B.Internal validity
  • C.External validity
  • D.Convergent validity
Correct Answer: External validity

To generalize the results of your research to a different population, you need external validity. External validity refers to the extent to which the results of a study can be applied to or generalized beyond the specific conditions, participants, or settings of the study. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

Question 13
Match List I with List II:List I (Abbreviations)A. id.,B. post:C. vidD. viz.List II (Meaning)I. refer toII. the sameIII. namelyIV. afterChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-I B-II C-III D-IV
  • B.A-II B-IV C-I D-III
  • C.A-II B-I C-III D-IV
  • D.A-III B-II C-IV D-I
Correct Answer: A-II B-IV C-I D-III

Here’s the correct match between the abbreviations and their meanings:

A. id. means the same (II)

B. post: means after (IV)

C. vid means refer to (I)

D. viz. means namely (III)

So, the correct answer is B (A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III).

Question 14
A sampling technique that relies on getting information from people who know about a population of interest rather than from members of that population themselves, refers to?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Probability sampling
  • B.Key informant sampling
  • C.Snowball sampling
  • D.Quota sampling
Correct Answer: Key informant sampling

The sampling technique where information is obtained from individuals who have knowledge about a population, rather than from the members of the population directly, is called key informant sampling. This method relies on experts or knowledgeable individuals to provide insights about the population of interest. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

Question 15
Identify the measures of dispersion:A. Mean deviationB. MedianC. Standard deviationD. RangeE. QuartileChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.A and E only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.C, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, C and D only

Measures of dispersion are used to describe the spread or variability of a set of data. These include:

Mean deviation (A) - a measure of the average distance between each data point and the mean.

Standard deviation (C) - a widely used measure of how spread out the data points are from the mean.

Range (D) - the difference between the maximum and minimum values in the data set.

Median (B) and Quartile (E) are measures of central tendency, not dispersion.

Therefore, the correct answer is C (A, C, and D only).

Question 16
When we describe how a media system should function in conformity with ideal values, it is labelled as?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Social theory
  • B.Normative theory
  • C.Comparative theory
  • D.Analytical theory
Correct Answer: Normative theory

Normative theory deals with how things ought to be, based on ideal values, ethics, and societal expectations.

When we describe how a media system should function (e.g., free press, responsibility to public, fairness), we are using normative theory.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 17
Sequential accounts, told from a particular viewpoint are called:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Situational actions
  • B.Social themes
  • C.Narratives
  • D.Dignified discourse
Correct Answer: Narratives

Narratives are sequential accounts or stories that are told from a particular perspective or viewpoint. They organize events in a logical order and often include a beginning, middle, and end.

 

Narratives help convey experiences, emotions, or messages through storytelling.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 18
Many modern scholars consider the following as positive aspects of communication, which of them are true?A. Communication helps create knowledgeB. It defines the human goalsC. It supports efforts to change social normsD. It makes simple tasks complexE. It promotes propaganda techniques all the timeAnswer options:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, C and E only
  • D.A, C and E only
Correct Answer: A, B and C only

Let’s evaluate each statement:

 

A. Communication helps create knowledge – True. Through interaction, discussion, and information exchange, communication plays a key role in knowledge creation.

 

B. It defines the human goals – True. Communication helps individuals and societies articulate, share, and refine their goals.

 

C. It supports efforts to change social norms – True. Mass communication, campaigns, and education can influence attitudes and transform societal norms (e.g., public health, gender equality).

 

D. It makes simple tasks complex – False. Effective communication is supposed to simplify understanding, not complicate it.

 

E. It promotes propaganda techniques all the time – False. While communication can be misused for propaganda, it does not inherently promote propaganda, nor is that its primary or constant purpose.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 19
Which of the following are part of narration?A. A sequence of a beginning, middle and endB. Causal development between sequences and the conclusionC. Memorable phrases indicating what happenedD. Absence of spatial contextE. Exclusion of temporal factorAnswer options:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.D and E only
  • D.A, C and E only
Correct Answer: A, B and C only

Let’s examine each statement:

 

A. A sequence of a beginning, middle and end – True. This is a core structure of any narrative—a linear progression from introduction to conclusion.

 

B. Causal development between sequences and the conclusion – True. Good narration often involves cause-and-effect relationships leading logically from one part to the next and finally to a conclusion.

 

C. Memorable phrases indicating what happened – True. Narratives often include descriptive or memorable language to help convey events clearly and keep them engaging.

 

D. Absence of spatial context – False. Narratives often include spatial context, describing where events occurred to create a vivid mental picture.

 

E. Exclusion of temporal factor – False. Time (temporal context) is crucial to narration—events unfold over time and are often organized chronologically.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 20
List the following developments in a chronological sequence:A. Invention of television remote controlsB. Publication of diurnalsC. Invention of cameraD. Arrival of mass market paperbacksE. Origin of hieroglyphic writing systemAnswer options:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, C, E, D, B
  • B.B, C, D, E, A
  • C.C, E, D, A, B
  • D.E, B, C, D, A
Correct Answer: E, B, C, D, A

Let’s place each event in historical order:

 

E. Origin of hieroglyphic writing system –

Ancient Egypt, around 3200 BCE

 

B. Publication of diurnals –

Early printed news periodicals from 16th–17th century Europe (early 1600s)

 

C. Invention of camera –

First camera invented in 1816 by Joseph Nicéphore Niépce.

 

D. Arrival of mass market paperbacks –

Popularized in the 1930s–40s, especially by Penguin Books in the UK

 

A. Invention of television remote controls –

Introduced in the 1950s, the first was called "Lazy Bones" by Zenith (1950)

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 21
40 people consume 320 kg of rice in 50 days. In how many days will 30 people consume 80 kg of rice?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.1813days
  • B.1623days
  • C.1723days
  • D.1613days
Correct Answer: 1623days

M1×D1W1 = M2×D2W2

or 40×50320 = 30×x80

or x = 16 23 days

Question 22
If the selling price of Rs. 623 results in a discount of 11% on the market price of an item, at what price should the item be sold to offer a discount of 19%?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Rs. 557
  • B.Rs. 567
  • C.Rs. 577
  • D.Rs. 587
Correct Answer: Rs. 567

MP = 6230.89 = 700

New SP = 700 × 0.81 = 567

Question 23
Find the next number in the number series: 48, 24, 72, 36, 108, ?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.115
  • B.121
  • C.110
  • D.54
Correct Answer: 54

Next number = 1082 = 54

Question 24
In a certain coding language, the word 'GREAT' is coded as 'ETCCR', then the word 'FROWN' will be coded as:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.DTMYL
  • B.ETNWL
  • C.HTQYP
  • D.DSOXL
Correct Answer: DTMYL

F – 2 = D

R + 2 = T

O – 2 = M

W + 2 = Y

N – 2 = L

Thus, code will be DTMYL

Question 25
Travelling in a train, a man notices 13 telephone poles in two minutes. If the two successive telephone poles are known to be 125 meters apart, then the train is travelling at a speed of:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.40 km/hr
  • B.42 km/hr
  • C.45 km/hr
  • D.48 km/hr
Correct Answer: 45 km/hr

Distance travelled in 2 mins = 125 × 12 = 1500 m = 1.5 km

Distance travelled in 1 hr = 1.5 × 30 = 45 km/hr

Question 26
"Of course, abortion has to be legal. After all, a woman must have freedom to do whatever she wants with her own body." Identify the fallacy committed in this statement:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Fallacy of composition
  • B.Complex question
  • C.Begging the question
  • D.Hasty generalization
Correct Answer: Begging the question

The fallacy committed in this statement is (C) Begging the question. This fallacy occurs when the argument's conclusion is assumed in one of the premises. In this case, the statement assumes that a woman must have the freedom to do whatever she wants with her own body, which essentially assumes the very point that needs to be proven (that abortion should be legal). This circular reasoning does not provide independent support for the claim that abortion should be legal.

Fallacy of composition (A) occurs when one assumes that what is true for parts must be true for the whole.

Complex question (B) involves asking a question that assumes a particular answer to an unasked question.

Hasty generalization (D) is making a broad or sweeping statement based on limited or insufficient evidence.

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Begging the question.

Question 27
Which of the following propositions is contradictory to the proposition "All cats are Carnivores"?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Some Cats are not Carnivores
  • B.Some Cats are Carnivores
  • C.No Cats are Carnivores
  • D.No Carnivores are Cats
Correct Answer: Some Cats are not Carnivores

In the Classical Square of Opposition, we examine the relationships between different types of propositions. The square involves A (Universal Affirmative), E (Universal Negative), I (Particular Affirmative), and O (Particular Negative) forms.

The proposition "All cats are carnivores" is an A-type proposition (Universal Affirmative), which means every cat is a carnivore.

The contradictory of an A-type proposition (All S are P) is an O-type proposition (Some S are not P). This means the contradictory of "All cats are carnivores" would be "Some cats are not carnivores".

Question 28
Which of the following statements are logically equivalent?A. No Carnivores are Cats.B. Some Carnivores are not Cats.C. All Cats are CarnivoresD. All non-carnivores are non-catsAnswer options:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.C and D only
  • B.A and D only
  • C.A and B only
  • D.B and D only
Correct Answer: C and D only

All non-carnivores are non-cats is CONTRAPOSITION of All Cats are Carnivores.

Question 29
Which of the following statements is true?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.In a valid argument all of its premises have to be true
  • B.Validity can be attributed to any single proposition by itself
  • C.Truth and falsehood are attributes of single propositions
  • D.Truth and falsehood can be attributed to arguments
Correct Answer: Truth and falsehood are attributes of single propositions

Truth and falsehood apply to single propositions, not to entire arguments. A proposition is a statement that can either be true or false. On the other hand, an argument consists of multiple propositions, where the focus is on whether the reasoning is valid or invalid. An argument is valid if its conclusion logically follows from the premises, regardless of the truth of the premises. If the premises are true and the argument is valid, the argument is said to be sound. Thus, arguments themselves cannot be true or false, only valid or invalid.

Question 30
According to Nyāya (Classical school of logic), which of the following step of inference corresponds to Upanaya?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.The hill has fire
  • B.Because it has smoke
  • C.Whatever has smoke has fire, e.g., an oven
  • D.The hill has smoke which is invariably associated with fire
Correct Answer: The hill has smoke which is invariably associated with fire

There are 5 propositions in the Nyaya syllogism as given below.

 

1. The first is called Pratijna or proposition. It is the logical statement which is to be proved.

2. The second is Hetu or reason which states the reason for the establishment of the proposition.

3. The third is called Udaharana which gives the universal concomitance together with an example.

4. The fourth is Upanaya or the application of the universal concomitance to the present case.

5. The fifth is Nigamana or conclusion drawn from the preceding propositions. These five propositions are called ‘members or avayavas’.

 

The following is a typical Nyaya syllogism:

  • This hill has fire (pratijna).
  • Because it has smoke (hetu).
  • Whatever has smoke has fire, e.g., an oven (udaharana).
  • This hill has smoke which is invariably associated with fire (upanaya).

 

Therefore, this hill has fire (nigamana).

Question 31
Which of the following electronic technologies is the key technology for making the Personal Computer (PC) in the 1970s?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Transistor based
  • B.Integrated components (ICs) based
  • C.Microprocessor based
  • D.Vacuum tube based
Correct Answer: Microprocessor based

The correct answer is: (C) Microprocessor based.

 

The microprocessor was the key breakthrough technology that enabled the development of personal computers (PCs) in the 1970s. Intel introduced the first commercially available microprocessor, the Intel 4004, in 1971. This allowed all the functions of a computer's central processing unit (CPU) to be placed on a single chip, making computers smaller, cheaper, and more accessible—paving the way for the personal computing revolution.

Question 32
Computer security breaches can be minimized by incorporating which feature into a computer system’s operation?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Installation of software of user's choice
  • B.The ability to log into multiple nodes, using only one account
  • C.Forced log off from the system if no activity has been detected
  • D.Allowing the uploading and downloading of files to the system
Correct Answer: Forced log off from the system if no activity has been detected

The correct answer is: (C) Forced log off from the system if no activity has been detected.

 

Auto log-off after a period of inactivity is a common and effective security feature. It helps prevent unauthorized access if a user leaves their computer unattended. The other options either increase risk (like installing arbitrary software or unrestricted file transfers) or are less secure (like single sign-on without safeguards).

Question 33
Identify the sequence of words A-E that correctly fills the blanks in the following paragraph:__________ is used to connect the smartwatch and wireless headphone to the phone and is a __________ range wireless technology. __________ is used to connect the phone and the laptop to the outside world called the "Internet" and it uses radio waves to allow high-speed data transfer over short distances. __________ is used to connect the phone to countless services via the "Internet" and is a __________ range wireless technology.A. ShortB. LongC. WifiD. 3G/4G/5GE. BluetoothAnswer options:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.E, A, C, D, B
  • B.E, A, C, D, E
  • C.A, C, E, B, D
  • D.E, C, A, B, D
Correct Answer: E, A, C, D, B

The correct answer is: (A) E, A, C, D, B

 

Let’s fill in the paragraph with this sequence:

 

Bluetooth is used to connect the smartwatch and wireless headphone to the phone and is a short range wireless technology. WiFi is used to connect the phone and the laptop to the outside world called the "Internet" and it uses radio waves to allow high-speed data transfer over short distances. 3G/4G/5G is used to connect the phone to countless services via the "Internet" and is a long range wireless technology.

 

This sequence fits all the technical descriptions correctly.

Question 34
With reference to computer components, which of the following statements are correct?A. A hard drive has no moving parts.B. Fan is required to cool down CPUs so that these do not overheat.C. Accessing information in a hard drive is faster than accessing information stored in RAM.D. When power is switched off, any information stored in a hard drive is lost.E. For a given amount of memory, RAM is more expensive than a hard drive.Answer options:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and E only
  • B.C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.B and E only
Correct Answer: B and E only

The correct answer is: (D) B and E only

 

A. A hard drive has no moving parts – Incorrect, traditional HDDs (Hard Disk Drives) do have moving parts (spinning disks). Only SSDs (Solid State Drives) have no moving parts.

 

B. Fan is required to cool down CPUs so that these do not overheat – Correct, CPU cooling is essential to prevent damage or shutdown due to overheating.

 

C. Accessing information in a hard drive is faster than accessing information stored in RAM – Incorrect, RAM is much faster than any kind of hard drive.

 

D. When power is switched off, any information stored in a hard drive is lost – Incorrect, hard drives are non-volatile, meaning they retain data without power.

 

E. For a given amount of memory, RAM is more expensive than a hard drive – Correct, RAM is faster and costlier per GB compared to hard drives.

 

Thus, only B and E are correct.

Question 35
Match List I with List II.List I (Computer Components)A. RAMB. ROMC. CMOSD. CPUList II (Meaning)I. Brain of the computerII. Stores the date, time, and system configuration for BIOSIII. Memory that can be written to and read fromIV. Stores ‘boot up’ programAnswer options:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-III, B-II, C-IV, D-I
  • B.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • C.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I

The correct answer is: (B) A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I

 

List I (Computer Components) → List II (Meaning):

 

A. RAM → III. Memory that can be written to and read from (Volatile memory used for temporary data storage)

 

B. ROM → IV. Stores ‘boot up’ program (Non-volatile memory storing BIOS/firmware)

 

C. CMOS → II. Stores the date, time, and system configuration for BIOS (Powered by a small battery)

 

D. CPU → I. Brain of the computer (Performs all processing tasks)

 

Thus, the correct matching is A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I.

Question 36
Dysentery is a waterborne disease caused by water contaminated by:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Virus
  • B.Protozoan
  • C.Fungi
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Protozoan

The correct answer is: (B) Protozoan

 

Dysentery is commonly caused by protozoan parasites, especially Entamoeba histolytica, which is transmitted through water contaminated with feces.

Question 37
Which one of the following agreements/protocols mainly focuses on the curbing of global temperature rise?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Montreal Protocol
  • B.Kigali Agreement
  • C.Kyoto Protocol
  • D.Paris Agreement
Correct Answer: Paris Agreement

The correct answer is: (D) Paris Agreement

 

The Paris Agreement (2015) is an international treaty under the UNFCCC that specifically aims to limit global temperature rise to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels, and preferably to 1.5°C.

 

Montreal Protocol focuses on phasing out ozone-depleting substances.

 

Kigali Agreement is an amendment to the Montreal Protocol, targeting HFCs.

 

Kyoto Protocol aimed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but had less emphasis on temperature targets than the Paris Agreement.

Question 38
A tsunami is a:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Transverse wave
  • B.Longitudinal waves
  • C.Both transverse and longitudinal waves
  • D.Neither transverse nor longitudinal wave
Correct Answer: Both transverse and longitudinal waves

The correct answer is option (C) - Both transverse and longitudinal waves.
