A tsunami involves both transverse and longitudinal wave motions:

 

In deep water, the water particles move in circular or elliptical paths, combining both types of motion.

 

As the wave approaches the shore and interacts with the seabed, longitudinal motion dominates, causing the massive forward surge of water.

 

Thus, a tsunami exhibits characteristics of both wave types.

Question 39
Which one of the following is a chemical parameter to measure the water quality?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Turbidity
  • B.Temperature
  • C.Hardness
  • D.Colour
Correct Answer: Hardness

The correct answer is: (C) Hardness

 

Hardness is a chemical parameter used to measure water quality. It refers to the concentration of dissolved minerals, primarily calcium and magnesium, in the water. These minerals contribute to the "hardness" of water and can affect both water usage and ecosystem health.

 

Turbidity and colour are physical parameters, as they relate to the appearance of water.

 

Temperature is a physical parameter related to heat but not a chemical one.

Question 40
Which one of the following is NOT an air pollutant?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.NO
  • B.NO₂
  • C.NOₓ
  • D.N₂O
Correct Answer: N₂O

The correct answer is: (D) N₂O

 

NO (Nitric oxide), NO₂ (Nitrogen dioxide), and NOₓ (Nitrogen oxides) are all considered air pollutants. They contribute to air pollution and are involved in the formation of smog and acid rain.

 

N₂O (Nitrous oxide) is a greenhouse gas and while it does contribute to climate change, it is not typically classified as a direct air pollutant in the same way as NO, NO₂, or NOₓ.

Question 41
Which was the first commission to touch upon the issues of higher education in India indirectly?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.The Indian Education Commission (1882-83)
  • B.The Indian Universities Commission (1902)
  • C.The Calcutta University Commission (1917-1919)
  • D.The Hartog Committee (1929)
Correct Answer: The Indian Education Commission (1882-83)

The correct answer is: (A) The Indian Education Commission (1882-83)

 

The Indian Education Commission (1882-83), also known as the Hunter Commission, was the first to address issues related to higher education in India, albeit indirectly. It focused primarily on primary and secondary education but also highlighted the need for reforms in the higher education sector to improve its accessibility and relevance.

Question 42
The N.N. Kunzru Committee was formed to look into the issue of ______ at the university level.(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Administrative reforms
  • B.Selection of vice-chancellors
  • C.Sports education
  • D.Medium of instruction
Correct Answer: Medium of instruction

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The Kunzru Committee (1959) was commissioned by the University Grants Commission to study and prepare a report on the matter of English as a medium of instruction and also the teaching of English. The Kunzru Committee made a study and brought out a report recommending the retention of English language which should be a properly studied second language in universities though Indian language may be used as the medium of instruction.

Question 43
Which of the following institutions can be declared as a "Deemed to be University" under Section (3) of the UGC Act, 1956?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Any institution as declared by UGC
  • B.Any institution as declared by Central Government, on the advice of UGC
  • C.Any institution that has been operational for more than 5 years
  • D.Any institution providing only technical education
Correct Answer: Any institution as declared by Central Government, on the advice of UGC

Section (3) of UGC Act 1956 provides for declaration of Deemed to be Universities to promote, strengthen and bring those institutions, which are doing work of high standards in specialised academic field comparable to university, under the purview of UGC. Accordingly, the Central Government on the advice of the Commission declare any institution as Deemed to be University.

Question 44
Which of the following ancient universities was visited by the Chinese traveller Hiuen Tsang?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Indraprastha
  • B.Takshashila
  • C.Nalanda
  • D.Odantapuri
Correct Answer: Nalanda

The correct answer is option (C) - Nalanda.

 

The Chinese traveler Hiuen Tsang (Xuanzang) visited the Nalanda University in the 7th century. Nalanda was one of the most renowned centers of learning in ancient India, particularly famous for Buddhist studies and scholarly activities.

Question 45
Match List - I with List - II.List I (Authors)A. Brahma GuptaB. VarahamihiraC. BhaskaracharyaD. BharatmuniList II (Books)I. LilavatiII. Brahma Sphota SiddhantaIII. NatyashastraIV. Brihat SamhitaChoose the correct answer from the options:(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • B.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • C.A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III
  • D.A-II, B-IV, C-III, D-I
Correct Answer: A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III

The correct answer is: (B) A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III

 

Here’s the correct matching of the authors and their works:

 

A. Brahma Gupta → II. Brahma Sphota Siddhanta: Brahma Gupta is famous for his work Brahma Sphota Siddhanta, a treatise on mathematics and astronomy.

 

B. Varahamihira → IV. Brihat Samhita: Varahamihira authored the Brihat Samhita, an important work on astronomy, astrology, and natural sciences.

 

C. Bhaskaracharya → I. Lilavati: Bhaskaracharya (also known as Bhaskara II) wrote the Lilavati, a famous work on mathematics.

 

D. Bharatmuni → III. Natyashastra: Bharatmuni is the author of Natyashastra, a classical text on performing arts, specifically drama and theatre.

Question 46
Read the following passage and answer the questions.Floods are normal events that cause damage. As rivers carve and shape the landscape, they build broad floodplains, level expanses that are periodically inundated. A “10-year flood” would be expected to occur once in every ten years; a “100-year flood” would be expected to occur once every century. The biggest economic loss from floods is usually not the buildings and property they carry away but rather, the contamination they cause. Many human activities like paving roads and parking lots reduce water infiltration into the soil and speed the rate of runoff into streams and lakes. Even more than development, though, flood-control structures have separated floodplains from rivers. Levees and flood walls are built to contain water within river banks, and river channels are dredged and deepened to allow water to recede faster. Every flood-control structure simply transfers the problem down-stream. However, the water has to go somewhere. If it doesn’t soak into the ground upstream, it will simply exacerbate floods somewhere downstream - leading to more levee development, and then to more flooding farther downstream, and so on.‘100 year flood’ :(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Will happen every 10 years.
  • B.Will never happen twice in the same year.
  • C.May happen more frequently than a “10-year flood”.
  • D.May happen once every century
Correct Answer: May happen once every century

The passage explains:

 

"A ‘10-year flood’ would be expected to occur once in every ten years; a ‘100-year flood’ would be expected to occur once every century."

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 47
Read the following passage and answer the questions.Floods are normal events that cause damage. As rivers carve and shape the landscape, they build broad floodplains, level expanses that are periodically inundated. A “10-year flood” would be expected to occur once in every ten years; a “100-year flood” would be expected to occur once every century. The biggest economic loss from floods is usually not the buildings and property they carry away but rather, the contamination they cause. Many human activities like paving roads and parking lots reduce water infiltration into the soil and speed the rate of runoff into streams and lakes. Even more than development, though, flood-control structures have separated floodplains from rivers. Levees and flood walls are built to contain water within river banks, and river channels are dredged and deepened to allow water to recede faster. Every flood-control structure simply transfers the problem down-stream. However, the water has to go somewhere. If it doesn’t soak into the ground upstream, it will simply exacerbate floods somewhere downstream - leading to more levee development, and then to more flooding farther downstream, and so on.What is the biggest economic loss from floods typically due to ?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Destruction of buildings
  • B.Loss of life
  • C.Contamination caused by flood waters
  • D.Erosion of river banks
Correct Answer: Contamination caused by flood waters

The passage clearly states:

 

“The biggest economic loss from floods is usually not the buildings and property they carry away but rather, the contamination they cause.”

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 48
Read the following passage and answer the questions.Floods are normal events that cause damage. As rivers carve and shape the landscape, they build broad floodplains, level expanses that are periodically inundated. A “10-year flood” would be expected to occur once in every ten years; a “100-year flood” would be expected to occur once every century. The biggest economic loss from floods is usually not the buildings and property they carry away but rather, the contamination they cause. Many human activities like paving roads and parking lots reduce water infiltration into the soil and speed the rate of runoff into streams and lakes. Even more than development, though, flood-control structures have separated floodplains from rivers. Levees and flood walls are built to contain water within river banks, and river channels are dredged and deepened to allow water to recede faster. Every flood-control structure simply transfers the problem down-stream. However, the water has to go somewhere. If it doesn’t soak into the ground upstream, it will simply exacerbate floods somewhere downstream - leading to more levee development, and then to more flooding farther downstream, and so on.How do human activities like paving the roads and parking lots influence floods?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.They reduce the severity of floods
  • B.They speed up the rate of run off into streams and lakes
  • C.They decrease the volume of water discharge after a storm
  • D.They have no influence on floods
Correct Answer: They speed up the rate of run off into streams and lakes

The passage states:

 

“Many human activities like paving roads and parking lots reduce water infiltration into the soil and speed the rate of runoff into streams and lakes.”

 

Thus, option (B) is correct.

Question 49
Read the following passage and answer the questions.Floods are normal events that cause damage. As rivers carve and shape the landscape, they build broad floodplains, level expanses that are periodically inundated. A “10-year flood” would be expected to occur once in every ten years; a “100-year flood” would be expected to occur once every century. The biggest economic loss from floods is usually not the buildings and property they carry away but rather, the contamination they cause. Many human activities like paving roads and parking lots reduce water infiltration into the soil and speed the rate of runoff into streams and lakes. Even more than development, though, flood-control structures have separated floodplains from rivers. Levees and flood walls are built to contain water within river banks, and river channels are dredged and deepened to allow water to recede faster. Every flood-control structure simply transfers the problem down-stream. However, the water has to go somewhere. If it doesn’t soak into the ground upstream, it will simply exacerbate floods somewhere downstream - leading to more levee development, and then to more flooding farther downstream, and so on.How do flood control structures like levees and flood walls affect downstream areas ?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.They prevent floods
  • B.They reduce flooding in all areas
  • C.They transfer the problem downstream, exacerbating floods there
  • D.They increase the absorption of water upstream
Correct Answer: They transfer the problem downstream, exacerbating floods there

The passage clearly states:

 

“Every flood-control structure simply transfers the problem downstream... it will simply exacerbate floods somewhere downstream – leading to more levee development, and then to more flooding farther downstream, and so on.”

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Question 50
Read the following passage and answer the questions.Floods are normal events that cause damage. As rivers carve and shape the landscape, they build broad floodplains, level expanses that are periodically inundated. A “10-year flood” would be expected to occur once in every ten years; a “100-year flood” would be expected to occur once every century. The biggest economic loss from floods is usually not the buildings and property they carry away but rather, the contamination they cause. Many human activities like paving roads and parking lots reduce water infiltration into the soil and speed the rate of runoff into streams and lakes. Even more than development, though, flood-control structures have separated floodplains from rivers. Levees and flood walls are built to contain water within river banks, and river channels are dredged and deepened to allow water to recede faster. Every flood-control structure simply transfers the problem down-stream. However, the water has to go somewhere. If it doesn’t soak into the ground upstream, it will simply exacerbate floods somewhere downstream - leading to more levee development, and then to more flooding farther downstream, and so on.What do broad floodplains, created by rivers often lead to?(UGC NET 03 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Higher mountain formation
  • B.Damage soil condition
  • C.Periodic inundation
  • D.Formation of lakes
Correct Answer: Periodic inundation

The passage states:

 

“As rivers carve and shape the landscape, they build broad floodplains, level expanses that are periodically inundated.”

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Quiz Attempt #119708

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the cumulative percentage distribution of the total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together and cumulative number of visitors to Kullu on five different days, that is Monday to Friday. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions.Note: Total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together in all five days is 4000.The total number of visitors to Manali on Monday and Wednesday is ______ % of the number of visitors to Kullu on Wednesday.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.200
  • B.150
  • C.125
  • D.50
Correct Answer: 200

Correct answer option A.

Required percentage = 960480 × 100 = 200%

Question 2
The following table shows the cumulative percentage distribution of the total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together and cumulative number of visitors to Kullu on five different days, that is Monday to Friday. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions.Note: Total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together in all five days is 4000.What is the average number of visitors to Manali on all the days except Monday?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.560
  • B.520
  • C.490
  • D.450
Correct Answer: 450

Correct answer is option D.

Required number = 18004 = 450

Question 3
The following table shows the cumulative percentage distribution of the total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together and cumulative number of visitors to Kullu on five different days, that is Monday to Friday. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions.Note: Total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together in all five days is 4000.If 20% of the visitors to Kullu on Tuesday are foreigners and 40% of the visitors to Manali on Friday are foreigners, then what is the total number of visitors to Kullu on Tuesday who are not foreigners and to Manali on Friday who are foreigners?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.920
  • B.776
  • C.984
  • D.844
Correct Answer: 776

Required number = 80% of 700 + 40% of 540 = 776

Question 4
The following table shows the cumulative percentage distribution of the total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together and cumulative number of visitors to Kullu on five different days, that is Monday to Friday. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions.Note: Total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together in all five days is 4000.The average number of visitors to Kullu on Monday and Thursday is ______ % less than the number of visitors to Manali on Wednesday.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.53.29
  • B.63.89
  • C.67.44
  • D.50.28
Correct Answer: 63.89

Required percentage = 720-360+1602720 × 100 = 63.89%

Question 5
The following table shows the cumulative percentage distribution of the total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together and cumulative number of visitors to Kullu on five different days, that is Monday to Friday. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions.Note: Total number of visitors to Kullu and Manali together in all five days is 4000.What is the ratio of the number of visitors to Manali on Wednesday to the number of visitors to Kullu on Thursday?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.9:2
  • B.4:3
  • C.2:9
  • D.3:4
Correct Answer: 9:2

Required ratio = 720160 = 9 : 2

Question 6
Which of the following are the characteristics of learner-centered approach?A. It lays emphasis on skillsB. It is centered on learner's needsC. It is centered on cooperative determination of subject matterD. Lays emphasis on variability of exposureChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.C and D only
  • B.A, B and C only
  • C.A, B, C and D
  • D.B and D only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and D

A learner-centered approach focuses on the active involvement and development of the learner rather than passive reception of knowledge. Let’s evaluate each statement:

 

A. It lays emphasis on skills

Correct – It promotes critical thinking, problem-solving, and application skills.

 

B. It is centered on learner's needs

Correct – The approach tailors content and methods to suit individual learning styles, pace, and interests.

 

C. It is centered on cooperative determination of subject matter

Correct – It encourages collaboration between teachers and students in selecting or shaping the content.

 

D. Lays emphasis on variability of exposure

Correct – Recognizes that different learners benefit from varied experiences and methods (e.g., projects, discussions, digital tools).

 

Thus, all four statements are characteristics of the learner-centered approach.

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Question 7
Which of the following is a free and open-source content collaboration framework based on Javascript that enables existing CMSs and LMSs to create richer content?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.H5P
  • B.Plotagon
  • C.Mindmeister
  • D.Labster
Correct Answer: H5P

H5P stands for HTML5 Package. It is a free and open-source content collaboration framework based on JavaScript, which allows educators and developers to create, share, and reuse interactive HTML5 content.

 

It can be integrated into existing CMSs and LMSs like Moodle, WordPress, and Drupal.

 

It supports a wide variety of rich content types like interactive videos, quizzes, presentations, timelines, drag-and-drop activities, etc.

 

Other options:

(B) Plotagon – A tool to create animated videos, not a content framework.

 

(C) MindMeister – A mind-mapping tool, not for content collaboration in LMSs.

 

(D) Labster – Provides virtual science labs and simulations, not a content collaboration framework.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 8
A child of first class is trying to learn how to draw a circle on his own but is able to do with the help of his/her teacher. In the light of Vygotsky's theory, it highlights?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Assimilation
  • B.Adoption
  • C.Zone of proximal development
  • D.Maturation
Correct Answer: Zone of proximal development

According to Lev Vygotsky's sociocultural theory, the Zone of Proximal Development (ZPD) is the range between:

  • What a learner can do independently, and
  • What they can do with guidance or support from a teacher or more knowledgeable other.

 

In the question:

 

The child cannot draw the circle alone, but can do so with the teacher’s help ➝ This is exactly what ZPD represents.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 9
Project method of teaching was first propounded by:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Crow and Crow
  • B.John Dewey
  • C.Robert Miller
  • D.Robert Mager
Correct Answer: John Dewey

The Project Method of teaching was first propounded by John Dewey, an American philosopher and education reformer. It was later developed and implemented by his student William Heard Kilpatrick, who gave it wider popularity.

 

Key Ideas of Project Method:

  • Learning through purposeful, real-life activities.
  • Encourages active participation, collaboration, and problem-solving.
  • Emphasizes "learning by doing", which aligns with Dewey’s philosophy.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 10
SWAYAM is a programme initiated by:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Government of India
  • B.National Council of Education Research and Training
  • C.University Grants commission
  • D.Indira Gandhi National Open University
Correct Answer: Government of India

SWAYAM (Study Webs of Active Learning for Young Aspiring Minds) is an initiative by the Government of India, specifically launched by the Ministry of Education (formerly MHRD).

Question 11
If a conclusion incorporates a casual relationship between two or more variables it has measured:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.External validity
  • B.Internal validity
  • C.Replicability
  • D.Conceptualisation
Correct Answer: Internal validity

When a conclusion incorporates a causal relationship between two or more variables, it refers to internal validity. Internal validity measures whether the observed effects in a study are due to the manipulation of the independent variable and not to other factors. Hence, the correct answer is B.

Question 12
An instrument used in structured observation that mentions the categories of behaviour to be observed is known as:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Category schedule
  • B.Observation device
  • C.Observation schedule
  • D.Ontological tool
Correct Answer: Observation schedule

An observation schedule is a structured instrument used to guide the observation process, listing the specific categories of behavior that should be observed. This tool helps the researcher systematically record the behaviors of interest. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

Question 13
Response of participants who are well aware of the fact that they are being studied is considered as:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Directed response
  • B.Intentional response
  • C.Desire effect
  • D.Reactive effect
Correct Answer: Reactive effect

When participants are aware that they are being studied, their responses may be influenced by this knowledge, which is known as the reactive effect. This term describes the changes in behavior due to the awareness of being observed. Hence, the correct answer is D.

Question 14
Which type of ethnography challenges traditional methods, incorporating postmodern critiques and often questioning the power dynamics in research?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Classical ethnography
  • B.Mainstream ethnography
  • C.Post-modern ethnography
  • D.Expressive ethnography
Correct Answer: Post-modern ethnography

Post-modern ethnography critiques traditional research methods, emphasizing power relations and questioning the authority of researchers in representing the communities they study. It often involves reflexivity and a focus on multiple perspectives.

Question 15
Qualitative research makes use of:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Scaling
  • B.Factoring
  • C.Representative quotations
  • D.SPSS
Correct Answer: Representative quotations

Qualitative research often involves collecting and analyzing non-numeric data such as interviews, observations, and textual data. One key aspect of qualitative research is the use of representative quotations, which capture the essence of participants' experiences and provide rich, descriptive insights. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

Question 16
In ancient times, the oral communication system operated in an environment that was:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Literate
  • B.Urban
  • C.Non-representative
  • D.Mediated
Correct Answer: Non-representative

In ancient times, oral communication was the primary means of sharing knowledge, traditions, and information. It operated in an environment that was:

  • Largely illiterate, with little to no writing systems.
  • Based on direct person-to-person interaction, not recorded or mediated by devices or media.
  • Non-representative, meaning it did not use symbols or scripts (like written text) to represent language.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 17
Any study of messages at the receivers stage is known as:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Communicator analysis
  • B.Message analysis
  • C.Noise analysis
  • D.Audience analysis
Correct Answer: Audience analysis

Audience analysis refers to the study of the receiver in the communication process — including their needs, background, knowledge level, attitudes, and preferences. It helps in tailoring the message for better understanding and impact at the receiver’s end.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 18
Which of the following are main functions of mass communication:A. Detachment of individual from societyB. Indulge in message creation without worrying about moral consequencesC. Surveillance of environmentD. Transmission of social heritageE. Correlating the parts of society in response to environmentChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.C, D and E only
  • C.A, B, and D only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: C, D and E only

The main functions of mass communication include:

 

(C) Surveillance of environment

Refers to monitoring and reporting events, news, and changes in society and the world.

 

(D) Transmission of social heritage

Involves passing on cultural values, norms, traditions, and knowledge from one generation to the next.

 

(E) Correlating the parts of society in response to environment

Mass media helps coordinate and unify society by providing common knowledge and shared values, especially in response to crises or major events.

 

Thus, option (B) is correct.

Question 19
For preservation of their power the ruling elites seek from media channels.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Societal intelligence
  • B.Entrepreneurial partnership
  • C.Digital technology diffusion
  • D.Voices of dissent
Correct Answer: Societal intelligence

Ruling elites often use media channels to gather and manage societal intelligence — information about public opinion, social trends, and population behavior.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 20
Individual who live in a particular community develop distinctively patterned systems of(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Information distribution
  • B.Media ownership
  • C.Media marketing
  • D.Information imperialism
Correct Answer: Information distribution

People living within a specific community tend to develop unique ways of sharing, interpreting, and circulating information based on their cultural, social, and environmental context.

 

This is referred to as information distribution — the patterns and channels through which information flows within a group or society.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 21
Two persons X and Y invested ₹15,000 and ₹20,000, respectively, in a business. At the end of the year, they share the profit in the ratio of 3:1. If X has invested his money for the whole year, for how many months Y has invested his money?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.3
  • B.6
  • C.5
  • D.4
Correct Answer: 3

Let Y invested his money for x years.

Then, 15000×1220000×x = 31

or x = 3

Question 22
In a certain code language A is coded as Z, B is coded as Y, C is coded as X, and so on. How ‘PERFECT’ will be coded in that language?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.KVIUVXG
  • B.KVIVUXG
  • C.KVIUVGX
  • D.KVUIVXG
Correct Answer: KVIUVXG

PERFECT ----- KVIUVXG

Question 23
A sum of money becomes ₹34,800 in 2 years and ₹42,000 in 5 years at simple interest per annum. Find the rate of interest and the sum of money respectively(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.6%, ₹40,000
  • B.7%, ₹30,000
  • C.8%, ₹30,000
  • D.5%, ₹35,000
Correct Answer: 8%, ₹30,000

So, Simple Interest (SI) for 3 years = ₹7,200

SI for 1 year = ₹7,200 ÷ 3 = ₹2,400

P = 34800 – 4800 = 30000

4800 = 30000×R×2100

or R = 8%

Question 24
What number would replace question mark (?) in the series given below?1, 7, 16, 28, 43, 61, 82 ?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.102
  • B.143
  • C.106
  • D.110
Correct Answer: 106

7 − 1 = 6

16 − 7 = 9

28 − 16 = 12

43 − 28 = 15

61 − 43 = 18

82 − 61 = 21

Thus, next number 82 + 24 = 106

Question 25
In an examination, average marks of six students is 50. However, during cross-checking of the papers, it is found that the marks of one student has been misread as 48 instead of 84. Find the correct average marks of the students.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.52
  • B.54
  • C.56
  • D.58
Correct Answer: 56

Total marks = 50 × 6 = 300

Correct average marks = 300-48+846 = 56

Question 26
Which informal fallacy is committed in the following statement “Famous actor Jimmy Pecker has said in an interview that astrology is a real science, therefore scientists now must acknowledge that astrology is actually a science.”?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Appeal to Inappropriate authority
  • B.Red herring
  • C.Strawman
  • D.Appeal to Ignorance
Correct Answer: Appeal to Inappropriate authority

The fallacy committed in the statement is (A) Appeal to Inappropriate Authority. This fallacy occurs when an argument relies on the opinion of an authority figure who is not an expert in the relevant field. In this case, the famous actor Jimmy Pecker, who is not an expert in science or astrology, is cited as authority to claim that astrology is a real science. This does not provide valid evidence for the scientific status of astrology.

Red herring (B) is a fallacy where an irrelevant topic is introduced to divert attention from the original issue.

Strawman (C) involves misrepresenting or oversimplifying an opposing argument to make it easier to attack.

Appeal to Ignorance (D) asserts that a claim is true because it has not been proven false, or vice versa.

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Appeal to Inappropriate Authority.

Question 27
Which of the following statements are subalternate as per traditional square of opposition?A. All plants are green organismsB. No plants are green organismsC. Some plants are not green organismsD. Some plants are green organisms(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A and D only
  • B.B and D only
  • C.A and C only
  • D.A and B only
Correct Answer: A and D only

Some plants are green organisms is sub-alternate of All plants are green organisms, as per traditional square of opposition

Question 28
Which of the following statements are logically equivalent?A. All cats are carnivorous animalsB. All non-carnivorous animals are non-catsC. No cats are non-carnivorous animalsD. Some carnivorous animals are cats(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.C and D only
Correct Answer: A, B and C only

All non-carnivorous animals are non-cats is CONTRAPOSITION of All cats are carnivorous animals

No cats are non-carnivorous animals is OBVERSION of All cats are carnivorous animals

Question 29
If the statement “all lions are carnivorous animals” is given as true which of the following statements can be immediately inferred to be false?A. No lions are carnivorous animalsB. Some lions are carnivorous animalsC. Some lions are not carnivorous animalsD. Some carnivorous animals are lions(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.C and D only
  • B.A and C only
  • C.A and B only
  • D.B and C only
Correct Answer: A and C only

If A is given as true, then both E and O are false.

Question 30
As per classical Indian school of logic (Nyāya) which of the following fallacy is committed when the middle term is too wide?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Anupasamḥāri
  • B.Bādhita
  • C.Sādhārana
  • D.Asādhārana
Correct Answer: Sādhārana

It is a kind of "Sadharana" Fallacy.

 

Sadharana: Here the middle term is too wide. It is present in both the sapaksa (positive) and the vipaksa (negative) instances and violates the rule that the middle should not be present in the negative instances (vipaksasattva). For example, ‘the hill has fire because it is knowable’. Here ‘knowable is present in fiery as well as non-fiery objects'.

Question 31
Consider the following snapshot of MS-Excel worksheet:In cell D18, the value returned by the function:=SUMIFS (C18:C23, B18:B23, “>3”, C18:C23, “>500”) is ________.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.1466
  • B.2140
  • C.1773
  • D.26
Correct Answer: 1773

Correct answer is option C – 1773.

Question 32
In the context of Computer Networks, which of the following best describes the transmission of a message using packet switching?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Data packets may follow different routes and may arrive at different times in different order.
  • B.Data packets will always follow the same route and arrive at the same time in the same order.
  • C.Data packets will always follow the same route but could arrive at different times in different order.
  • D.Data packets may follow different routes but will always arrive at the same time in the same order.
Correct Answer: Data packets may follow different routes and may arrive at different times in different order.

The correct answer is: (A) Data packets may follow different routes and may arrive at different times in different order.

 

In packet switching, a message is broken into smaller units called packets. Each packet is transmitted independently and can take different routes through the network depending on the current network conditions. As a result:

 

Packets may arrive at different times.

 

They may arrive out of order.

 

The destination system reassembles the packets into the correct sequence.

 

This method is efficient and resilient, making it the basis of communication on the Internet.

Question 33
Which of the following statements is true about Number system?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.The binary equivalent of the decimal number 57.625 is 111000.101
  • B.1456=7510
  • C.10112+10012=2010
  • D.6510=2205
Correct Answer: 10112+10012=2010

Binary equivalent of the decimal number 57.625 is 111001.101. Hence A is incorrect.

1456 is equal to 65 in base 10. Hence B is incorrect.

2205 is equal to 60 in base 10. Hence D is incorrect.

Question 34
Which of the following statements about Read Only Memory (ROM) are correct?A. The contents of the memory remain intact even when the power to the ROM is turned offB. ROM is often used to store the start-up instructions when the computer is first switched onC. As the ROM becomes full, the processor has to continually access the hard diskD. ROM is a volatile memory.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A and C only
  • D.A, B, C and D
Correct Answer: A and B only

The correct answer is: (A) A and B only

 

Explanation:

A. The contents of the memory remain intact even when the power to the ROM is turned off

– Correct. ROM is non-volatile memory, meaning it retains data even when power is off.

 

B. ROM is often used to store the start-up instructions when the computer is first switched on

– Correct. The BIOS or firmware, which contains start-up instructions, is stored in ROM.

 

C. As the ROM becomes full, the processor has to continually access the hard disk

– Incorrect. ROM is not dynamic storage that fills up during operation. It contains fixed instructions and does not "fill up" like RAM.

 

D. ROM is a volatile memory

– Incorrect. ROM is non-volatile by definition.

Question 35
Which of the following statements is true about computers?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.The quality of the pictures taken by a digital camera depends on its resolution, which is measured in megabytes
  • B.USB stands for Universal Secure Bus
  • C.Microsoft Excel is an example of system software
  • D.The size of a computer monitor is measured diagonally across the screen
Correct Answer: The size of a computer monitor is measured diagonally across the screen

The correct answer is: (D) The size of a computer monitor is measured diagonally across the screen

 

(A) False – The quality of digital camera images depends on resolution measured in megapixels, not megabytes.

 

(B) False – USB stands for Universal Serial Bus, not Universal Secure Bus.

 

(C) False – Microsoft Excel is application software, not system software.

 

(D) True – The size of a computer monitor is indeed measured diagonally from one corner of the screen to the opposite corner.

Question 36
Which one of the following is used as a reference to measure the Global Warming Potential (GWP) of a greenhouse gas?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Carbon dioxide (CO₂)
  • B.Methane (CH₄)
  • C.Chlorofluorocarbon (CFC)
  • D.Hydrofluorocarbon (HFC)
Correct Answer: Carbon dioxide (CO₂)

The correct answer is: (A) Carbon dioxide (CO₂)

 

Carbon dioxide (CO₂) is used as the reference gas for measuring the Global Warming Potential (GWP) of other greenhouse gases. It is assigned a GWP value of 1, and the GWP of other gases is calculated relative to it based on their heat-trapping ability and atmospheric lifetime.

Question 37
Sustainable Development Goal 7 is related to:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Gender Equality
  • B.Climate Action
  • C.Affordable and Clean Energy
  • D.Quality Education
Correct Answer: Affordable and Clean Energy

The correct answer is: (C) Affordable and Clean Energy

 

Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 7 aims to "ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all."

It focuses on increasing the use of renewable energy, improving energy efficiency, and expanding infrastructure for energy access.

Question 38
Toxic substances that damage kidneys are called:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Hematotoxic
  • B.Neurotoxic
  • C.Cytotoxic
  • D.Nephrotoxic
Correct Answer: Nephrotoxic

The correct answer is: (D) Nephrotoxic

 

Nephrotoxic substances are those that damage the kidneys.

 

Hematotoxic – affects the blood

 

Neurotoxic – affects the nervous system

 

Cytotoxic – toxic to cells in general

 

So, substances harmful to the kidneys are specifically called nephrotoxic.

Question 39
Montreal Protocol is related to the protection of:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Biodiversity
  • B.Glaciers
  • C.Oceans
  • D.Stratospheric ozone layer
Correct Answer: Stratospheric ozone layer

The correct answer is: (D) Stratospheric ozone layer

 

The Montreal Protocol, adopted in 1987, is an international treaty designed to phase out the production and consumption of ozone-depleting substances (ODS) such as CFCs and halons. Its primary goal is to protect the stratospheric ozone layer, which shields the Earth from harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

Question 40
Which of the following are examples of organic pollutants in water?A. SaltsB. PesticidesC. DioxinsD. BasesE. PigmentsChoose the correct answer.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B, and C only
  • B.B, C, and D only
  • C.C, D, and E only
  • D.B, C, and E only
Correct Answer: B, C, and E only

The correct answer is (D) B, C, and E only.

 

Explanation: Organic pollutants in water are typically carbon-based chemicals. In this case:

 

B (Pesticides) are organic compounds used to kill pests.

 

C (Dioxins) are toxic organic compounds that result from industrial processes.

 

E (Pigments) are organic compounds that can be found in dyes and coloring agents.

 

Salts (A) and bases (D) are inorganic compounds, so they are not considered organic pollutants.

Question 41
In the Buddhist system of education higher education was placed at:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.The first level
  • B.The second level
  • C.The third level
  • D.The fourth level
Correct Answer: The second level

The correct answer is (B) The second level.

 

In the Buddhist system of education, higher education was typically placed at the second level, which involved more advanced teachings and training, including meditation and philosophical study.

Question 42
Which one of the following is a deemed to be university?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Periyar University, Salem
  • B.Nagaland University, Kohima
  • C.Guru Ghasidas Vishwavidyalaya, Bilaspur
  • D.Gandhigram Rural University, Madurai
Correct Answer: Gandhigram Rural University, Madurai

The correct answer is (D) Gandhigram Rural University, Madurai.

 

Gandhigram Rural University is a deemed-to-be university. It focuses on rural development and is recognized as a "deemed university" under the UGC (University Grants Commission) Act 1956.

 

An Institution of Higher Education, other than universities, working at a very high standard in specific area of study, can be declared by the Central Government on the advice of the UGC as an Institution ‘Deemed-to-be-university’. Institutions that are ‘deemed-to-be-university’ enjoy academic status and privileges of a university.

Question 43
Which of the following is included among the core values promoted by NAAC (National Assessment and Accreditation Council) among the institutions of higher learning?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Framing National Education Protocols
  • B.Promoting religious education
  • C.Total Privatisation of education
  • D.Fostering global competencies among students and teachers
Correct Answer: Fostering global competencies among students and teachers

The correct answer is (D) Fostering global competencies among students and teachers.

 

NAAC promotes core values that include fostering global competencies, enhancing critical thinking, and encouraging holistic development in students and faculty. This is aimed at making higher education institutions globally competitive and socially relevant. The other options do not align with NAAC's values.

Question 44
Which of the following are true regarding Fort William College?A. Its medium of education was EnglishB. Lord Wellesley taught hereC. Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar taught hereD. It was here that Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar studied along with Subhash Chandra BoseChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, C, and D only
  • B.B and D only
  • C.A, B, C, D
  • D.A and C only
Correct Answer: A and C only

The correct answer is (D) A and C only.

 

A (Its medium of education was English): Fort William College used English as the medium of instruction.

 

C (Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar taught here): Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar was indeed involved with Fort William College.

Question 45
According to National Education Policy 2020, which of the following universal human values will be considered as an integral part of holistic education?A. TruthB. SympathyC. Righteous conductD. Non-violenceE. Scientific temperChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.C and E only
  • B.B, D and E only
  • C.A, C, D, and E only
  • D.A, B, C, and D only
Correct Answer: A, C, D, and E only

The correct answer is (C) A, C, D, and E only.

 

According to the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020, the following universal human values are integral to holistic education:

 

A (Truth): Truth is a core value.

 

C (Righteous conduct): Ethical and moral behavior is emphasized.

 

D (Non-violence): Non-violence is a key principle.

 

E (Scientific temper): The policy encourages the promotion of scientific thinking and rationality.

Question 46
Read the passage and answer the following.The field ecologist has played a key role in shining the light on the species we love and admire. They have also underlined why conservation should not be just about caring for a few charismatic species—the cats, elephants, whales, or Olive Ridleys. It’s also about knowing the value of creatures many of us might consider annoying, even dangerous. For millennia, communities have attempted to protect animals and plants for practical and spiritual reasons. However, for around two centuries or so, an anthropocentric view of the world created an ecological discord of sorts. Utilitarian ideas began to dominate attitudes towards nature, which often meant that even conservation had a strictly commercial purpose. Modern environmental consciousness is about six decades old. In India, organisations such as the Bombay Natural History Society date back to the late 19th century and the endeavors of hunters-turned-conservationists played an important role in underlining the value of several species. But systematic efforts in mainstreaming ecology began much later and owed much to the works of pioneers like Salim Ali and M Krishnan.Utilitarian ideas started dominating attitudes towards nature about.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.2000 years ago
  • B.60 years ago
  • C.100 years ago
  • D.200 years ago
Correct Answer: 200 years ago

The passage states:

 

"However, for around two centuries or so, an anthropocentric view of the world created an ecological discord of sorts. Utilitarian ideas began to dominate attitudes towards nature..."

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 47
Read the passage and answer the following.The field ecologist has played a key role in shining the light on the species we love and admire. They have also underlined why conservation should not be just about caring for a few charismatic species—the cats, elephants, whales, or Olive Ridleys. It’s also about knowing the value of creatures many of us might consider annoying, even dangerous. For millennia, communities have attempted to protect animals and plants for practical and spiritual reasons. However, for around two centuries or so, an anthropocentric view of the world created an ecological discord of sorts. Utilitarian ideas began to dominate attitudes towards nature, which often meant that even conservation had a strictly commercial purpose. Modern environmental consciousness is about six decades old. In India, organisations such as the Bombay Natural History Society date back to the late 19th century and the endeavors of hunters-turned-conservationists played an important role in underlining the value of several species. But systematic efforts in mainstreaming ecology began much later and owed much to the works of pioneers like Salim Ali and M Krishnan.Modern environmental consciousness is.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.~ 20 years old
  • B.~ 40 years old
  • C.~ 60 years old
  • D.~ 100 years old
Correct Answer: ~ 60 years old

The passage clearly mentions:

 

"Modern environmental consciousness is about six decades old."

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 48
Read the passage and answer the following.The field ecologist has played a key role in shining the light on the species we love and admire. They have also underlined why conservation should not be just about caring for a few charismatic species—the cats, elephants, whales, or Olive Ridleys. It’s also about knowing the value of creatures many of us might consider annoying, even dangerous. For millennia, communities have attempted to protect animals and plants for practical and spiritual reasons. However, for around two centuries or so, an anthropocentric view of the world created an ecological discord of sorts. Utilitarian ideas began to dominate attitudes towards nature, which often meant that even conservation had a strictly commercial purpose. Modern environmental consciousness is about six decades old. In India, organisations such as the Bombay Natural History Society date back to the late 19th century and the endeavors of hunters-turned-conservationists played an important role in underlining the value of several species. But systematic efforts in mainstreaming ecology began much later and owed much to the works of pioneers like Salim Ali and M Krishnan.Identify the charismatic species based on the information given in the passage.A. DeerB. WhalesC. ElephantsD. Dogs(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.C and D only
  • D.A and D only
Correct Answer: B and C only

The passage states:

 

“Conservation should not be just about caring for a few charismatic species—the cats, elephants, whales, or Olive Ridleys.”

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 49
Read the passage and answer the following.The field ecologist has played a key role in shining the light on the species we love and admire. They have also underlined why conservation should not be just about caring for a few charismatic species—the cats, elephants, whales, or Olive Ridleys. It’s also about knowing the value of creatures many of us might consider annoying, even dangerous. For millennia, communities have attempted to protect animals and plants for practical and spiritual reasons. However, for around two centuries or so, an anthropocentric view of the world created an ecological discord of sorts. Utilitarian ideas began to dominate attitudes towards nature, which often meant that even conservation had a strictly commercial purpose. Modern environmental consciousness is about six decades old. In India, organisations such as the Bombay Natural History Society date back to the late 19th century and the endeavors of hunters-turned-conservationists played an important role in underlining the value of several species. But systematic efforts in mainstreaming ecology began much later and owed much to the works of pioneers like Salim Ali and M Krishnan.Identify the correct statements.A. Conservation is all about caring for the species we love and admireB. Communities have been living in ecological harmony for the last two centuriesC. Field ecologists have contributed to our understanding about the value of different species in our livesD. Salim Ali is considered a pioneer in India in the field of mainstream ecology(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.C and D only
  • D.A and D only
Correct Answer: C and D only

. Let’s evaluate each statement based on the passage:

 

A. Conservation is all about caring for the species we love and admire

Incorrect – The passage explicitly states:

“Conservation should not be just about caring for a few charismatic species...”

 

B. Communities have been living in ecological harmony for the last two centuries

Incorrect – The passage says:

“For around two centuries, an anthropocentric view... created an ecological discord...”

So, harmony was disrupted two centuries ago.

 

C. Field ecologists have contributed to our understanding about the value of different species in our lives

Correct – The passage begins by highlighting the role of field ecologists in showing why all species, even those seen as annoying or dangerous, are valuable.

 

D. Salim Ali is considered a pioneer in India in the field of mainstream ecology

Correct – The passage says:

“Systematic efforts... owed much to the works of pioneers like Salim Ali and M. Krishnan.”

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 50
Read the passage and answer the following.The field ecologist has played a key role in shining the light on the species we love and admire. They have also underlined why conservation should not be just about caring for a few charismatic species—the cats, elephants, whales, or Olive Ridleys. It’s also about knowing the value of creatures many of us might consider annoying, even dangerous. For millennia, communities have attempted to protect animals and plants for practical and spiritual reasons. However, for around two centuries or so, an anthropocentric view of the world created an ecological discord of sorts. Utilitarian ideas began to dominate attitudes towards nature, which often meant that even conservation had a strictly commercial purpose. Modern environmental consciousness is about six decades old. In India, organisations such as the Bombay Natural History Society date back to the late 19th century and the endeavors of hunters-turned-conservationists played an important role in underlining the value of several species. But systematic efforts in mainstreaming ecology began much later and owed much to the works of pioneers like Salim Ali and M Krishnan.Communities have been involved in the protection of plants and animals for the last.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Morning)
  • A.Several thousand years
  • B.200 years only
  • C.60 years only
  • D.only recently
Correct Answer: Several thousand years

The passage states:

 

"For millennia, communities have attempted to protect animals and plants for practical and spiritual reasons."

 

Thus, the answer is option (A).

Quiz Attempt #119709

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The table shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table, and you are expected to calculate the missing values if required. Based on the table, answer the questions that follow.If the total number of items sold by A and B on all five days is 4000 and 4400, respectively, then the number of items sold by B on Tuesday is _________ % more than the number of items sold by A on Friday.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.37.5
  • B.23.5
  • C.32.25
  • D.42.5
Correct Answer: 37.5

Items sold by B on Tuesday = 4400 – (880 + 480 + 1020 + 920) = 1100

Items sold by A on Friday = 4000 – (840 + 720 + 560 + 1080) = 800

Required Percentage = 1100-800800 = 37.5%

Question 2
The table shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table, and you are expected to calculate the missing values if required. Based on the table, answer the questions that follow.If the ratio of the number of items sold by B and C together on Thursday to the number of items sold by C and E together on the same day is 2:1, then the number of items sold by C on Thursday is:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.300
  • B.420
  • C.380
  • D.340
Correct Answer: 380

Let items sold by C on Thursday = x

Then, 1020+xx+320 = 21

or 2x + 640 = 1020 + x

or 2x – x = 1020 – 640

or x = 380

Question 3
The table shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table, and you are expected to calculate the missing values if required. Based on the table, answer the questions that follow.If the total number of items sold by A on all five days is 3600, then the difference between the number of items sold by A on Monday and Friday is:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.640
  • B.450
  • C.420
  • D.440
Correct Answer: 440

Items sold by A on Friday = 3600 – (840 + 720 + 560 + 1080) = 400

Required difference = 840 – 400 = 440

Question 4
The table shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table, and you are expected to calculate the missing values if required. Based on the table, answer the questions that follow.If the average number of items sold by D on Monday and Tuesday is 490, then the number of items sold by E on Friday is _________% more than the number of items sold by D on Monday.(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.39.76
  • B.42.86
  • C.48.23
  • D.45
Correct Answer: 42.86

Items sold by D on Monday = 980 – 420 = 560

Required Percentage = 800-560560 × 100 = 42.86%

Question 5
The table shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table, and you are expected to calculate the missing values if required. Based on the table, answer the questions that follow.If the number of items sold by C on Thursday is the average of the number of items sold by C on Wednesday and Friday, then the total number of items sold by C on all five days is:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.3500
  • B.3800
  • C.3400
  • D.3700
Correct Answer: 3800

Items sold by C on Thursday = 820+7002 = 760

Total number of items sold by C on all the days = 480 + 1040 + 820 + 760 + 700 = 3800

Question 6
Match the List-I with List-II.LIST I (ICT/Tools)A. PadletB. RubricsC. QuizletD. MentimeterLIST II (Functions)I. Criteria-based assessment and feedbackII. Collaborative digital bulletin boardIII. Real-time audience response and pollingIV. Interactive Flashcards and Study setsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • C.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • D.A-I, B-IV, C-III, D-II
Correct Answer: A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III

The correct answer is option (B) i.e., A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III.

 

Let's match each tool in List I with its correct function from List II:

 

A. Padlet – II. Collaborative digital bulletin board

Padlet is a digital tool that allows users to post notes, images, links, and files on a virtual wall. It is widely used for collaborative learning and idea sharing.

 

B. Rubrics – I. Criteria-based assessment and feedback

Rubrics are evaluation tools that list criteria for a task and describe levels of quality for each criterion. They are used for giving structured feedback.

 

C. Quizlet – IV. Interactive Flashcards and Study sets

Quizlet is a learning platform that uses flashcards, matching games, and tests to help with memorization and learning.

 

D. Mentimeter – III. Real-time audience response and polling

Mentimeter is an interactive tool used in live presentations to gather real-time feedback, polls, and quizzes from the audience.

Question 7
A teacher assigns a video lecture for students to watch at home before coming to class. The next day in the class, she engages students in ‘hands-on’ experimental activities. Which approach did she use in this situation?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Problem solving
  • B.Collaborative learning
  • C.Flipped classroom
  • D.Personalized learning
Correct Answer: Flipped classroom

In a flipped classroom, students first gain exposure to new material at home, often via video lectures, and then use classroom time for active learning, such as discussions, problem-solving, or hands-on activities.

 

In this question:

 

  • The teacher assigns a video lecture to watch at home ➝ content delivery outside the classroom.

 

  • The next day is used for hands-on experiments ➝ classroom time for practical application.

 

This matches the flipped classroom model.

Question 8
A way of dealing with conflict in which people express their feelings, ask for what they want, say ‘no’ to things they don’t want, and act in their own best interests, is known as:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Aggressive style
  • B.Passive style
  • C.Assertive style
  • D.Manipulative style
Correct Answer: Assertive style

Assertive style involves expressing one’s thoughts, feelings, and needs openly, honestly, and respectfully, while also respecting others' rights. It includes saying “no” when needed, standing up for oneself, and communicating clearly without being aggressive or submissive.

 

Let's contrast briefly:

 

  • Aggressive style: Dominating others, often disrespectfully.

 

  • Passive style: Avoiding conflict, not expressing true feelings or needs.

 

  • Manipulative style: Influencing others indirectly or deceptively for personal gain.

 

Hence, the style described — expressing feelings, asking clearly, saying no, and acting in one’s interest — is best described as assertive.

Question 9
The transfer of learning from one situation to another situation that is conscious and effortful is known as:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Near transfer
  • B.High-road transfer
  • C.Low-road transfer
  • D.Far transfer
Correct Answer: High-road transfer

High-road transfer involves conscious, effortful application of knowledge or skills from one context to another. It requires reflection, abstraction, and thoughtful processing.

 

Let’s differentiate the terms:

 

(A) Near transfer: Applying learning to a similar context or situation (e.g., using skills learned in one math problem on a similar one).

 

(B) High-road transfer: Deliberate and mindful transfer of knowledge to distant or different situations.

 

(C) Low-road transfer: Happens automatically, without conscious effort, in similar situations (e.g., driving different cars).

 

(D) Far transfer: Applying learning to a dissimilar context, often overlaps with high-road transfer but emphasizes the distance between contexts.

 

So, conscious and effortful transfer = High-road transfer.

Question 10
The belief that one can master a situation and produce positive outcomes is known as:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Self-efficacy
  • B.Self-esteem
  • C.Self-actualization
  • D.Self-regulation
Correct Answer: Self-efficacy

Self-efficacy is the belief in one's ability to succeed in specific situations or accomplish a task. It influences how people think, feel, and behave — especially their motivation and persistence in challenging situations.

 

Let’s clarify the other options:

 

  • Self-esteem: One’s overall sense of self-worth or value.

 

  • Self-actualization: The realization or fulfillment of one’s talents and potential, a concept from Maslow’s hierarchy.

 

  • Self-regulation: The ability to control one's emotions, thoughts, and behaviors in pursuit of long-term goals.
  •  

Thus, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 11
‘Code numbers given to the religion of persons’ is an example of data on which of the following scales of measurement?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Nominal
  • B.Ordinal
  • C.Interval
  • D.Ratio
Correct Answer: Nominal

The code numbers assigned to religions represent categories without any specific order or meaningful difference between them. This makes it an example of the nominal scale, which is used for labelling or categorizing data without any quantitative value or hierarchy.

Question 12
The criterion of ‘dependability’ in qualitative research parallels which of the following criteria in quantitative research?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Objectivity
  • B.Internal validity
  • C.External validity
  • D.Reliability
Correct Answer: Reliability

In qualitative research, dependability refers to the consistency and reliability of the research process, similar to reliability in quantitative research. Reliability ensures that the research results can be repeated and are consistent over time and across different situations. Therefore, dependability in qualitative research parallels reliability in quantitative research.

Question 13
Identify the correct statement about the quantitative content analysis:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.It can allow a certain amount of longitudinal analysis
  • B.It is an obtrusive method
  • C.It is a very rigid method
  • D.It is a reactive method
Correct Answer: It can allow a certain amount of longitudinal analysis

Quantitative content analysis involves systematically counting and measuring elements in media or text to analyze trends over time. Longitudinal analysis refers to studying data over an extended period, making option A correct. This method can track changes across different time points, allowing for longitudinal analysis.

Question 14
The geometric mean of the number 9, 12, and 16 is:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.12.33
  • B.11.66
  • C.12
  • D.12.66
Correct Answer: 12

The geometric mean is calculated by multiplying the numbers together and then taking the nth root (where n is the number of values). For the numbers 9, 12, and 16:

Thus, the geometric mean is 12 (option C).

Question 15
SupposeH0= Null Hypothesis,Ha= Alternate Hypothesis, μ = population mean,µ0= hypothesized mean. A researcher sets upH0: μ =µ0andHa: μ <µ0.In this situation, the researcher would apply:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Right-tailed test
  • B.Left-tailed test
  • C.Two-tailed test
  • D.Half-tailed test
Correct Answer: Left-tailed test

This indicates a left-tailed test because the critical region for rejecting the null hypothesis is in the left tail of the distribution, where values smaller than the hypothesized mean are considered significant. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

Question 16
The Western Society considers communication as an instrument of -(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Aggression
  • B.Separation
  • C.Covert operations
  • D.Human relationship
Correct Answer: Human relationship

In Western society, communication is primarily viewed as a tool for building and maintaining human relationships. It emphasizes clarity, self-expression, individualism, and open dialogue as essential for effective interpersonal interaction.

 

Let’s quickly review the other options:

 

(A) Aggression – Not a typical or primary view of communication in Western culture.

 

(B) Separation – Communication is meant to bridge gaps, not create them.

 

(C) Covert operations – This relates to secrecy or military intelligence, not the general societal view.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 17
The context in which communication takes place is termed as -(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Historical background
  • B.Objectification
  • C.Environment
  • D.Mediasphere
Correct Answer: Environment

The context or setting in which communication occurs — including physical, social, psychological, and cultural surroundings — is referred to as the communication environment.

 

Thus, option (C) is the correct answer.

Question 18
In non-verbal communication, a symbol representing an object is known as -(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Identify symbol
  • B.Explanatory symbol
  • C.Animated symbol
  • D.Concrete symbol
Correct Answer: Concrete symbol

In non-verbal communication, a concrete symbol is a tangible or visual representation that stands for a real object. These symbols are easily understood because they closely resemble the object they represent.

 

For example:

  • A fork and knife icon on a sign = restaurant
  • A red cross symbol = medical help or hospital

 

Such symbols help in quick recognition without needing words, making them powerful in visual communication.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 19
Communication is continuously -(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Evolving
  • B.Negative
  • C.Stagnant
  • D.Subliminal
Correct Answer: Evolving

Communication is a dynamic and ongoing process that constantly adapts to changes in technology, culture, society, and human behavior. It evolves through new languages, media platforms, non-verbal cues, and cultural expressions.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 20
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Communication noise)A. SemanticB. PhysicalC. PsychologicalD. PhysiologicalLIST II (Description)1. Exists outside of the receiver2. Communicator's prejudices and biases towards another person3. The biological influence on the communication process4. Linguistic influence on message receptionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • B.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • C.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
  • D.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III

The correct answer is option (C), i.e., A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III.

 

Let’s match each type of communication noise with its correct description:

 

A. Semantic noise → IV. Linguistic influence on message reception

Occurs when the meaning of words or language used interferes with understanding (e.g., jargon, unfamiliar terms).

 

B. Physical noise → I. Exists outside of the receiver

This is external interference like traffic sounds, construction noise, or background chatter that disrupts communication.

 

C. Psychological noise → II. Communicator's prejudices and biases

Internal factors such as attitudes, emotions, stereotypes, or biases that affect how a message is received or interpreted.

 

D. Physiological noise → III. Biological influence

Physical conditions like hearing problems, fatigue, or illness that affect communication.

Question 21
A school boy, travelling at 3 km/hr, reaches his school 28 minutes late but when he travels at 5 km/hr, he reaches his school 28 minutes early. What distance does he travel every day to reach the school?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.6 km
  • B.8 km
  • C.7 km
  • D.9 km
Correct Answer: 7 km

Let distance = x km

Then, x3 - x5 = 5660

or 5x-3x15 = 5660

or x = 7

Question 22
There are three positive numbers. One third of the average of all the three numbers is 8 less than the value of the highest number. If the average of the lowest and the second lowest number is 8, then what is the highest number?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.9
  • B.10
  • C.11
  • D.12
Correct Answer: 11

Let three numbers be x, y and z. Also let z be the highest number.

Then, 13 x+y+z3 = z – 8

or 8z – 72 = x+y --------------(i)

From second condition, x+y2 = 8

or x + y = 16 --------------------(ii)

Solving equations (i) and (ii), we get

z = 11

Question 23
In a school, there were 1582 students and the ratio of the number of boys and girls was 4:3. After a few days, 30 girls joined the school but few boys left the school and as a result, the ratio of boys and girls became 7:6. The number of boys who left the school is?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.84
  • B.74
  • C.86
  • D.78
Correct Answer: 78

Let x and y be the number of boys and girls respectively

x + y = 1582 ----------(i)

and xy = 43

or x = 43 y ----------(ii)

Solving equations (i) and (ii), we get

x = 904 and y = 678

Now, let b boys left the school

Then, 904-b678+30 = 76

or b = 78

Question 24
What will be the value of P in the following number series?0, 3, 26, 255, P, ...........(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.624
  • B.511
  • C.1023
  • D.3124
Correct Answer: 3124

0 = 10 − 1 = 1 - 1 = 0

3 = 22 − 1 = 4 - 1 = 3

26 = 33 − 1 = 27 - 1 = 26

255 = 44 − 1 = 256 - 1 = 255

Next number = 55 − 1 = 3125 - 1 = 3124

Question 25
A certain sum of money becomes ₹28800 in 2 years at 20% per annum of compound interest (Compounded annually). The sum of money is:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.₹24000
  • B.₹22000
  • C.₹21000
  • D.₹20000
Correct Answer: ₹20000

Let P be the amount of money.

Then, P (1+0.2)2 = 28800

or P = 288001.44 = 20000

Question 26
Arrange the following terms in order of increasing abstractness:(1) Alloy(2) Metal(3) Steel(4) MineralChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.3, 2, 4, 1
  • B.3, 1, 2, 4
  • C.3, 1, 4, 2
  • D.4, 2, 1, 3
Correct Answer: 3, 1, 2, 4

The terms are arranged in increasing order of abstractness based on their level of generality:

Steel (3): A specific type of alloy, a mixture of metals, so it is the most concrete term.

Alloy (1): A mixture of metals, less specific than steel, but still concrete.

Metal (2): A broader category, including a variety of metallic elements and alloys, so it is more abstract.

Mineral (4): A much broader and more abstract term, as it includes naturally occurring substances that can be metals or non-metals.

Thus, the correct order of increasing abstractness is Steel (3), Alloy (1), Metal (2), Mineral (4).

Question 27
Which of the following statements are true regarding the word ‘God’?(1) It is meaningless(2) It is meaningful(3) The word God has no intension that could be its meaning.(4) In case of word ‘God’, there is an intension that is its meaning.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.2 and 4 only
  • B.1 and 3 only
  • C.1 only
  • D.2 only
Correct Answer: 2 and 4 only

The word ‘God’ has an intension, which refers to the inherent meaning or concept behind the word. For many people, it refers to a supreme being or deity, which is meaningful. So:

(1) It is meaningless is incorrect because the word ‘God’ has a specific meaning for many individuals and cultures.

(2) It is meaningful is correct because the word ‘God’ conveys a concept or idea, especially in religious or philosophical contexts.

(3) The word God has no intension that could be its meaning is incorrect because ‘God’ does have an intension, or conceptual meaning.

(4) In case of the word ‘God’, there is an intension that is its meaning is correct because the word ‘God’ indeed has an intension, representing a concept of a deity or supreme being.

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) 2 and 4 only.

Question 28
“A line is composed of points. Points have no length. Therefore a line has no length.” Which informal fallacy is committed in this statement?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Fallacy of composition
  • B.Equivocation
  • C.Hasty generalisation
  • D.Slippery slope
Correct Answer: Fallacy of composition

The argument in the statement commits the fallacy of composition (A). This fallacy occurs when it is assumed that what is true of the parts must also be true of the whole. In this case, the argument assumes that because points have no length, the line, which is composed of points, must also have no length. This reasoning incorrectly applies the properties of the parts (points) to the whole (line).

Equivocation (B) involves using a word with different meanings in different parts of an argument.

Hasty generalization (C) is drawing a conclusion based on insufficient or unrepresentative evidence.

Slippery slope (D) involves assuming that a relatively small first step will inevitably lead to a chain of related events with significant negative consequences.

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Fallacy of composition.

Question 29
Which of the following statement is logically equivalent to the statement - “No liquids are beverages.”?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.All non-beverages are non-liquids
  • B.All liquids are beverages
  • C.Some beverages are not liquids
  • D.No beverages are liquids
Correct Answer: No beverages are liquids

“No beverages are liquids” is Conversion of “No liquids are beverage”

Question 30
According to Classical Indian School of Logic (Nyaya), the argument - “Sound is eternal because it is produced” is fallacious because:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.The middle term instead of being pervaded by the presence of the major term is pervaded by its absence.
  • B.The locus of the middle term is impossible.
  • C.The middle term instead of being pervaded by the absence of the major term is pervaded by its presence.
  • D.It lacks any major term.
Correct Answer: The middle term instead of being pervaded by the presence of the major term is pervaded by its absence.

It is an example of Viruddha Fallacy.

 

Viruddha is the contradictory middle. The middle term, instead of being pervaded by the presence of the major term, is pervaded by the absence of the major term. Instead of proving the existence of the major term in the minor term, it proves its non-existence therein; e.g., 'sound is eternal, because it is produced'. Here ‘produced, instead of proving the eternality of sound, proves its non-eternality. Here the middle term itself disproves the original proposition and proves its contradictory.

Question 31
A security system used a camera to capture images of each person entering a gift shop. Each image taken requires 1 MB of storage. If the camera captures an image every 5 seconds over a 24-hour period, how much storage is required?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.16.875 GB
  • B.15.250 GB
  • C.12.525 GB
  • D.19.625 GB
Correct Answer: 16.875 GB

24 hours = 24 × 60 × 60 = 86400 secs

Number of images captured = 864005 = 17280 images

Total storage = 17280 × 1 = 17280 MB = 172801024 = 16.875 GB

Question 32
With reference to different number systems, which of the following statements is true?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.(109)10=(1101001)2
  • B.(123)5=(212)4
  • C.(101)16+(110)8=(429)10
  • D.(241)6=(131)8
Correct Answer: (123)5=(212)4

(123)5 = 3 × 50 + 2 × 51 + 1 × 52 = 38

(212)4 = 2 × 40 + 1 × 41 + 2 × 42 = 38

Thus, option B is correct.

Question 33
In the context of Bluetooth and Wi-Fi as wireless communication technologies, which of the following statements are true?(1) Bluetooth allows for short-range data transfer between electronic devices, whereas Wi-Fi allows electronic devices to connect to the Internet.(2) Bluetooth needs a direct line of sight for data transmission, whereas Wi-Fi does not need it.(3) Bluetooth limits the number of devices that can connect at any one time, whereas Wi-Fi is open to more devices and more users.(4) Bluetooth does not need a direct line of sight for data transmission, whereas Wi-Fi does need it.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.1 and 2 only
  • B.2 and 3 only
  • C.1, 3 and 4 only
  • D.1 and 3 only
Correct Answer: 1 and 3 only

Bluetooth is typically used for short-range data transfer (e.g., between phones, headphones). Wi-Fi allows devices to connect to the Internet through a router.

 

Bluetooth does not require line of sight; it uses short-range radio waves. Wi-Fi also does not require line of sight. So, this statement is incorrect.

 

Bluetooth typically supports 7 active connections (limited). Wi-Fi supports many more users and connections (dozens to hundreds depending on router capability).

Thus, only options 1 and 3 are correct.

Question 34
In computers, which of the following statements is true?(UGC NET 02 Sep 2024 Evening)
  • A.Data matrix printer is a type of non-impact printer
  • B.Laser printer is a type of impact printer
  • C.The resolution of a laser printer is measured in Megabits per second (Mbps)
  • D.Data matrix printers are noisy, low quality and slow in comparison to laser printers
Correct Answer: Data matrix printers are noisy, low quality and slow in comparison to laser printers

Data matrix printers are noisy, low quality and slow in comparison to laser printers. Dot matrix printers, which are a type of impact printer, function by physically striking an ink ribbon to create text or images on paper. This results in noisy operation, lower print quality, and slower speed compared to laser printers, which are non-impact printers using toner and laser technology to produce high-quality prints silently and quickly. Therefore, option D accurately reflects the key differences between these two printer types.

Question 35
