  • Scanner is an input device, not an output device, as it is used to scan documents.
  • Light pen is also an input device, used to draw or select objects on a screen.

 

Thus, the correct answer is B, D, and E Only.

Question 35
Match List - I with List - II.List - I (ICT Term)A. VoIPB. Instant Messaging (IM)C. VPND. WWWList - II (Definition)I. A tool for real-time communication between two or more people sending text messages to their devicesII. A system of interlinked hypertext documents accessed via the InternetIII. A technology that allows you to talk with other people using the internetIV. A network that protects data by encrypting network trafficChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.A-(II), B-(I), C-(IV), D-(III)
  • B.A-(IV), B-(II), C-(III), D-(I)
  • C.A-(III), B-(I), C-(II), D-(IV)
  • D.A-(III), B-(I), C-(IV), D-(II)
Correct Answer: A-(III), B-(I), C-(IV), D-(II)

The correct answer is (D) A-(III), B-(I), C-(IV), D-(II).

 

A. VoIP (Voice over Internet Protocol): A technology that allows you to talk with other people using the internet (III).

 

B. Instant Messaging (IM): A tool for real-time communication between two or more people sending text messages to their devices (I).

 

C. VPN (Virtual Private Network): A network that protects data by encrypting network traffic (IV).

 

D. WWW (World Wide Web): A system of interlinked hypertext documents accessed via the Internet (II).

 

Thus, the correct matching is A-(III), B-(I), C-(IV), D-(II).

Question 36
Which of the following are routes for exposure to pollutants in humans?A. InhalationB. ConsumptionC. IngestionD. DermalE. DigestionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.A, C and D Only
  • C.B, D and E Only
  • D.A, C and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

The correct answer is (B) A, C and D Only.

 

Inhalation (A): Pollutants can be inhaled through the air.

 

Consumption (C): Pollutants can be consumed through food or water.

 

Dermal (D): Pollutants can be absorbed through the skin.

 

Ingestion (E) and Digestion (C) are not specifically distinct routes of exposure. Digestion is part of the process of consumption but not a separate route.

 

Thus, the correct options are A, C, and D only.

Question 37
Which one of the following is considered as a prominent indoor air pollutant?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.Mercury
  • B.Radon
  • C.Helium
  • D.Argon
Correct Answer: Radon

The correct answer is (B) Radon.

 

Radon is a naturally occurring radioactive gas that can accumulate in indoor environments, particularly in basements or poorly ventilated areas. It is considered a prominent indoor air pollutant because it is linked to lung cancer risk.

 

Mercury, Helium, and Argon are not considered major indoor air pollutants.

Question 38
Leachate is a:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.Greenhouse gas
  • B.Air pollutant
  • C.Liquid extract from landfill site
  • D.Ozone depleting substance
Correct Answer: Liquid extract from landfill site

The correct answer is (C) Liquid extract from landfill site.

 

Leachate is the liquid that drains or 'leaches' from a landfill. It is formed when rainwater or other liquids percolate through the waste material, dissolving chemicals and pollutants in the process.

 

It is a significant environmental concern as it can contaminate nearby water sources if not managed properly.

Question 39
Which of the following are true about tropospheric or ground level ozone?A. It is called as good ozoneB. It is formed due to downward transfer of ozone from ozone layerC. It is formed due to the action of sunlight on oxides of nitrogenD. It is a greenhouse gasE. It is a key component of photochemical smogChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.B, C, D and E Only
  • B.A, B and C Only
  • C.C, D and E Only
  • D.A, D and E Only
Correct Answer: B, C, D and E Only

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Tropospheric ozone (ground-level ozone) is not considered "good ozone." Ozone in the stratosphere is often referred to as "good ozone" because it protects us from harmful UV radiation, while ground-level ozone is considered harmful.

 

Near Earth’s surface, ozone is produced in chemical reactions involving naturally occurring gases and gases from pollution sources. Production reactions primarily involve hydrocarbon and nitrogen oxide gases and require sunlight. Fossil fuel combustion is a primary pollution source for tropospheric ozone production. The surface production of ozone does not significantly contribute to the abundance of stratospheric ozone. The amount of surface ozone is too small in comparison, and the transport of surface air to the stratosphere is not effective enough. However, UGC NET has given Statement B correct.

 

Tropospheric ozone is a greenhouse gas because it absorbs infrared radiation, contributing to global warming.

 

It is a key component of photochemical smog, which is a type of air pollution, especially in urban area

Question 40
Which of the following are true about International Solar Alliance (ISA)?A. There are over 100 member countries in this allianceB. Its headquarter is in Geneva, SwitzerlandC. Most of its member countries lie between equator and tropic of cancerD. Primary objective of alliance is to efficiently use solar energyE. It is a collaborative initiative of India and FranceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B and D Only
  • B.A, D and E Only
  • C.B, C and E Only
  • D.C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, D and E Only

The correct answer is: (B) A, D and E Only.

 

A. There are over 100 member countries – True. ISA has over 110 member countries as of recent updates.

 

B. Its headquarters is in Geneva, Switzerland – False. The ISA headquarters is located in Gurugram, Haryana, India.

 

C. Most of its member countries lie between equator and Tropic of Cancer – False. Most member countries lie between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn, not just the equator and Tropic of Cancer.

 

D. Primary objective is efficient use of solar energy – True. ISA aims to promote the sustainable and efficient use of solar energy.

 

E. It is a collaborative initiative of India and France – True. ISA was launched jointly by India and France in 2015 at COP21 in Paris.

Question 41
The Kothari Commission (1963-64) suggested spending ______ of national income on education.(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.3 percent
  • B.6 percent
  • C.7 percent
  • D.9 percent
Correct Answer: 6 percent

The correct answer is: (B) 6 percent.

 

The Kothari Commission (1964–66), officially known as the Indian Education Commission, recommended that 6% of the national income should be allocated to education to ensure comprehensive educational development in India.

Question 42
The University Education Commission (1948-49) suggested a bachelor degree of:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.Five years
  • B.Four years
  • C.Three years
  • D.Two years
Correct Answer: Three years

The correct answer is: (C) Three years.

 

The University Education Commission (1948–49), chaired by Dr. S. Radhakrishnan, recommended a three-year bachelor’s degree after completing 12 years of school education. This structure laid the foundation for India’s modern undergraduate system.

Question 43
Which of the following were measures initiated by Lord Auckland?A. Guaranteed the maintenance of oriental collegesB. Publication of useful works for instruction in oriental languagesC. Selection of certain places for establishing central colleges for highest instructionD. Closure of college librariesE. Abolition of student scholarshipsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B, C Only
  • B.B, C, D Only
  • C.C, D, E Only
  • D.A, D, E Only
Correct Answer: A, B, C Only

The correct option is A. The measures initiated by Lord Auckland are –

A. Guaranteed the maintenance of oriental colleges

B. Publication of useful works for instruction in oriental languages

C. Selection of certain places for establishing central colleges for highest instruction

Question 44
Identify the correct chronological order of the establishment of the following colleges:A. Fort William College, CalcuttaB. Sanskrit College, PoonaC. Central Hindu College, BenaresD. Anglo-Vedic College, LahoreE. Sanskrit College, BenaresChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.A, B, C, E, D
  • B.C, D, B, E, A
  • C.D, E, A, B, C
  • D.E, A, B, D, C
Correct Answer: E, A, B, D, C

The correct answer is option (D) - E, A, B, D, C.

 

Chronological Order of Establishment:

 

Sanskrit College, Benares

Fort William College, Calcutta

Sanskrit College, Poona

Anglo-Vedic College, Lahore

Central Hindu College, Benares

 

This sequence correctly reflects the historical timeline of these prominent educational institutions in India.

Question 45
Match List - I with List - II.List - I (Commission)A. Hunter CommissionB. Sadler CommissionC. Hartog CommitteeD. Sargent planList - II (Recommendation)I. University technological departments providing for research and teachingII. Withdrawal of government support to collegiate educationIII. Development of mofussil colleges into future university centresIV. Enrichment of college libraries and concentration on Honours courses in select centresChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.A-(I), B-(II), C-(III), D-(IV)
  • B.A-(II), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(I)
  • C.A-(III), B-(IV), C-(I), D-(II)
  • D.A-(IV), B-(I), C-(II), D-(III)
Correct Answer: A-(II), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(I)

The correct answer is option (B) - A-(II), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(I).

 

A. Hunter Commission → (II) Withdrawal of government support to collegiate education

The 1882 Hunter Commission focused on primary and secondary education and recommended reducing government involvement in collegiate education.

 

B. Sadler Commission → (III) Development of mofussil colleges into future university centres

The 1917–19 Sadler Commission studied problems of Calcutta University and suggested reforms including the upliftment of mofussil (provincial) colleges.

 

C. Hartog Committee → (IV) Enrichment of college libraries and concentration on Honours courses in select centres

The 1929 Hartog Committee emphasized improving standards in higher education with better facilities and focused honours courses.

 

D. Sargent Plan → (I) University technological departments providing for research and teaching

The 1944 Sargent Plan was a post-war proposal recommending significant investment in education, including advanced university research and technology.

Question 46
Read the passage carefully and answer the questions that follow:Holidays are often a time of culinary indulgence even for people who are usually careful about diets for the rest of the year.But there is more to holiday eating than avoiding excess calories. What we eat affects the health of the entire body, including the immune system. Since the most of the body’s immune system is concentrated in the gut and the trillions of healthy bacteria living there called the microbiome – what we eat has a direct impact on how the immune system functions. “A lot of people don’t think about the effects of what they eat on immunity. But the science says it’s crucial”, says Heather Moday, MD, Founder of the Moday Centre for Functional and Integrative Medicine in Norfolk, Virginia, and Philadelphia. And it’s especially important at this time of year, since the winter holidays occur around the time when illnesses like colds, flu and other respiratory illnesses peak.While an occasional indulgence probably won’t cause lasting damage, throwing caution to the wind till New Year’s Day is certainly unhealthy and might make you more susceptible to getting sick. “Even just a month of really just blowing it and not caring about nutrition can impact the microbiome”, says Kristin Kirkpatrick, a registered dietitian at Cleveland Clinic’s department of wellness and preventive medicine.Important key message the above text conveys about holiday eating can be stated as follows:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.It is important to completely avoid indulgence
  • B.Occasional indulgence is unlikely to cause lasting damage
  • C.Diet has no significant impact on the immune system
  • D.Holidays are an ideal time to experiment with extreme diets
Correct Answer: Occasional indulgence is unlikely to cause lasting damage

The main takeaway is: Occasional indulgence is unlikely to cause lasting damage.

Question 47
Read the passage carefully and answer the questions that follow:Holidays are often a time of culinary indulgence even for people who are usually careful about diets for the rest of the year.But there is more to holiday eating than avoiding excess calories. What we eat affects the health of the entire body, including the immune system. Since the most of the body’s immune system is concentrated in the gut and the trillions of healthy bacteria living there called the microbiome – what we eat has a direct impact on how the immune system functions. “A lot of people don’t think about the effects of what they eat on immunity. But the science says it’s crucial”, says Heather Moday, MD, Founder of the Moday Centre for Functional and Integrative Medicine in Norfolk, Virginia, and Philadelphia. And it’s especially important at this time of year, since the winter holidays occur around the time when illnesses like colds, flu and other respiratory illnesses peak.While an occasional indulgence probably won’t cause lasting damage, throwing caution to the wind till New Year’s Day is certainly unhealthy and might make you more susceptible to getting sick. “Even just a month of really just blowing it and not caring about nutrition can impact the microbiome”, says Kristin Kirkpatrick, a registered dietitian at Cleveland Clinic’s department of wellness and preventive medicine.Find out the correct statement that describes the primary focus of Heather Moday’s statement in the text:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.The benefits of a balanced diet
  • B.The relationship between diet and immune system
  • C.The importance of regular exercise
  • D.The effects of meditation on health
Correct Answer: The relationship between diet and immune system

Heather Moday's statement in the passage emphasizes that:

 

“A lot of people don’t think about the effects of what they eat on immunity. But the science says it’s crucial.”

 

This clearly highlights the link between diet and how the immune system functions. The passage further supports this by explaining that most of the immune system is located in the gut, where diet plays a major role in maintaining the microbiome.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 48
Read the passage carefully and answer the questions that follow:Holidays are often a time of culinary indulgence even for people who are usually careful about diets for the rest of the year.But there is more to holiday eating than avoiding excess calories. What we eat affects the health of the entire body, including the immune system. Since the most of the body’s immune system is concentrated in the gut and the trillions of healthy bacteria living there called the microbiome – what we eat has a direct impact on how the immune system functions. “A lot of people don’t think about the effects of what they eat on immunity. But the science says it’s crucial”, says Heather Moday, MD, Founder of the Moday Centre for Functional and Integrative Medicine in Norfolk, Virginia, and Philadelphia. And it’s especially important at this time of year, since the winter holidays occur around the time when illnesses like colds, flu and other respiratory illnesses peak.While an occasional indulgence probably won’t cause lasting damage, throwing caution to the wind till New Year’s Day is certainly unhealthy and might make you more susceptible to getting sick. “Even just a month of really just blowing it and not caring about nutrition can impact the microbiome”, says Kristin Kirkpatrick, a registered dietitian at Cleveland Clinic’s department of wellness and preventive medicine.Which of the following are effects of diet on the body’s immune system as discussed in the text?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.Increased cholesterol levels
  • B.Direct impact on immune system functions
  • C.Improved skin health
  • D.Loss of appetite
Correct Answer: Direct impact on immune system functions

The passage clearly states that:

 

"What we eat affects the health of the entire body, including the immune system."

"...the trillions of healthy bacteria living there called the microbiome – what we eat has a direct impact on how the immune system functions."

 

This confirms that the diet has a direct impact on the immune system’s functioning, especially through its influence on the gut microbiome.

Question 49
Read the passage carefully and answer the questions that follow:Holidays are often a time of culinary indulgence even for people who are usually careful about diets for the rest of the year.But there is more to holiday eating than avoiding excess calories. What we eat affects the health of the entire body, including the immune system. Since the most of the body’s immune system is concentrated in the gut and the trillions of healthy bacteria living there called the microbiome – what we eat has a direct impact on how the immune system functions. “A lot of people don’t think about the effects of what they eat on immunity. But the science says it’s crucial”, says Heather Moday, MD, Founder of the Moday Centre for Functional and Integrative Medicine in Norfolk, Virginia, and Philadelphia. And it’s especially important at this time of year, since the winter holidays occur around the time when illnesses like colds, flu and other respiratory illnesses peak.While an occasional indulgence probably won’t cause lasting damage, throwing caution to the wind till New Year’s Day is certainly unhealthy and might make you more susceptible to getting sick. “Even just a month of really just blowing it and not caring about nutrition can impact the microbiome”, says Kristin Kirkpatrick, a registered dietitian at Cleveland Clinic’s department of wellness and preventive medicine.Microbiomes are important as:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.They create lots of sugar in the body
  • B.They are healthy bacteria living in the body
  • C.They may raise blood pressure and heart disease risk
  • D.They increase the tendency for processed food
Correct Answer: They are healthy bacteria living in the body

From the passage:

 

"...the trillions of healthy bacteria living there called the microbiome – what we eat has a direct impact on how the immune system functions."

 

This clearly defines microbiomes as healthy bacteria residing in the gut, and they play a vital role in maintaining the body's immune system.

Question 50
Read the passage carefully and answer the questions that follow:Holidays are often a time of culinary indulgence even for people who are usually careful about diets for the rest of the year.But there is more to holiday eating than avoiding excess calories. What we eat affects the health of the entire body, including the immune system. Since the most of the body’s immune system is concentrated in the gut and the trillions of healthy bacteria living there called the microbiome – what we eat has a direct impact on how the immune system functions. “A lot of people don’t think about the effects of what they eat on immunity. But the science says it’s crucial”, says Heather Moday, MD, Founder of the Moday Centre for Functional and Integrative Medicine in Norfolk, Virginia, and Philadelphia. And it’s especially important at this time of year, since the winter holidays occur around the time when illnesses like colds, flu and other respiratory illnesses peak.While an occasional indulgence probably won’t cause lasting damage, throwing caution to the wind till New Year’s Day is certainly unhealthy and might make you more susceptible to getting sick. “Even just a month of really just blowing it and not caring about nutrition can impact the microbiome”, says Kristin Kirkpatrick, a registered dietitian at Cleveland Clinic’s department of wellness and preventive medicine.Which of the following statements is incorrect in the context of the given text?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.There is a lot less harm done if four days out of the week you are eating pretty well
  • B.To keep the immunity strong, one does not have to stop celebrating but needs to celebrate a little smarter
  • C.What we eat has a direct impact on the immune system
  • D.Occasional food indulgence will cause lasting damage
Correct Answer: Occasional food indulgence will cause lasting damage

Occasional food indulgence will cause lasting damage

This is incorrect, because the passage clearly says:

 

“While an occasional indulgence probably won’t cause lasting damage...”

Quiz Attempt #119713

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the number of players who participated in three sports events E1, E2 and E3 along with the ratio of Male (M) to Female (F) participants among them from six different countries, namely, India, US, China, Russia, England and Germany.Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:What is the total number of female participants in sports events E1 and E3 together?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.4274
  • B.4308
  • C.4326
  • D.4334
Correct Answer: 4334

E3 Female Total = 200 + 500 + 310 + 700 + 400 + 250 = 2360

Total = 1974 + 2360 = 4334

Question 2
The following table shows the number of players who participated in three sports events E1, E2 and E3 along with the ratio of Male (M) to Female (F) participants among them from six different countries, namely, India, US, China, Russia, England and Germany.Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:What is the ratio of the number of female participants from US in the event E2 to the number of female participants from China in the event E3?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.60 : 31
  • B.29 : 31
  • C.27 : 31
  • D.58 : 31
Correct Answer: 60 : 31

Required ratio = 512×144014×1240 = 60 : 31

Question 3
The following table shows the number of players who participated in three sports events E1, E2 and E3 along with the ratio of Male (M) to Female (F) participants among them from six different countries, namely, India, US, China, Russia, England and Germany.Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:What is the difference between the number of male participants and the number of female participants in the event E2 from all the six countries together?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.1724
  • B.1728
  • C.1732
  • D.1734
Correct Answer: 1732

Difference = 3860 – 2128 = 1732

Question 4
The following table shows the number of players who participated in three sports events E1, E2 and E3 along with the ratio of Male (M) to Female (F) participants among them from six different countries, namely, India, US, China, Russia, England and Germany.Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:The number of female participants from India in event E1 is ________ % less than the number of female participants from Germany in event E3.(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.40
  • B.36
  • C.28
  • D.22
Correct Answer: 36

India E1 Female = 13×480 = 160

Germany E3 Female = 13×750 = 250

Difference = 250 – 160 = 90

% less = 90250×100 = 36%

Question 5
The following table shows the number of players who participated in three sports events E1, E2 and E3 along with the ratio of Male (M) to Female (F) participants among them from six different countries, namely, India, US, China, Russia, England and Germany.Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:The number of participants from China in event E2 is ________% more than the number of female participants from US in event E3.(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.120
  • B.124
  • C.128
  • D.132
Correct Answer: 132

Required percentage = 1160-500500×100 = 132%

Question 6
Which of the following are not the examples of Positive - Transfer of Learning?A. Learning of Piano makes it more difficult to learn the violinB. Mastering Algebra helps in understanding CalculusC. Knowing how to drive a car makes it harder to learn how to ride a bicycleD. Learning to speak French hinders learning SpanishChoose the correct answer from the options given below.(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.B and D only
  • B.A, C and D only
  • C.B, C and D only
  • D.A and C
Correct Answer: A, C and D only

Positive Transfer of Learning occurs when learning one task helps in learning another.

 

Let’s evaluate each statement:

 

A. Learning of Piano makes it more difficult to learn the violin

This is an example of negative transfer, since the prior learning hinders new learning.

 

B. Mastering Algebra helps in understanding Calculus

This is positive transfer, because previous learning helps new learning.

 

C. Knowing how to drive a car makes it harder to learn how to ride a bicycle

Again, negative transfer — prior learning interferes with new learning.

 

D. Learning to speak French hinders learning Spanish

Another example of negative transfer, due to interference between similar languages.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 7
A web-based e-learning application allowing users to select a video and customize it by editing, cropping, recording their own audio and adding quiz questions directly to the video stream is known as:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.ED puzzle
  • B.Mindmeister
  • C.Miro
  • D.Labster
Correct Answer: ED puzzle

EDpuzzle is a web-based e-learning tool that allows teachers and learners to:

 

  • Select existing videos (from platforms like YouTube or upload their own),

 

  • Crop and edit the video,

 

  • Record voiceovers or add audio notes, and

 

  • Insert quiz questions (MCQs or open-ended) at different points in the video stream.

 

It is widely used for interactive video lessons, flipped classrooms, and formative assessments.

 

Let’s briefly check the other options:

 

  • MindMeister – a mind-mapping tool, not for video editing.

 

  • Miro – a collaborative whiteboard platform, not for customizing videos.

 

  • Labster – offers virtual science labs, but does not allow custom video editing.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 8
The process mostly completed within several hours, but which can last for years, which fixes information in long-term memory is known as:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Repression
  • B.Episodic memory
  • C.Consolidation
  • D.Retroactive interference
Correct Answer: Consolidation

Consolidation is the neurobiological process by which newly acquired information is stabilized and stored in long-term memory.

 

It often begins within hours of learning but can continue for days, weeks, or even years, especially with repeated use or emotional significance.

 

Let’s look at the other options:

 

(A) Repression – a defense mechanism where distressing memories are unconsciously blocked.

 

(B) Episodic memory – a type of long-term memory that stores personal experiences/events.

 

(D) Retroactive interference – occurs when new learning interferes with the recall of old information.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 9
In an online course, a teacher wants to organize weekly readings, quizzes and discussion forums for students. Which of the following platforms would be most suitable for managing these activities?A. SchoologyB. Blackboard learnC. ZoomD. CanvasE. MoodleOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.C, D and E Only
  • B.A, B and C Only
  • C.A, B, D and E Only
  • D.C and D Only
Correct Answer: A, B, D and E Only

The question asks for platforms suitable for organizing readings, quizzes, and discussion forums — key features of a Learning Management System (LMS).

 

Let’s evaluate the options:

 

A. Schoology – A full-featured LMS supporting readings, quizzes, discussions, assignments, and grading.

 

B. Blackboard Learn – A widely-used LMS with course management, quizzes, forums, and grading tools.

 

C. Zoom – A video conferencing tool, not an LMS. It does not manage readings or quizzes natively.

 

D. Canvas – A modern LMS that allows uploading readings, creating quizzes, discussion boards, and tracking student progress.

 

E. Moodle – An open-source LMS offering all the required features: reading materials, quizzes, and discussion forums.

 

Thus, platforms A, B, D, and E meet the teacher’s needs.

Question 10
Match List - I with List - IIList - I (Swayamprabha Channel No.):A. Channel 8B. Channel 9C. Channel 10D. Channel 11List - II (Theme):(I) Applied Sciences(II) Social Sciences and Humanities(III) Life Science(IV) Physical and Earth SciencesOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-(III), B-(II), C-(IV), D-(I)
  • B.A-(I), B-(II), C-(III), D-(IV)
  • C.A-(III), B-(IV), C-(II), D-(I)
  • D.A-(IV), B-(III), C-(I), D-(II)
Correct Answer: A-(IV), B-(III), C-(I), D-(II)

The correct match is as follows:

List I- List II

A. Channel 8 - Physical and Earth Sciences

B. Channel 9 - Life Science

C. Channel 10 - Applied Sciences

D. Channel 11 – Social Sciences and Humanities

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 11
According to UGC Regulations 2018 on Plagiarism, which of the following percentages of similarity in a research article would result in denial of one annual increment to a university teacher?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.62%
  • B.84%
  • C.48%
  • D.18%
Correct Answer: 48%

According to the UGC Regulations 2018 on Plagiarism, a similarity percentage between 40% to 60% in a research article results in a denial of one annual increment to a university teacher.

Question 12
Which of the following types of sampling is likely to have maximum bias?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Simple random sampling
  • B.Stratified random sampling
  • C.Snowball sampling
  • D.Cluster random sampling
Correct Answer: Snowball sampling

Bias in sampling refers to systematic errors that can occur when certain groups or individuals are more likely to be included in the sample than others. Let’s review the different types of sampling:

(A) Simple random sampling: This is one of the least biased methods because every individual has an equal chance of being selected. It's generally considered a very reliable method.

(B) Stratified random sampling: This involves dividing the population into subgroups (strata) and randomly selecting from each group. This ensures representation from all strata, reducing bias, especially if there are distinct groups within the population.

(C) Snowball sampling: This method relies on existing participants to refer others, which can introduce maximum bias. The sample is highly dependent on the initial participants, and it’s likely that the sample will not be representative of the broader population, especially if the initial sample is homogenous or from a specific network.

(D) Cluster random sampling: In this method, the population is divided into clusters, and then entire clusters are randomly selected. It can introduce some bias, but it's less biased than snowball sampling, as the clusters are randomly chosen, though the randomness might still not capture the diversity of the whole population if clusters are not well-divided.

 

The type of sampling most likely to have maximum bias is (C) Snowball sampling because it depends on referrals from participants, which can lead to a non-representative sample and potential homogeneity.

Question 13
Identify the threats to internal validity associated with participants in a study.A. Testing threatB. Selection threatC. History threatD. Attrition threatChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.A, B and D Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: B, C and D Only

In the context of internal validity, threats refer to factors that can affect the accuracy of the conclusions drawn about the relationship between variables. Here's a breakdown of each option:

A. Testing threat: This refers to the threat where the act of taking a test can affect participants' performance on subsequent tests. However, this is not directly related to participants themselves in the way selection, history, or attrition are.

B. Selection threat: This occurs when participants in the study are not randomly assigned, leading to differences between the experimental and control groups. This is a threat to internal validity because the differences may affect the outcome.

C. History threat: This refers to external events that occur during the study that could influence participants' behavior and skew the results. This is more of an external factor but still relevant to the participants' environment.

D. Attrition threat: This is when participants drop out of the study, leading to a loss of data and potentially altering the results if the drop-out rate is related to the variables being studied.

Thus, selection threat, history threat, and attrition threat are directly related to participants in a study.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) B, C and D Only.

Question 14
Arrange the data sets with following means (x̄) and standard deviations (σ) in increasing order of their coefficients of variation:A. σ = 3.7, x̄ = 20B. σ = 4.3, x̄ = 25C. σ = 5.2, x̄ = 35D. σ = 6.1, x̄ = 40Options:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.B, C, D, A
  • C.C, D, B, A
  • D.D, C, A, B
Correct Answer: C, D, B, A

To arrange the data sets in increasing order of their coefficient of variation (CV), we need to calculate the CV for each dataset. The coefficient of variation is given by the formula:

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) C, D, B, A.

Question 15
Match List - I with List - IIList I (Variable):A. Dichotomous variableB. Independent variableC. Dependent variableD. Interval variableList II (Description):(I) Is causally influenced by another variable(II) Where distances between categories are identical across its range of categories(III) Has just two categories(IV) Has a causal impact on another variableOptions: (UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-(I), B-(II), C-(III), D-(IV)
  • B.A-(III), B-(I), C-(IV), D-(II)
  • C.A-(III), B-(IV), C-(I), D-(II)
  • D.A-(I), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(II)
Correct Answer: A-(III), B-(IV), C-(I), D-(II)

Let's break down each option in the context of the matching between the variables and their descriptions:

A. Dichotomous variable: A dichotomous variable has only two categories. For example, yes/no, male/female, true/false. This matches with (III) Has just two categories.

B. Independent variable: The independent variable is the one that is manipulated or considered the cause in a causal relationship. This matches with (IV) Has a causal impact on another variable.

C. Dependent variable: The dependent variable is influenced or affected by changes in the independent variable. This matches with (I) Is causally influenced by another variable.

D. Interval variable: An interval variable has meaningful distances between categories but no true zero point (e.g., temperature in Celsius). This matches with (II) Where distances between categories are identical across its range of categories.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) A-(III), B-(IV), C-(I), D-(II).

Question 16
The interactive technologies are responsible for the appearance of:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Traditional media age
  • B.Broadcast media age
  • C.Market media age
  • D.Second media age
Correct Answer: Second media age

The Second Media Age refers to the rise of interactive, digital, and networked communication (like the internet and social media), in contrast to the First Media Age which was characterized by one-way mass communication like radio, TV, and print. Interactive technologies allow two-way communication and user participation.

Question 17
The interactive society is based on integration of:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Multiple communication modes
  • B.Dual communication restrictions
  • C.Single purpose audience
  • D.Varied face-to-face options
Correct Answer: Multiple communication modes

An interactive society uses a blend of communication forms—such as text, audio, video, and digital platforms—to facilitate dynamic, two-way interaction. This reflects the convergence of media and technologies in modern communication.

Question 18
The post-modern mass media have the characteristics of:A. ImmobilityB. MobilityC. GlobalisationD. SimulationE. LinearityOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B, C Only
  • B.B, C, D Only
  • C.C, D, E Only
  • D.A, C, E Only
Correct Answer: B, C, D Only

Post-modern media is known for:

 

Mobility – Access to media content anywhere (e.g., mobile phones, laptops).

 

Globalisation – Media transcends national borders, creating a global culture.

 

Simulation – Media often blurs the line between reality and fiction (e.g., virtual worlds, deepfakes).

Immobility and linearity are more typical of earlier media forms.

Question 19
Identify the chronological sequence of the following communication devices:A. Audio cassettesB. Long playing recordC. Magnetic tapeD. Compact discsE. MP3Options:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B, C, E, D
  • B.B, D, E, A, C
  • C.C, B, A, D, E
  • D.D, E, B, C, A
Correct Answer: C, B, A, D, E

Let’s arrange the communication/audio storage devices in chronological order of their introduction:

 

C. Magnetic tape – 1928

Introduced for audio recording and later used in reels and professional use.

 

B. Long Playing Record (LP) – 1948

Vinyl records that became standard for music distribution.

 

A. Audio cassettes – 1960s–1970s

Popularized by Philips, compact and portable.

 

D. Compact discs (CDs) – 1982

Digital audio storage, replacing cassettes and LPs over time.

 

E. MP3 – 1990s

Digital compression format allowing audio to be stored and shared easily online.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 20
Match List - I with List – IIList I (Concept of profit):A. SynergyB. Planned obsolescenceC. Logic of safetyD. SpectacleList II (Description):(I) Strong incentive to replicate a successful format(II) Media obsession with sensationalism(III) Horizontal integration of subsidiary media companies(IV) Planned Phasing out of productOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-(I), B-(II), C-(III), D-(IV)
  • B.A-(II), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(I)
  • C.A-(III), B-(IV), C-(I), D-(II)
  • D.A-(IV), B-(I), C-(II), D-(III)
Correct Answer: A-(III), B-(IV), C-(I), D-(II)

The correct answer is option ©.

Question 21
Match List - I with List – II.List I (Expression):A. 0.5 × 0.05 × 0.005 × 50B. 5.55 × 55.5 × 55C. 5.05 × 5.55 × 5.5D. 5.5 × 5.5 × 55.5List II (Value):(I) 154.15125(II) 16941.375(III) 1678.875(IV) 0.00625Options:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-(IV), B-(III), C-(I), D-(II)
  • B.A-(II), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(I)
  • C.A-(IV), B-(II), C-(I), D-(III)
  • D.A-(IV), B-(III), C-(II), D-(I)
Correct Answer: A-(IV), B-(II), C-(I), D-(III)

A. 0.5 × 0.05 × 0.005 × 50 = 00625

B. 5.55 × 55.5 × 55 = 16941.375

C. 5.05 × 5.55 × 5.5 = 154.15125

D. 5.5 × 5.5 × 55.5 = 1678.875

Question 22
Find the number that can be inserted at the place of question mark (?) in the series given below:6, 7/2, 8/3, 9/4, ?, 11/6(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.3
  • B.5/12
  • C.2
  • D.59/12
Correct Answer: 2

Missing number = 105 = 2

Question 23
Which of the following statements are true?A. A single discount, equivalent to a series of discounts of 20%, 10% and 5%, is 35%.B. If after two successive discounts of 12% and 5%, an article was sold for ₹209, then the original priceof the article is ₹250.C. If a shopkeeper allows two successive discounts of 5% each on the marked price of ₹80, the selling price of the article is ₹75.D. If the difference between a single discount of 35% and two successive discounts of 20% on a certain bill is ₹22, then the total amount of the bill is ₹2200.Options:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.A and C Only
  • C.B and D Only
  • D.C and D Only
Correct Answer: B and D Only

Only statements B and D are correct.

Question 24
In a certain coded language:“Indian cuisines are good” is coded as: “MI CI FI GI”“They like Indian cuisines” is coded as: “AI LI MI CI”“People like Indian Chinese” is coded as: “PI LI MI HI”“They and people are best” is coded as: “AI DI PI FI BI”How are the words ‘good’, ‘Chinese’, and ‘cuisines’ coded in this language?Options:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.GI, HI and CI
  • B.AI, LI and FI
  • C.MI, DI and BI
  • D.HI, CI and LI
Correct Answer: GI, HI and CI

"Indian" appears in 1, 2, 3

Common code in those = MI

 

"Cuisines" appears in 1, 2

Other common code besides MI = CI

 

So, Good = GI

Chinese = HI

Cuisines = CI

Question 25
The average age of a group of workers is 42 yrs. If eight (8) new workers of average age of 36 yrs join the group, the average age of the group becomes 40 yrs. Find the number of workers initially present in the group.(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.17
  • B.16
  • C.18
  • D.20
Correct Answer: 16

42x+(36×8)x+8 = 40

or x = 16

Question 26
“According to some newspapers today the Crime rate in New York has slightly increased in the recent past. New Yorkers are nothing but a bunch of criminals.”Which fallacy is committed in the above statement?Options:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Slippery slope
  • B.Appeal to Inappropriate Authority
  • C.Hasty Generalization
  • D.Strawman
Correct Answer: Hasty Generalization

The correct answer is: (C) Hasty Generalization

 

A hasty generalization occurs when a broad conclusion is drawn from a small or unrepresentative sample.

 

In this case, based on a slight increase in crime rate, the argument jumps to the extreme conclusion that all New Yorkers are criminals.

 

This overgeneralizes from limited or insufficient data, which is the essence of this fallacy.

Question 27
Which of the following statements are true?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)(A) An argument is sound when it is valid and has only true premises(B) In an argument truth of its conclusion determines its validity by itself(C) Some valid arguments have false premises and a true conclusion(D) Some invalid arguments have false premises and a true conclusionOptions:
  • A.(A), (C) and (D) Only
  • B.(A), (B) and (C) Only
  • C.(B) and (C) Only
  • D.(A), (B) and (D) Only
Correct Answer: (A), (C) and (D) Only

Let’s analyze each statement:

 

(A) An argument is sound when it is valid and has only true premises: This is correct. A sound argument is both valid (the conclusion logically follows from the premises) and has all true premises.

 

(B) In an argument, the truth of its conclusion determines its validity by itself: This is incorrect. The validity of an argument does not depend on the truth of the conclusion; it depends on the logical structure of the argument—whether the conclusion follows logically from the premises.

 

(C) Some valid arguments have false premises and a true conclusion: This is correct. A valid argument can have false premises and a true conclusion. Validity only ensures that if the premises are true, the conclusion must be true; it doesn’t require the premises to be true.

 

(D) Some invalid arguments have false premises and a true conclusion: This is correct. An argument can be invalid (the conclusion does not follow from the premises) but still have false premises and a true conclusion.

 

So, the correct answer is (A) (A), (C) and (D) Only.

Question 28
Arrange the following in order of decreasing extension:(a) Sonnet(b) Poem(c) Verse(d) LiteratureOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(a), (b), (c), (d)
  • B.(d), (c), (b), (a)
  • C.(d), (b), (a), (c)
  • D.(a), (b), (c), (d)
Correct Answer: (d), (b), (a), (c)

The correct order of decreasing extension is: Literature > Verse > Poem > Sonnet

Correct Answer: (B)

Question 29
Match List - I with List – IIList I (Informal fallacy):(a) Argument from Ignorance(b) Appeal to Emotion(c) Fallacy of Division(d) Begging the QuestionList II (Reason):(I) Presumption(II) Ambiguity(III) Relevance(IV) Defective InductionOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(a)-(IV), (b)-(II), (c)-(III), (d)-(I)
  • B.(a)-(IV), (b)-(I), (c)-(III), (d)-(II)
  • C.(a)-(I), (b)-(III), (c)-(II), (d)-(IV)
  • D.(a)-(IV), (b)-(III), (c)-(II), (d)-(I)
Correct Answer: (a)-(IV), (b)-(III), (c)-(II), (d)-(I)

Here’s the breakdown of the match between the informal fallacies and their respective reasoning types:

 

(A) Argument from Ignorance: This fallacy is related to defective induction because it claims something is true simply because it has not been proven false (or vice versa), which is a faulty form of inductive reasoning.

 

(B) Appeal to Emotion: This fallacy is an example of relevance, where the argument distracts from the issue at hand by appealing to the emotions of the audience, rather than providing logical support for the conclusion.

 

(C) Fallacy of Division: This is an example of ambiguity, where the properties of a whole are incorrectly assumed to apply to its individual parts.

 

(D) Begging the Question: This fallacy involves presumption, where the argument assumes the truth of what it is trying to prove, essentially using the conclusion as a premise.

 

Thus, the correct answer is (D) (A)-(IV), (B)-(III), (C)-(II), (D)-(I).

Question 30
According to Nyāya logic, which of the following statements is fallacious because it involves a non-inferentially contradicted middle term?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.The hill has fire because it is knowable
  • B.Fire is cold because it is a substance
  • C.All things are non-eternal because they are knowable
  • D.Sound is eternal because it is audible
Correct Answer: Fire is cold because it is a substance

Given is the fallacies related to "Badhita".

 

Badhita is the non-inferentially contradicted middle. Here the middle term is contradicted by some other pramana and not by inference. It cannot prove the major term which is disproved by another stronger source of valid knowledge; e.g., ‘fire is cold, because it is a substance'. Here the middle term ‘substance' becomes contradicted because its major term ‘coldness' is directly contradicted by perception.

Question 31
With reference to computer networking, which of the following statements is true of an Intranet?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.It is a network within an organization that uses Internet protocols and technologies.
  • B.It is a network that covers a wide area with the help of rented telecommunication lines.
  • C.It is a network where a computer is connected to the Internet and acts as a gateway for other devices.
  • D.It is a widely available public network of interconnected computer networks.
Correct Answer: It is a network within an organization that uses Internet protocols and technologies.

The correct answer is: (A) It is a network within an organization that uses Internet protocols and technologies.

 

An Intranet is a private network accessible only to an organization's staff. It often uses the same protocols and technologies as the Internet (like TCP/IP, HTTP, and web browsers), but is restricted to internal use, enhancing security and collaboration within the organization.

Question 32
Which of the following pair of acronym and its expansion is incorrectly matched?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.CDROM – Computer Disk Read Only Memory
  • B.CRT – Cathode Ray Tube
  • C.MICR – Magnetic Ink Character Recognition
  • D.AVI – Audio Video Interleave
Correct Answer: CDROM – Computer Disk Read Only Memory

The correct answer is: (A) CDROM – Computer Disk Read Only Memory

 

(A) Incorrect: CDROM stands for Compact Disc Read Only Memory, not "Computer Disk Read Only Memory".

 

(B) Correct: CRT = Cathode Ray Tube.

 

(C) Correct: MICR = Magnetic Ink Character Recognition.

 

(D) Correct: AVI = Audio Video Interleave.

Question 33
Identify the sequence of words A–E that correctly fills the blanks in the following paragraph:An operating system that uses windows, icons, menus and pointers for human-computer interaction is known as__. Post-WIMP interfaces found on devices like iPads, iPods and mobile phones make use of__technology that allows us to use our fingers to select icons and menus. Post-WIMP interfaces allow us to use__, rotating and swiping techniques. The technology that allows users to store documents, programs and data on Internet is known as__. Documents created using Google Docs are stored__on the Internet and can be accessed anywhere and at any time.(a) Touch Screen(b) Cloud Computing(c) GUI(d) Remotely(e) PinchingOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(c), (a), (e), (d), (b)
  • B.(a), (c), (d), (b), (e)
  • C.(b), (d), (c), (e), (a)
  • D.(c), (a), (e), (b), (d)
Correct Answer: (c), (a), (e), (b), (d)

The correct answer is: (D) (C), (A), (E), (B), (D)

 

Explanation of the paragraph with the correct sequence:

 

An operating system that uses windows, icons, menus and pointers for human-computer interaction is known as GUI. Post-WIMP interfaces found on devices like iPads, iPods and mobile phones make use of Touch Screen technology that allows us to use our fingers to select icons and menus. Post-WIMP interfaces allow us to use Pinching, rotating and swiping techniques. The technology that allows users to store documents, programs and data on Internet is known as Cloud Computing. Documents created using Google Docs are stored Remotely on the Internet and can be accessed anywhere and at any time.

Question 34
Which of the following devices are computer input devices only?A. DVD – RB. JoystickC. PlotterD. Touch PadE. MicrophoneChoose the correct answer from the options given below.(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, D and E only
  • B.B, D and E only
  • C.A, B and C only
  • D.B, C, D and E only
Correct Answer: B, D and E only

The correct answer is: (B) B, D and E only

 

Input devices are used to send data into the computer.

 

Joystick – Input device (used to control movement in games or simulations)

 

Touch Pad – Input device (like in laptops for controlling the cursor)

 

Microphone – Input device (used to input audio)

 

DVD-R – Not an input device; it's a storage medium.

 

Plotter – Output device (used for printing vector graphics)

Question 35
Match List - I with List – IIList I (Error Message in MS-Excel):(A) #####(B) #VALUE!(C) #REF!(D) #DIV/0List II (Error Description):(I) When the formula contains a cell reference that is pointing to an invalid cell(II) When you divide a number by a cell that points to an empty cell(III) When the arithmetic formula contains text instead of a number(IV) When the cell contains a number that is too wide for the result to be displayedOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(A)-(III), (B)-(IV), (C)-(II), (D)-(I)
  • B.(A)-(IV), (B)-(III), (C)-(I), (D)-(II)
  • C.(A)-(I), (B)-(IV), (C)-(II), (D)-(III)
  • D.(A)-(IV), (B)-(I), (C)-(III), (D)-(I)
Correct Answer: (A)-(IV), (B)-(III), (C)-(I), (D)-(II)

The correct answer is: (B) (A)-(IV), (B)-(III), (C)-(I), (D)-(II)

 

##### → (IV) The cell is not wide enough to display the number.

 

#VALUE! → (III) Occurs when there’s an invalid data type, like text in a formula expecting numbers.

 

#REF! → (I) Happens when a cell reference is invalid, often due to deleted cells.

 

#DIV/0! → (II) Occurs when trying to divide by zero or an empty cell.

Question 36
Pure rain water is naturally:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Mild Acidic
  • B.Mild Basic
  • C.Neutral
  • D.Strong Acidic
Correct Answer: Mild Acidic

The correct answer is: (A) Mild Acidic.

 

Pure rainwater is slightly acidic due to the dissolution of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, which forms carbonic acid (H₂CO₃). This results in a pH of around 5.6, making it mildly acidic.

Question 37
Presence of Lead in drinking water can adversely affect the human health. The three vital systems in the human body that are most sensitive to Lead are:(A) Nervous system(B) Cardio-vascular system(C) Renal system(D) Respiratory system(E) Blood forming systemOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(A), (C) and (E) Only
  • B.(B), (C) and (D) Only
  • C.(B), (D) and (E) Only
  • D.(A), (C) and (D) Only
Correct Answer: (A), (C) and (E) Only

The correct answer is: (A) (A), (C) and (E) Only.

 

Lead exposure primarily affects the following systems:

 

Nervous system - Lead is neurotoxic and can cause developmental issues in children, affecting cognitive abilities and behavior.

 

Renal system - Lead can impair kidney function, especially with prolonged exposure.

 

Blood-forming system - Lead interferes with the production of hemoglobin, leading to anemia.

 

The cardiovascular and respiratory systems are less directly affected by lead compared to these three systems.

Question 38
Which of the following represent the nutrient contents of a water body at different levels?(A) Phototropic(B) Eutrophic(C) Mesotrophic(D) Chemotrophic(E) OligotrophicOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(A), (C) and (E) Only
  • B.(B), (C) and (D) Only
  • C.(A), (B) and (D) Only
  • D.(B), (C) and (E) Only
Correct Answer: (B), (C) and (E) Only

The correct answer is: (D) (B), (C) and (E) Only

 

The terms eutrophic, mesotrophic, and oligotrophic refer to the nutrient levels and the productivity of water bodies:

 

Eutrophic - Water bodies that are rich in nutrients, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus, often leading to excessive plant growth and algal blooms.

 

Mesotrophic - Water bodies with moderate levels of nutrients, supporting a balanced amount of plant and animal life.

 

Oligotrophic - Water bodies with low nutrient levels, often supporting clear water and fewer plants and algae.

 

Phototropic refers to organisms that use light for energy (like plants), and chemotrophic refers to organisms that obtain energy from chemical reactions (usually in non-photosynthetic organisms).

Question 39
Which of the following are true about sound?(A) 10 decibel (dB) increase in sound is equal to 10 fold increase in sound intensity(B) 20 dB increase in sound is equal to 20 fold increase in sound intensity(C) Loudness is the human perception of sound intensity(D) The audible sound range is between 20 Hz to 20 kHz(E) Sound below 20 Hz is called ultrasound while above 20 kHz is called infrasoundOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(A), (B) and (D) Only
  • B.(B), (C) and (D) Only
  • C.(C), (D) and (E) Only
  • D.(A), (C) and (D) Only
Correct Answer: (C), (D) and (E) Only

The correct answer is: (C) (C), (D) and (E) Only.

 

(C) Loudness is the human perception of sound intensity: This is correct. Loudness is how we perceive the intensity or strength of sound.

 

(D) The audible sound range is between 20 Hz to 20 kHz: This is correct. The typical human hearing range is between 20 Hz and 20,000 Hz (20 kHz).

 

(E) Sound below 20 Hz is called infrasound while above 20 kHz is called ultrasound: This is also correct. Infrasound refers to sound below 20 Hz, and ultrasound refers to sound above 20 kHz.

Question 40
Which of the following greenhouse gases trapped in large quantity in permafrost and hydrates will likely be released in atmosphere due to global warming?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Nitrous Oxide (N₂O)
  • B.Methane (CH₄)
  • C.Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)
  • D.Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs)
Correct Answer: Methane (CH₄)

The correct answer is: (B) Methane (CH₄).

 

Methane (CH₄) is a potent greenhouse gas trapped in large quantities in permafrost and methane hydrates. Due to global warming, as the Earth's temperature rises, the permafrost and hydrates begin to thaw, releasing methane into the atmosphere, which can significantly contribute to further climate change.

Question 41
The Council of Education (in India) sought the establishment of a university in:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Bengal Presidency
  • B.Bombay Presidency
  • C.Madras Presidency
  • D.North-Western Provinces
Correct Answer: Bengal Presidency

The correct answer is: (A) Bengal Presidency.

 

The Council of Education in India, under the British colonial administration, recommended the establishment of the first university in Bengal Presidency, leading to the creation of the University of Calcutta in 1857, which was the first university in India. This was part of the British initiative to promote higher education in the country.

Question 42
According to the New Education Policy, 2020, who among the following must be at the centre of fundamental reforms in the education system?(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Policy makers
  • B.Teachers
  • C.Industry leaders
  • D.Administrators
Correct Answer: Teachers

The correct answer is: (B) Teachers

 

According to the New Education Policy (NEP), 2020, teachers must be at the center of fundamental reforms in the education system. The policy emphasizes the importance of empowering and equipping teachers with the necessary skills, training, and autonomy to improve the quality of education. Teachers play a crucial role in shaping the learning environment and are seen as central to the success of the education system.

Question 43
Which of the following Anglican Missionary Societies were most involved in teaching in high schools and colleges across North India in later part of Nineteenth century?(A) The Church Missionary Society(B) The London Missionary SocietyC) Society for the propagation of the Gospel(D) The Cambridge Mission to DelhiOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(A) and (B) Only
  • B.(A), (B), (C), (D)
  • C.(C) and (D) Only
  • D.(A), (C) and (D) Only
Correct Answer: (A), (B), (C), (D)

The correct answer is: (B) (A), (B), (C), (D)

 

All 4 of these Anglican Missionary Societies were involved in teaching in high schools and colleges across North India during the later part of the nineteenth century. They contributed significantly to education, particularly in urban areas, and helped establish schools and colleges that were instrumental in spreading education in India during British colonial rule.

Question 44
Find out the chronological order of the following agencies of educational administration in British India:(A) University Board(B) Board of Governors(C) Committee of Native Education(D) Council of Education(E) Department of Public InstructionOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(A), (C), (D), (E), (B)
  • B.(B), (E), (C), (A), (D)
  • C.(C), (A), (D), (B), (E)
  • D.(D), (E), (B), (C), (A)
Correct Answer: (C), (A), (D), (B), (E)

The correct answer is: (C) (C), (A), (D), (B), (E)

 

The chronological order of the educational administrative agencies in British India is as follows:

 

Committee of Native Education (C): Established in 1786, it was one of the earliest initiatives to review the state of education in India.

 

University Board (A): Formed in 1857, following the establishment of universities in India, particularly in Bombay, Calcutta, and Madras.

 

Council of Education (D): Formed in 1835, it was responsible for overseeing education policies and initiatives.

 

Board of Governors (B): Formed later as a body overseeing specific educational institutions.

 

Department of Public Instruction (E): Established in 1854 to administer public education, becoming a central agency for educational reforms.

 

This sequence reflects the historical development of educational administrative bodies during British rule in India.

Question 45
Match List - I with List – IIList - I (Author):(A) Gotama(B) Patanjali(C) Kautilya(D) KanādList - II (Ancient Text):(I) Vaiśeṣika sutras(II) Nyāya sutra(III) Yoga sutra(IV) ArthaśāstraOptions:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.(A)-(III), (B)-(II), (C)-(IV), (D)-(I)
  • B.(A)-(II), (B)-(III), (C)-(IV), (D)-(I)
  • C.(A)-(III), (B)-(II), (C)-(I), (D)-(IV)
  • D.(A)-(II), (B)-(IV), (C)-(III), (D)-(I)
Correct Answer: (A)-(II), (B)-(III), (C)-(IV), (D)-(I)

The correct answer is: (A) (A)-(III), (B)-(II), (C)-(IV), (D)-(I)

 

Explanation:

Gotama - He is associated with the Nyāya Sutra (II), which is a text focused on logic and epistemology.

 

Patanjali - He is associated with the Yoga Sutra (III), a foundational text of the Yoga school of philosophy.

 

Kautilya - He authored the Arthaśāstra (IV), which is an ancient Indian treatise on statecraft, economic policy, and military strategy.

 

Kanād - He authored the Vaiśeṣika Sutras (I), which is one of the six orthodox schools of Indian philosophy, focusing on the nature of reality and the classification of the universe.

Question 46
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.Adolescence is the most important period of human life. Poets have described it as the spring of life of human being and an important era in the total life span. The word adolescence comes from a Greek word ‘adolescere’ which means ‘to grow to maturity’. A number of definitions have been given by Psychologists from time to time. Some Psychologists define it as the transitional period of life. The child experiences a number of changes in this transitional period. The period runs between childhood and adulthood and is sometimes called the period of teenage.According to A. T. Jersild “Adolescence is that span of years during which boys and girls move from childhood to adulthood, mentally, emotionally, socially and physically”.Chronologically adolescence comes roughly in between the years from 12 to the early 20’s. The onset of adolescence varies from culture to culture depending on the socio-economic conditions of the country. In this period, great changes occur in all developmental dimensions of the individual.The term ‘adolescence’ means:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A state of bliss
  • B.Innocence of childhood
  • C.Moving towards maturity
  • D.Detachment from materialistic world
Correct Answer: Moving towards maturity

The passage states:

 

"The word adolescence comes from a Greek word ‘adolescere’ which means ‘to grow to maturity’."

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Question 47
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.Adolescence is the most important period of human life. Poets have described it as the spring of life of human being and an important era in the total life span. The word adolescence comes from a Greek word ‘adolescere’ which means ‘to grow to maturity’. A number of definitions have been given by Psychologists from time to time. Some Psychologists define it as the transitional period of life. The child experiences a number of changes in this transitional period. The period runs between childhood and adulthood and is sometimes called the period of teenage.According to A. T. Jersild “Adolescence is that span of years during which boys and girls move from childhood to adulthood, mentally, emotionally, socially and physically”.Chronologically adolescence comes roughly in between the years from 12 to the early 20’s. The onset of adolescence varies from culture to culture depending on the socio-economic conditions of the country. In this period, great changes occur in all developmental dimensions of the individual.The origin of the word ‘adolescence’ has come from the following language:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Latin
  • B.Greek
  • C.Sanskrit
  • D.German

Question 48
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.Adolescence is the most important period of human life. Poets have described it as the spring of life of human being and an important era in the total life span. The word adolescence comes from a Greek word ‘adolescere’ which means ‘to grow to maturity’. A number of definitions have been given by Psychologists from time to time. Some Psychologists define it as the transitional period of life. The child experiences a number of changes in this transitional period. The period runs between childhood and adulthood and is sometimes called the period of teenage.According to A. T. Jersild “Adolescence is that span of years during which boys and girls move from childhood to adulthood, mentally, emotionally, socially and physically”.Chronologically adolescence comes roughly in between the years from 12 to the early 20’s. The onset of adolescence varies from culture to culture depending on the socio-economic conditions of the country. In this period, great changes occur in all developmental dimensions of the individual.A.T. Jersild’s definition regarding adolescence highlights the following:(UGC NET 29 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A child moves from childhood to adulthood, mentally, emotionally, socially and physically.
  • B.Adolescents spend less time in front of the television than other age groups.
  • C.Adolescents reject their parents as companions and as a source of advice.
  • D.Only a minority of adolescents experience some serious psychological issues.
Correct Answer: A child moves from childhood to adulthood, mentally, emotionally, socially and physically.

The passage directly quotes A.T. Jersild's definition:

 

“Adolescence is that span of years during which boys and girls move from childhood to adulthood, mentally, emotionally, socially and physically.”

 

This aligns perfectly with Option (A), which paraphrases the same idea using the same four dimensions of development mentioned in the passage.

Question 49
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.Adolescence is the most important period of human life. Poets have described it as the spring of life of human being and an important era in the total life span. The word adolescence comes from a Greek word ‘adolescere’ which means ‘to grow to maturity’. A number of definitions have been given by Psychologists from time to time. Some Psychologists define it as the transitional period of life. The child experiences a number of changes in this transitional period. The period runs between childhood and adulthood and is sometimes called the period of teenage.According to A. T. Jersild “Adolescence is that span of years during which boys and girls move from childhood to adulthood, mentally, emotionally, socially and physically”.Chronologically adolescence comes roughly in between the years from 12 to the early 20’s. The onset of adolescence varies from culture to culture depending on the socio-economic conditions of the country.
