  • B.A-(III), B-(II), C-(IV), D-(I)
  • C.A-(II), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(I)
  • D.A-(I), B-(IV), C-(III), D-(II)
Correct Answer: A-(II), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(I)

Let’s match the tools with their correct applications:

Therefore, the correct answer is option (C).

 

Question 10
The contents ofSwayamprabha Channel–16 with the theme of “Skill and Vocational Education” are provided by:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.CEC, Delhi
  • B.IGNOU, Delhi
  • C.IIT, Bombay
  • D.IIT, Kanpur
Correct Answer: IGNOU, Delhi

The content of Swayamprabha Channel–16 with the theme of “Skill and Vocational Education” are provided by IGNOU, Delhi.

Question 11
Which of the following is the most appropriate for measuring the strength and direction of association between two interval/ratio variables?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Spearman's rho
  • B.Pearson's r
  • C.Phi
  • D.Eta
Correct Answer: Pearson's r

To measure the strength and direction of association between two interval/ratio variables, the most appropriate test is (B) Pearson's r.

(A) Spearman's rho: This is used for measuring the strength and direction of association between two ordinal variables, or when the relationship is not linear (non-parametric).

(B) Pearson's r: This is the correct answer. Pearson's correlation coefficient (r) is used to measure the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two interval or ratio variables.

(C) Phi: The Phi coefficient is used for measuring the association between two binary (dichotomous) variables.

(D) Eta: Eta is used to measure the relationship between a categorical independent variable and a continuous dependent variable, not specifically between two interval/ratio variables.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) Pearson's r.

Question 12
Which of the following methods of graphical representation of data would be useful for showing trends?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Bar charts
  • B.Line charts
  • C.Box plants
  • D.Pie charts
Correct Answer: Line charts

To show trends in data, the most appropriate graphical representation method is (B) Line charts.

(A) Bar charts: These are useful for comparing discrete categories or groups, but they do not typically show trends over time.

(B) Line charts: Line charts are excellent for showing trends over time or continuous data. The points on the line represent data at specific time intervals, and the line shows how the data changes.

(C) Box plots: These are used to display the distribution of data and to identify outliers, but they do not effectively show trends over time.

(D) Pie charts: Pie charts are used to represent parts of a whole, typically in categorical data, and are not suitable for showing trends.

Thus, the correct answer is (B) Line charts.

Question 13
Identify the main preoccupations of qualitative researches.A. GeneralizationB. DescriptionC. Emphasis on contextD. FlexibilityChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, B and D only
  • D.A, C and D only
Correct Answer: B, C and D only

In qualitative research, the main focus is on understanding deeper meanings, contexts, and the richness of individual experiences. The typical preoccupations in qualitative research are:

B. Description: Qualitative research is primarily concerned with providing a detailed, rich description of a phenomenon or the lived experiences of participants.

C. Emphasis on context: Qualitative research emphasizes the context in which the study takes place, as context plays a crucial role in shaping the experiences and understanding of participants.

D. Flexibility: Qualitative research is flexible and adaptive, allowing for changes in the approach as the research progresses and new insights emerge.

Question 14
Covariance i.e. Cov(X,Y) and standard deviations of different datasets are given. Estimate the correlation coefficients and arrange in increasing order:A. Cov(X,Y) = 32, σx= 8, σy= 7B. Cov(X,Y) = 36, σx= 12, σy= 5C. Cov(X,Y) = 35, σx= 7, σy= 8D. Cov(X,Y) = 39, σx= 6, σy= 13Choose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.B, C, D, A
  • C.C, D, A, B
  • D.D, A, B, C
Correct Answer: D, A, B, C

To estimate the correlation coefficient (denoted as 𝑟) for each dataset, we use the formula:

Thus, the correct answer is (D) D, A, B, C.

Question 15
Match List–I with List–II:List–I (Total Sum Squares (TSS) and Residual Sum of Squares (RSS))A. RSS = 25, TSS = 60B. RSS = 35, TSS = 75C. RSS = 30, TSS = 70D. RSS = 40, TSS = 75List–II (R² of Regression Model)(I) 0.46(II) 0.57(III) 0.53(IV) 0.58Options:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A–(I), B–(II), C–(III), D–(IV)
  • B.A–(II), B–(III), C–(IV), D–(I)
  • C.A–(III), B–(IV), C–(I), D–(II)
  • D.A–(IV), B–(III), C–(II), D–(I)
Correct Answer: A–(IV), B–(III), C–(II), D–(I)

Therefore, the correct answer is (D) A–(IV), B–(III), C–(II), D–(I).

Question 16
Which of the following has been criticized for ‘dumbing down’ the news media?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Weather broadcasts
  • B.Commercial brochures
  • C.Magazines
  • D.Television
Correct Answer: Television

The term “dumbing down” refers to the simplification or sensationalization of content, often at the expense of depth, accuracy, or critical analysis. In media studies, television — especially TV news — has frequently been criticized for:

  • prioritizing entertainment over information
  • focusing on sensational stories rather than complex issues
  • reducing critical journalism to sound bites, visuals, and simplified narratives

 

This criticism is particularly aimed at the way TV formats package news to attract mass audiences, sometimes compromising on quality and analytical depth.

Question 17
Today mass media exercise enormous(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Corporate power
  • B.Ethical might
  • C.Economic influence
  • D.Trade unionism
Correct Answer: Corporate power

While mass media has economic influence, the more accurate and commonly accepted answer in media studies and critical theory is corporate power — especially when discussing how mass media operate today.

 

The reasons are as follows:

 

  • Ownership Concentration: A few large corporations control a majority of the mass media (e.g., Disney, Comcast, Reliance, Times Group).

 

  • Agenda Setting: Media are used not just to inform, but to promote corporate interests, political alliances, and market ideologies.

 

  • Commercialization: Content is often influenced by the interests of advertisers, sponsors, and parent companies — not just public service or economic logic.

 

  • Cross-media synergy: Corporates owning multiple media platforms use them in integrated ways to expand influence and profit.
  •  

Thus, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 18
Which of the following are the feature of broadcast (first media) age?(A) Decentred(B) One-way communication(C) Many-way communication(D) Pre-disposed to state control(E) An instrument of inequalityChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B, C only
  • B.B, D, E only
  • C.C, D, E only
  • D.A, C, D only
Correct Answer: B, D, E only

The Broadcast Age (also known as the First Media Age) is associated with traditional mass communication like radio, television, and print, typically before the rise of the internet.

 

Key features of the Broadcast Age include:

 

B. One-way communication

Information flows from a single source to a passive audience. There is no interaction or feedback loop.

 

D. Pre-disposed to state control

Early broadcast media were often regulated or owned by the state, especially in developing countries or authoritarian regimes.

 

E. An instrument of inequality

Access to broadcasting tools was concentrated in the hands of elites, reinforcing social and informational inequality.

 

Let’s rule out the others:

 

A. Decentred – Broadcast media are typically centralized, with few producers and many receivers.

 

C Many-way communication – That’s a feature of the Internet/New Media Age, not the Broadcast Age.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 19
Identify the correct sequence of the emergence of the following concepts.(A) Virtual Communities(B) Cyber Culture(C) Being Digital(D) Tele Computer(E) Interactive Media CultureChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.B, C, D, A, E
  • C.D, A, C, E, B
  • D.C, D, E, A, B
Correct Answer: D, A, C, E, B

Let's place each concept chronologically based on their historical emergence and usage in academic or media contexts:

 

(D) Tele Computer –

 

Emerged in the 1970s–1980s, referring to devices combining telecommunication and computing capabilities — a forerunner to the modern internet.

 

(A) Virtual Communities –

 

Coined by Howard Rheingold in his 1993 book “The Virtual Community”, this concept refers to online social groups interacting through internet platforms.

 

(C) Being Digital –

 

A 1995 book by Nicholas Negroponte, discussing the digital transformation and convergence of media, communication, and computing.

 

(E) Interactive Media Culture –

 

Gained popularity in the late 1990s to 2000s, referring to user engagement with digital content, including games, social media, etc.

 

(B) Cyber Culture –

 

Although the term existed earlier, it became more mainstream and academically significant post-2000, analyzing the culture formed through cyberspace and digital interaction.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 20
MatchList–IwithList–II:List–I(Author)A. Manuel CastellsB. Trevor BarrC. Nicolas NegroponteD. Marshall McLuhanList–II(Concept)(I) Electronic Nomads(II) Post-Information Age(III) Global Village(IV) Interactive Media CultureOptions:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-(I), B-(II), C-(III), D-(IV)
  • B.A-(II), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(I)
  • C.A-(III), B-(IV), C-(I), D-(II)
  • D.A-(IV), B-(I), C-(II), D-(III)
Correct Answer: A-(IV), B-(I), C-(II), D-(III)

The correct match is option (D).

Question 21
Find the missing term in the series given below: 2, 12, 36, ?, 150.(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.80
  • B.72
  • C.100
  • D.86
Correct Answer: 80

The missing term is 80.

Question 22
A certain amount of money deposited in a bank becomes ₹1008 in 2 years and ₹1164 in 3½ years. Find the amount deposited in the bank and the rate of interest per annum.(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.₹700, 12%
  • B.₹800, 13%
  • C.₹750, 13%
  • D.₹850, 13.5%
Correct Answer: ₹800, 13%

Interest for 1 year = 1164-10081.5 = 104

Interest for 2 years = 2 × 104 = 208

P = 1008 – 208 = 800

R = 208×100800×2 = 14%

Question 23
If ‘CAKE’ is coded as 20 and ‘FAIL’ is coded as 28 then how shall ‘FIRST’ be coded?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.35
  • B.72
  • C.64
  • D.40
Correct Answer: 72

C A K E → 3 + 1 + 11 + 5 = 20

F A I L → 6 + 1 + 9 + 12 = 28

 

F I R S T → 6 + 9 + 18 + 19 + 20 = 72

Question 24
Forty five (45) men can do a job in 16 days. Six days after they started working, 30 more men joined them. How many days will they now take to complete the remaining work?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.5½ days
  • B.7 days
  • C.5 days
  • D.6 days
Correct Answer: 6 days

Total Work = 45 × 16 = 720 man-days

Work done in first 6 days by 45 men = 45 × 6 = 270 man-days

Remaining work = 720 − 270 = 450 man-days

 

Now 30 more men join → total = 45 + 30 = 75 men

Let the number of additional days required = x

Then, 75 × x = 450

or x = 6

Question 25
MatchList–IwithList–II:List–I(Expression)A. 0.1 × 5.5 × 55.5 × 0.5B. 0.01 × 0.55 × 5.55 × 0.05C. 0.1 × 0.55 × 55.5 × 0.005D. 0.01 × 5.5 × 5.55 × 0.5List–II(Value)(I) 0.00152625(II) 0.0152625(III) 0.152625(IV)15.2625Options:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-(I), B-(II), C-(III), D-(IV)
  • B.A-(II), B-(III), C-(IV), D-(I)
  • C.A-(IV), B-(I), C-(II), D-(III)
  • D.A-(IV), B-(II), C-(III), D-(I)
Correct Answer: A-(IV), B-(I), C-(II), D-(III)

A. 0.1 × 5.5 × 55.5 × 0.5 = 15.2625

B. 0.01 × 0.55 × 5.5 × 0.05 = 0.00152625

C. 0.1 × 0.55 × 55.5 × 0.005 = 0.0152625

D. 0.01 × 5.5 × 5.5 × 0.5 = 0.152625

Question 26
“Since all medical practitioners are competent and no competent people are underpaid. Therefore no medical practitioners are underpaid.”Which fallacy is committed in the above argument?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Hasty Generalisation
  • B.Affirming the consequent
  • C.Begging the question
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: None of above

There is no fallacy in the argument.

Question 27
If the statement “All Plants are Carnivorous” is given as false, which of the following statements can be inferred to be true:A. Some non-plants are non-carnivorousB. No Plants are carnivorousC. Some plants are carnivorousD. Some plants are not carnivorousChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.C only
  • B.B and D only
  • C.D only
  • D.A, B, C, D only
Correct Answer: D only

A is given as false THEN O is true; E and I are undetermined. Hence we can only infer “Some plants are not carnivorous”

Question 28
Which of the following propositions are Contrary?A. All cows are herbivoresB. No cows are herbivoresC. Some cows are herbivoresD. Some cows are not herbivoresChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A and C only
  • B.A and B only
  • C.C and D only
  • D.A and D only
Correct Answer: A and B only

The correct answer is: (B) A and B only

 

Contrary propositions are both universal but have opposite qualities (affirmative vs. negative), and both cannot be true at the same time, though both can be false.

 

In traditional logic (Aristotelian), this applies to:

A-type: All S are P

E-type: No S are P

 

Here:

A. All cows are herbivores → Universal Affirmative (A-type)

B. No cows are herbivores → Universal Negative (E-type

Question 29
From the following, identify the statements that are logically equivalent.A. No squares are circlesB. Some squares are not circlesC. Some non-circles are not non-squaresD. No circles are squaresChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.B and D only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A, B and C only
  • D.A, C and D only
Correct Answer: B and C only

Some non-circles are not non-squares is CONTRAPOSITION of Some squares are not circles.

Question 30
Which of the following statements are included in the inferential process for inferring fire from the perception of smoke as per Nyāya Philosophy?A. That hill has fire (Pratijñā)B. Since it has smoke (Hetu)C. Wherever there is fire, there is smoke, eg kitchen (Udāharana)D. That hill which is smokey, must have fire too (Upanaya)E. Therefore the hill has fire (Nigamana)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.A, B, D and E only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A and B only
Correct Answer: A, B, D and E only

The correct answer is (B) A, B, D and E only.

 

Let's break it down as per the Nyāya philosophy of inference:

 

Pratijñā (Proposition): The statement that needs to be proved. In this case, "That hill has fire" is the proposition we are trying to infer.

 

Hetu (Reason): The reason or cause behind the proposition. Here, "Since it has smoke" is the reason provided for inferring the fire.

 

Udāharana (Example or Illustration): A general rule or example supporting the reason. The statement "Wherever there is fire, there is smoke, e.g., kitchen" is the example used to generalize the reasoning.

 

Upanaya (Application): Applying the rule or example to the specific case. Here, "That hill which is smokey, must have fire too" applies the rule (where there is smoke, there is fire) to the case of the hill.

 

Nigamana (Conclusion): The final conclusion drawn based on the above reasoning. "Therefore, the hill has fire" is the conclusion.

 

Thus, the correct set of statements is A, B, D, and E, excluding C because it is the example (Udāharana) used to support the reasoning but not part of the inferential process itself.

Question 31
A keylogger, short for Keystroke logger, is a type of cyber threat. Keyloggers are a form of _______.(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Worm
  • B.Trojan Horse
  • C.Virus
  • D.Spyware
Correct Answer: Spyware

The correct answer is option (D) - Spyware.

 

A keylogger is a type of spyware that secretly records the keystrokes made by a user on a keyboard. It captures sensitive information like usernames, passwords, credit card numbers, etc., and sends it to a third party, often without the user's knowledge.

Question 32
Which of the following pair of acronyms and their expansion is incorrectly matched?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.ROM - Read Only Memory
  • B.WAN - Wide Area Network
  • C.OMR - Optical Mark Reader
  • D.USB - Universal Secure Bus
Correct Answer: USB - Universal Secure Bus

The correct answer is: (D) USB – Universal Secure Bus

 

USB actually stands for Universal Serial Bus, not "Universal Secure Bus."

 

All other options are correctly matched:

 

ROM – Read Only Memory

 

WAN – Wide Area Network

 

OMR – Optical Mark Reader

Question 33
In cyber world, Black Hat Hackers are individuals with extraordinary computing skills who use these skills with malicious intent.In this context, identify the correct order for a successful black hat operation.A. ScanningB. ReconnaissanceC. Gaining AccessD. Covering TracksE. Maintaining AccessChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B, C, E, D
  • B.B, A, C, E, D
  • C.C, D, B, A, E
  • D.D, C, A, E, B
Correct Answer: B, A, C, E, D

The correct answer is: (B) B, A, C, E, D

 

Here is the correct order for a typical Black Hat hacking operation:

 

B. Reconnaissance – Gathering preliminary information about the target (e.g., IP addresses, domain details).

 

A. Scanning – Actively probing the target to identify open ports, services, vulnerabilities, etc.

 

C. Gaining Access – Exploiting the identified vulnerabilities to enter the system.

 

E. Maintaining Access – Installing backdoors or creating new user accounts to return later.

 

D. Covering Tracks – Erasing logs or altering files to avoid detection.

Question 34
Which of the following software titles are examples of system software?A. UbuntuB. Google DocsC. MS-Office 365D. AndroidE. Chrome OSChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B, D and E only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A, D and E only
  • D.C, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, D and E only

The correct answer is: (C) A, D and E only

 

System software includes operating systems and utilities that manage computer hardware and software resources. Let's analyze each option:

 

A. Ubuntu – Yes, it is a Linux-based operating system.

 

B. Google Docs – No, it's an application software used for word processing.

 

C. MS-Office 365 – No, it's also an application software suite.

 

D. Android – Yes, it is an operating system for mobile devices.

 

E. Chrome OS – Yes, it's a Linux-based operating system by Google.

 

System software runs the device; application software helps users perform specific tasks.

Question 35
Match theList–IwithList–II:List–I (Unit of Data Capacity)A. KilobyteB. GigabyteC. TerabyteD. MegabyteList–II(Approximate Size)I. 8 billion bitsII. 8 million bitsIII. 8 thousand bitsIV. 8 trillion bitsOptions:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
  • B.A–IV, B–II, C–I, D–III
  • C.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • D.A–I, B–III, C–II, D–IV
Correct Answer: A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

The correct answer is: (A) A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

1 Kilobyte = 1,000 Bytes (Decimal) = 8000 bits
1 Gigabyte = 8,000,000,000 bits = 8 billion bits
1 Terabyte = 8 trillion bits
1 Megabyte = 8 million bits

Question 36
Match the List–I with List–IIList–I (Fuel Type)A. Non fuelB. Alternative fuelC. Non-traditional fossil fuelD. Emerging fuelList–II (Example)I. BiodieselII. Hydrogen fuel cellIII. Wind powerIV. Compressed Natural Gas (CNG)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • B.A-IV, B-II, C-III, D-I
  • C.A-I, B-III, C-IV, D-II
  • D.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
Correct Answer: A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II

The correct answer is: (D) A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

 

A. Non fuel → III. Wind power

(Wind power is a source of energy, but not a fuel in itself.)

 

B. Alternative fuel → I. Biodiesel

(Biodiesel is used as an alternative to conventional diesel.)

 

C. Non-traditional fossil fuel → IV. Compressed Natural Gas (CNG)

(CNG is a cleaner fossil fuel but not as widely used as coal or oil.)

 

D. Emerging fuel → II. Hydrogen fuel cell

(Hydrogen is considered an emerging, future-oriented fuel technology.)

Question 37
Which of the following is not caused due to noise pollution?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Bronchitis
  • B.Cardiovascular diseases
  • C.High Blood Pressure
  • D.Insomnia
Correct Answer: Bronchitis

The correct answer is: (A) Bronchitis

 

Bronchitis is a respiratory condition typically caused by infections or exposure to pollutants like smoke or dust—not noise.

 

Cardiovascular diseases, High Blood Pressure, and Insomnia can all be induced or worsened by chronic exposure to noise pollution, due to stress and disturbance of natural bodily rhythms.

Question 38
Which of the following are true about Waste-to-Energy incinerations?A. It serves dual purpose of disposing municipal solid waste and producing energyB. It produces fly ashC. It produces bottom ashD. It generates a high level toxic air pollutant-dioxinE. It produces toxic metals such as Lead and MercuryChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, C, D and E only
  • B.A, B, D and E only
  • C.B and C only
  • D.A, B, C, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C, D and E only

The correct answer is: (D) A, B, C, D and E only

 

Explanation:

All the listed statements about Waste-to-Energy (WTE) incineration are true:

 

A. True – WTE incineration helps dispose of municipal solid waste while generating electricity or heat.

 

B. True – It produces fly ash, which is a fine particulate waste carried with flue gases.

 

C. True – It also produces bottom ash, the heavier residue that remains after combustion.

 

D. True – Dioxins, which are highly toxic air pollutants, can be released if not properly controlled.

 

E. True – Toxic heavy metals such as lead and mercury can be emitted or remain in ash residues.

Question 39
Which of the following cause indirect Green House Warming?A.CH4B. NOC.NO2D.N2OE. COChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.A and D only
  • C.B, D and E only
  • D.B, C and E only
Correct Answer: B, C and E only

The correct answer is: (D) B, C and E only

 

Indirect greenhouse warming refers to gases that indirectly contribute to the greenhouse effect, typically by reacting in the atmosphere to produce secondary greenhouse gases or by influencing the chemical composition of the atmosphere.

 

B. NO (Nitric Oxide) – NO can react in the atmosphere to form NO₂, which is a greenhouse gas.

 

C. NO₂ (Nitrogen Dioxide) – NO₂ can contribute to the formation of ozone (O₃), a potent greenhouse gas.

 

E. CO (Carbon Monoxide) – CO, when oxidized, can contribute to the formation of CO₂, which is a direct greenhouse gas.

 

Direct Greenhouse Gases:

A. CH₄ (Methane) and D. N₂O (Nitrous Oxide) are direct greenhouse gases, not indirect.

Question 40
So far, which of the following countries has not ratified the Convention on Biological Diversity?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.India
  • B.China
  • C.Russia
  • D.United States of America
Correct Answer: United States of America

The correct answer is: (D) United States of America.

 

The United States is the only country that has not ratified the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD). While it signed the convention, it has not completed the ratification process due to lack of approval from the U.S. Senate. This means that, despite being a signatory, the U.S. is not legally bound by the treaty's provisions. On the other hand, India, China, and Russia have all ratified the CBD and are committed to its goals.

Question 41
The names of great scholars like Raghunath, Raghunandan and Sri Chaitanya were associated with which of the following ancient university?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Sridhanya Katak
  • B.Vikramshila
  • C.Sakya
  • D.Odantapuri
Correct Answer: Vikramshila

The correct answer is option (B) - Vikramshila.

 

Vikramshila was one of the ancient universities of India, and it played a major role in the development of Hindu and Buddhist philosophy. Scholars such as Raghunath, Raghunandan, and Sri Chaitanya were associated with this university. It was known for its prominent Buddhist scholars and was a major center of learning, especially under the rule of the Pala dynasty.

Question 42
The professional organization that opposed the inclusion of its educational discipline under NCHER was:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Education Council of India
  • B.Dental Council of India
  • C.Architectural Council of India
  • D.Bar Council of India
Correct Answer: Bar Council of India

The correct answer is: (D) Bar Council of India.

 

The Bar Council of India opposed the inclusion of its educational discipline under the National Commission for Higher Education and Research (NCHER). The Bar Council of India is a statutory body that regulates legal education and profession in India, and it sought to retain its autonomy over legal education, which led to its opposition to being governed by the NCHER.

Question 43
The recommendations of the National Council of Teachers Education (1976) were:A. Limiting the number of teacher education collegesB. Universities should recognize short term courses for in-service education for teachersC. Avoidance of correspondence courses for in-service teachersD. Use of technological aids like television, films and othersE. Formulation of a network of extension services for in-service teachersChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, B, C only
  • B.B, C, D only
  • C.C, D, E only
  • D.B, D, E only
Correct Answer: B, D, E only

The correct answer is: (D) B, D, E only.

 

The National Council of Teachers Education (NCTE) made several recommendations in 1976 to improve the quality of teacher education in India. These included:

 

B: Universities should recognize short-term courses for in-service education for teachers.

 

D: Use of technological aids like television, films, and others to enhance teaching.

 

E: Formulation of a network of extension services for in-service teachers to improve their ongoing professional development.

Question 44
The National Education Policy, 2020, recommended certain verticals under Higher Education Commission of India. They are:A. NHERC (National Higher Education Regulatory Council)B. NAC (National Accreditation Council)C. HEGC (Higher Education Grants Council)D. GEC (General Education Council)E. OLC (Open Learning Council)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A, D, E only
  • B.A, B, C, D only
  • C.B, C, D, E only
  • D.A, B, C, E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C, D only

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The National Education Policy, 2020, recommended certain verticals under Higher Education Commission of India. They are:
A. NHERC (National Higher Education Regulatory Council)
B. NAC (National Accreditation Council)
C. HEGC (Higher Education Grants Council)
D. GEC (General Education Council)

Question 45
Match the List–I with List–II.List–I(Proponent)A. Lord DalhousieB. Annie BesantC. Lord CurzonD. Lord AucklandList–II (Initiative)I. Support to oriental educationII. Technical educationIII. Moral educationIV. Reform and control of higher educationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
Correct Answer: A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I

The correct answer is: (B) A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I.

 

A. Lord Dalhousie: Lord Dalhousie is known for his promotion of technical education during his tenure as the Governor-General of India. This matches with II. Technical education.

 

B. Annie Besant: Annie Besant was an advocate for moral education, particularly for the upliftment of the Indian population, matching with III. Moral education.

 

C. Lord Curzon: Lord Curzon was involved in the reform and control of higher education, especially the introduction of the Calcutta University Act in 1904, making it match with IV. Reform and control of higher education.

 

D. Lord Auckland: Lord Auckland is associated with support to oriental education, promoting the study of Indian languages and culture, matching with I. Support to oriental education.

Question 46
Read the passage and answer the following questions:Anthropologists have questioned universal explanations of war. Some hold out the hope that war, like slavery, can be erased by wise collective decision-making. But warfare is too diverse and historically widespread to be cured by simple remedies. Economic motives have always existed. A fight for salt or metals, gold and treasure, enslaved labour or access to trade routes, or oil and other resources has marked many of the world’s violent conflicts. But ideological and religious confrontations have also driven war. Hubristic warfare from Alexander to Napolean to Hitler was meant to establish dominion. The rise of Chinese power has provoked questions on whether potential conflict with US will descend into war. The search for security can be found in every warlike episode, as frontiers feel fragile. Is war on the decline, with new forms of settling conflict, cyber-attacks, and so on? The wars of this very century belie that hope. An ecological crisis, resource stresses and clashes of beliefs are only too visible in the emerging international order. And so, the future of war might not look very different from its past.What do some anthropologists think and hope about war?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.War will continue forever
  • B.War will keep on evolving taking a new form
  • C.War can be eradicated by wise collective decision making
  • D.War will happen more frequently
Correct Answer: War can be eradicated by wise collective decision making

The passage states:

 

"Some [anthropologists] hold out the hope that war, like slavery, can be erased by wise collective decision-making."

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 47
Read the passage and answer the following questions:Anthropologists have questioned universal explanations of war. Some hold out the hope that war, like slavery, can be erased by wise collective decision-making. But warfare is too diverse and historically widespread to be cured by simple remedies. Economic motives have always existed. A fight for salt or metals, gold and treasure, enslaved labour or access to trade routes, or oil and other resources has marked many of the world’s violent conflicts. But ideological and religious confrontations have also driven war. Hubristic warfare from Alexander to Napolean to Hitler was meant to establish dominion. The rise of Chinese power has provoked questions on whether potential conflict with US will descend into war. The search for security can be found in every warlike episode, as frontiers feel fragile. Is war on the decline, with new forms of settling conflict, cyber-attacks, and so on? The wars of this very century belie that hope. An ecological crisis, resource stresses and clashes of beliefs are only too visible in the emerging international order. And so, the future of war might not look very different from its past.According to the text, why is it difficult to eliminate war from the world?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Because it is too diverse and historically widespread
  • B.Because it is not difficult to understand people and society
  • C.Because of the modern technology
  • D.Because of the rich people
Correct Answer: Because it is too diverse and historically widespread

The passage clearly states:

 

"But warfare is too diverse and historically widespread to be cured by simple remedies."

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 48
Read the passage and answer the following questions:Anthropologists have questioned universal explanations of war. Some hold out the hope that war, like slavery, can be erased by wise collective decision-making. But warfare is too diverse and historically widespread to be cured by simple remedies. Economic motives have always existed. A fight for salt or metals, gold and treasure, enslaved labour or access to trade routes, or oil and other resources has marked many of the world’s violent conflicts. But ideological and religious confrontations have also driven war. Hubristic warfare from Alexander to Napolean to Hitler was meant to establish dominion. The rise of Chinese power has provoked questions on whether potential conflict with US will descend into war. The search for security can be found in every warlike episode, as frontiers feel fragile. Is war on the decline, with new forms of settling conflict, cyber-attacks, and so on? The wars of this very century belie that hope. An ecological crisis, resource stresses and clashes of beliefs are only too visible in the emerging international order. And so, the future of war might not look very different from its past.What all economic motives have historically driven war?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Only gold and treasure
  • B.Only salt and metals
  • C.Only trade routes
  • D.Various resources including salt, metals, gold, treasure, enslaved labour, trade routes and oil
Correct Answer: Various resources including salt, metals, gold, treasure, enslaved labour, trade routes and oil

The passage clearly lists multiple economic motives that have historically driven wars:

 

"A fight for salt or metals, gold and treasure, enslaved labour or access to trade routes, or oil and other resources has marked many of the world’s violent conflicts."

 

Options (A), (B), and (C) are each incomplete as they mention only one aspect.

Question 49
Read the passage and answer the following questions:Anthropologists have questioned universal explanations of war. Some hold out the hope that war, like slavery, can be erased by wise collective decision-making. But warfare is too diverse and historically widespread to be cured by simple remedies. Economic motives have always existed. A fight for salt or metals, gold and treasure, enslaved labour or access to trade routes, or oil and other resources has marked many of the world’s violent conflicts. But ideological and religious confrontations have also driven war. Hubristic warfare from Alexander to Napolean to Hitler was meant to establish dominion. The rise of Chinese power has provoked questions on whether potential conflict with US will descend into war. The search for security can be found in every warlike episode, as frontiers feel fragile. Is war on the decline, with new forms of settling conflict, cyber-attacks, and so on? The wars of this very century belie that hope. An ecological crisis, resource stresses and clashes of beliefs are only too visible in the emerging international order. And so, the future of war might not look very different from its past.Which of the following terms has been used to describe wars meant to establish dominion by leaders like Alexander, Napoleon and Hitler?(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Resource Wars
  • B.Defensive Wars
  • C.Hubristic Warfare
  • D.Revolutionary Wars
Correct Answer: Hubristic Warfare

The passage clearly states:

 

“Hubristic warfare from Alexander to Napoleon to Hitler was meant to establish dominion.”

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 50
Read the passage and answer the following questions:Anthropologists have questioned universal explanations of war. Some hold out the hope that war, like slavery, can be erased by wise collective decision-making. But warfare is too diverse and historically widespread to be cured by simple remedies. Economic motives have always existed. A fight for salt or metals, gold and treasure, enslaved labour or access to trade routes, or oil and other resources has marked many of the world’s violent conflicts. But ideological and religious confrontations have also driven war. Hubristic warfare from Alexander to Napolean to Hitler was meant to establish dominion. The rise of Chinese power has provoked questions on whether potential conflict with US will descend into war. The search for security can be found in every warlike episode, as frontiers feel fragile. Is war on the decline, with new forms of settling conflict, cyber-attacks, and so on? The wars of this very century belie that hope. An ecological crisis, resource stresses and clashes of beliefs are only too visible in the emerging international order. And so, the future of war might not look very different from its past.Common element that is found in every warlike episode mentioned in the text is:(UGC NET 28 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Technological advancement
  • B.Economic upliftment
  • C.Search for security
  • D.Ecological balance
Correct Answer: Search for security

The relevant line from the passage is:

 

"The search for security can be found in every warlike episode, as frontiers feel fragile."

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).
